urn:contentItem:5TDG-SGP1-JBYT-H1TK-00000-00Senate Panel Opens Hearing on Crafting U.S. Privacy Law2018-09-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:47ZLexisNexisSenate Panel Opens Hearing on Crafting U.S. Privacy LawNew Delhi

New Delhi, Sep. 27 -- The Trump administration is hoping Congress can come up with a new set of national rules governing how companies can use consumers' data that finds a balance between "privacy and prosperity."


But it will be tricky to reconcile the concerns of privacy advocates who want people to have more control over the usage of their personal data - where they've been, what they view, who their friends are - and the powerful companies that mine it for profit.
Senior executives from AT&T, Amazon, Apple, Google, Twitter and Charter Communications are scheduled to testify at the hearing, amid increasing anxiety over safeguarding consumers' data online and recent scandals that have stoked outrage among users and politicians.
Sen. John Thune, a South Dakota Republican who heads the Senate Commerce Committee, opened Wednesday's hearing by saying there's a strong desire by both Republicans and Democrats for a new data privacy law.
But the approach being pondered by policymakers and pushed by the internet industry leans toward a relatively light government touch. That's in contrast to stricter EU rules that took effect in May.
An early move in President Donald Trump's tenure set the tone on data privacy. He signed a bill into law in April 2017 that allows internet providers to sell information about their customers' browsing habits. The legislation scrapped Obama-era online privacy rules aimed at giving consumers more control over how broadband companies like AT&T, Comcast and Verizon share that information.
Allie Bohm, policy counsel at the consumer group Public Knowledge, says examples abound of companies not only using the data to market products but also to profile consumers and restrict who sees their offerings: African Americans not getting access to ads for housing, minorities and older people excluded from seeing job postings.
The companies "aren't going to tell that story" to the Senate panel, she said. "These companies make their money off consumer data."
What is needed, privacy advocates maintain, is legislation to govern the entire "life cycle" of consumers' data: how it's collected, used, kept, shared and sold.
Meanwhile, regulators elsewhere have started to act.
The 28-nation European Union put in strict new rules this spring that require companies to justify why they're collecting and using personal data gleaned from phones, apps and visited websites. Companies also must give EU users the ability to access and delete data, and to object to data use under one of the claimed reasons.
A similar law in California will compel companies to tell customers upon request what personal data they've collected, why it was collected and what types of third parties have received it. Companies will be able to offer discounts to customers who allow their data to be sold and to charge those who opt out a reasonable amount, based on how much the company makes selling the information.
Andrew DeVore, Amazon's vice president and associate general counsel, told the Senate panel Wednesday that it should consider the "possible unintended consequences" of California's approach. For instance, he says the state law defines personal information too broadly such that it could include all data.
The California law doesn't take effect until 2020 and applies only to California consumers, but it could have fallout effects on other states. And it's strong enough to have rattled Big Tech, which is seeking a federal data-privacy law that would be more lenient toward the industry.
"A national privacy framework should be consistent throughout all states, pre-empting state consumer-privacy and data security laws," the Internet Association said in a recent statement . The group represents about 40 big internet and tech companies, spanning Airbnb and Amazon to Zillow. "A strong national baseline creates clear rules for companies."
The Trump White House said this summer that the administration is working on it, meeting with companies and other interested parties. Thune's pronouncement and one from a White House official stress that a balance should be struck in any new legislation - between government supervision and technological advancement.
The goal is a policy "that is the appropriate balance between privacy and prosperity," White House spokeswoman Lindsay Walters said. "We look forward to working with Congress on a legislative solution."

urn:contentItem:60XC-TCK1-F03R-N1K5-00000-00Senate panel plans subpoena vote for Google, Facebook, Twitter CEOs2020-09-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:47ZLexisNexisSenate panel plans subpoena vote for Google, Facebook, Twitter CEOsAshley Gold

Sep 24, 2020( Axios: https://link.axios.com/join/am-signup?source=aci Delivered by Newstex) The Senate Commerce Committee plans to hold a subpoena vote to compel testimony from the top executives of Google, Facebook and Twitter for a hearing next month, the panel announced Thursday.Why it matters: The subpoena threat is the latest move by lawmakers to pare back the tech industry's prized liability shield, Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. Lawmakers want to hold another hearing on the topic with industry executives as legislative proposals work their way through Congress. Context: On Wednesday, the Department of Justice unveiled suggested language to amend the law[1] with the backing of the White House and Republican attorneys general. What's happening: On Oct. 1, the Senate Commerce Committee will vote to authorize subpoenas for Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg, Google's Sundar Pichai and Twitter's Jack Dorsey.But, but, but: It's doubtful Democrats will be on board, which puts the outcome of the subpoena vote in flux, though Republicans run the Senate Commerce Committee. On Thursday, Sen. Maria Cantwell (D-Wash.), the committee's ranking Democrat, said in a statement that she would not "participate in an attempt to use the committee's serious subpoena power for a partisan effort 40 days before an election." WASHINGTON - The Trump administration is hoping Congress can come up with a new set of national rules governing how companies can use consumers' data that finds a balance between "privacy and prosperity."

But it will be tricky to reconcile the concerns of privacy advocates who want people to have more control over the usage of their personal data - where they've been, what they view, who their friends are -and the powerful companies that mine it for profit.

Executives of a half-dozen U.S. internet titans are due to appear Wednesday before the Senate Commerce Committee to explain their privacy policies. Senior executives from AT&;T, Amazon, Apple, Google, Twitter and Charter Communications are expected to testify at the hearing, amid increasing anxiety over safeguarding consumers' data online and recent scandals that have stoked outrage among users and politicians.

But the approach to privacy legislation being pondered by policymakers and pushed by the internet industry leans toward a relatively light government touch.

An early move in President Donald Trump's tenure set the tone on data privacy. He signed a bill into law in April 2017 that allows internet providers to sell information about their customers' browsing habits. The legislation scrapped Obama-era online privacy rules aimed at giving consumers more control over how broadband companies like AT&;T, Comcast and Verizonshare that information.

Allie Bohm, policy counsel at the consumer group Public Knowledge, says examples abound of companies not only using the data to market products but also to profile consumers and restrict who sees their offerings: African Americans not getting access to ads for housing, minorities and older people excluded from seeing job postings.

The companies "aren't going to tell that story" to the Senate panel, she said. "These companies make their money off consumer data."

What is needed, privacy advocates maintain, is legislation to govern the entire "life cycle" of consumers' data: how it's collected, used, kept, shared and sold.

Meanwhile, regulators elsewhere have started to act.

The 28-nation European Union put in strict new rules this spring that require companies to justify why they're collecting and using personal data gleaned from phones, apps and visited websites. Companies also must give EU users the ability to access and delete data, and to object to data use under one of the claimed reasons.

A similar law in California will compel companies to tell customers upon request what personal data they've collected, why it was collected and what types of third parties have received it. Companies will be able to offer discounts to customers who allow their data to be sold and to charge those who opt out a reasonable amount, based on how much the company makes selling the information.

The California law doesn't take effect until 2020 and applies only to California consumers, but it could have fallout effects on other states. And it's strong enough to have rattled Big Tech, which is seeking a federal data-privacy law that would be more lenient toward the industry.

"A national privacy framework should be consistent throughout all states, pre-empting state consumer-privacy and data security laws," the Internet Association said in a recent statement . The group represents about 40 big internet and tech companies, spanning Airbnb and Amazon to Zillow. "A strong national baseline creates clear rules for companies."

The Trump White House said this summer that the administration is working on it, meeting with companies and other interested parties. Thune's pronouncement and one from a White House official stress that a balance should be struck in any new legislation - between government supervision and technological advancement.

An early move in President Donald Trump's tenure set the tone on data privacy. He signed a bill into law in April 2017 that allows internet providers to sell information about their customers' browsing habits. The legislation scrapped Obama-era online privacy rules aimed at giving consumers more control over how broadband companies like AT&;T, Comcast and Verizon share that information.

Allie Bohm, policy counsel at the consumer group Public Knowledge, says examples abound of companies not only using the data to market products but also to profile consumers and restrict who sees their offerings: African Americans not getting access to ads for housing, minorities and older people excluded from seeing job postings.

The companies "aren't going to tell that story" to the Senate panel, she said. "These companies make their money off consumer data."

What is needed, privacy advocates maintain, is legislation to govern the entire "life cycle" of consumers' data: how it's collected, used, kept, shared and sold.

Meanwhile, regulators elsewhere have started to act.

The 28-nation European Union put in strict new rules this spring that require companies to justify why they're collecting and using personal data gleaned from phones, apps and visited websites. Companies also must give EU users the ability to access and delete data, and to object to data use under one of the claimed reasons.

A similar law in California will compel companies to tell customers upon request what personal data they've collected, why it was collected and what types of third parties have received it. Companies will be able to offer discounts to customers who allow their data to be sold and to charge those who opt out a reasonable amount, based on how much the company makes selling the information.

The California law doesn't take effect until 2020 and applies only to California consumers, but it could have fallout effects on other states. And it's strong enough to have rattled Big Tech, which is seeking a federal data-privacy law that would be more lenient toward the industry.

"A national privacy framework should be consistent throughout all states, pre-empting state consumer-privacy and data security laws," the Internet Association said in a recent statement . The group represents about 40 big internet and tech companies, spanning Airbnb and Amazon to Zillow. "A strong national baseline creates clear rules for companies."

The Trump White House said this summer that the administration is working on it, meeting with companies and other interested parties. Thune's pronouncement and one from a White House official stress that a balance should be struck in any new legislation - between government supervision and technological advancement.

The goal is a policy "that is the appropriate balance between privacy and prosperity," White House spokeswoman Lindsay Walters said. "We look forward to working with Congress on a legislative solution." !@COPYRIGHT=© 2018 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: I can't believe that we work in industries where we have to wear make-up every day and worry about like flight delays. I can't believe it. Thank you, ladies. Good to see you, guys.

Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Wednesday, December 20th. Your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

The Senate making history. Republicans approving the largest overhaul of our country's tax system in about 30 years, early this morning.

(BEING VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. MITCH MCCONNELL (R), KENTUCKY: I'm a little surprised the democrats all decided voting against middle class tax relief and make American business more competitive as a smart vote and that's an argument we're more than happy to have.

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D), NEW YORK: Eighty-three percent of the middle class will get -- will either pay more in taxes or get little breadcrumbs. Is that this great bill that's helping the middle class? Absolutely not.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The house will vote on the bill later today, likely sending it to the President Trump's desk to sign.

The house originally did pass it yesterday, but there was a procedural snag that is forced the second vote. It was a snag over in the senate. Following the passage in the senate, futures are showing this happening in the markets. We had a slight full back in the Dow yesterday, off about 37 points. But we're seeing possibly new all-time highs for all your major market gauges.

By the way, you have highs on the transports earlier in the week on the Russell 2000. Literally every single market gauge in the U.S. has been moving in sync on the optimism from this tax reform package.

Over in Europe, checking on England, France and Germany, we have losses across the board. All those slight, all markets there down, lessen, about two tenths of a percent.

In Asia overnight stocks mostly lower as well. The Nikkei in Japan up ever so slightly.

ISIS threatening America. The terror group warning of the New Year's Eve attack. The latest as New York Governor, Andrew Cuomo announces heightened security measures for the holidays.

Uber, dealt a blow in Europe. The EU's top core has ruled that the ridesharing company is a taxi service and should be regulated as such. We break down the major implications of that ruling.

What can brown do for Tesla? The details as UPS delivers a big bet on the company's electric semi-truck.

And Diddy making moves to be the top cat down in Carolina. The music mogul reportedly meeting with ambassadors in his bid to buy the Panthers. How the teams could soon have a new owner. All of that and so much more coming up this morning.

Fox News correspondent, Lea Gabrielle, Benchmark managing partner, Kevin Kelly and Forbes Media chairman, former republican presidential candidate, Steve Forbes.

When you walked in this morning, I went I am so glad you're here. Any day, but particularly this day, Mr. Forbes.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good to be with you.

MCDOWELL: Because we have the same feeling about this tax cut package. But if you listen to the democrats, we're going to hell. That's pretty much the message. The country is going hell. It's savory and I just say, poppycock to that. So we're going to get into that immediately.

FORBES: Yes, it's a good word to use on a family channel.

MCDOWELL: Yes. I have an entire lexicon of things like that, like gooey and poppycock, and balderdash. So I will break all of that out.

KEVIN KELLY, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: I think I heard you called the democrats when it's coming into this plain nincompoops.

LEA GABRIELLE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: You know what? I actually called the republicans nincompoops.

KELLY: That's what it is.

MCDOWELL: As thy are putting this together, this is --

FORBES: Another old word is knuckleheads.

MCDOWELL: Knuckleheads. This is what we're going to talk about though, that why do people not yet feel good about this tax reform? Part of it is the problem of how they put it together. So we're going to talk about that in two seconds. I just want to tease our guests that are coming up, Illinois congressman, Peter Roskam. Fox News senior judicial analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. Louisiana senator, John Kennedy. Former republican presidential candidate, Herman Cain. And administrator of the small business administration, Linda McMahaon. There's a lot in this package for small businesses as well.

But first, on the verge of a big tax victory. Republicans are set to give their final approval to a sweeping tax overhaul today after the senate passed a plan and a late night vote.

House are scheduled a final vote this morning on the plan ready to send it to President Trump's desk to sign it into law.

Senate Majority Leader, Mitch McConnell says that both American businesses and individual tax payers will see the benefit.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MCCONNELL: We had three, two quarters in a row of three percent growth. Stock market is up. Optimism is high. Coupled with this tax reform, America is ready to start performing as they should have for a number of years.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The president congratulating lawmakers on Twitter, writing "The United States senate just passed the biggest in history tax cut in reform barrel. Terrible individual mandate, Obamacare repealed. Goes to the house tomorrow morning for a final vote. If approved, there will be a news conference at the White House at approximately 1:00 p.m.

Steve Forbes, we're on the precipice of passing this first major tax overhaul. "The Wall Street Journal" is saying certainly on the business side, it actually does more in some ways than the '86 tax reform did in terms of reforming corporate taxes.

FORBES: The big news on the business side reducing the rate, corporate rate down to 21 and pastors and its partnerships, Ascopr in the like which how most American businesses organize for tax purposes. They got that rate down. Looks like 29.6. We'll have to see the final details on that.

Overseas earnings, no longer being penalized and bringing some of that cash back home. Instant expensing. So if there are no sleepers in this bill, and the market, I think would have fare the amount by now. They did good on that side. The individual side is where they've got to do work the next time.

And I hope today --

GABRIELLE: When is the next time? When is that?

FORBES: Well, this is what they should announce today. That oh, yes, it's great history, since 1986 and all that good stuff. What they should also announce is this is a down payment. This is the first of many big tax cuts to come. Give people anticipation, especially on the individual side. We're going to keep slashing taxes because you the Americans create the resources and can employ them better than Washington bureaucrats.

GABRIELLE: I think the question though for many of us, is that really possible if you look at the debt worth, 20 trillion in debt and people can show that a national security issue. So, can you -- is it really feasible --

FORBES: What history shows -- experience shows is the only way you get a balanced budget, if you want that is what the booming economy. Late 1960s. Kennedy tax cuts, finally in the 90s, after the Cold War and Reagan's Cold War victory massive tax cuts. So if you want to get the Russian's fiscal situation under control, that economy where people feel good.

MCDOWELL: On that note, Steve, the budget deficit has grown in the last two years. Spending has gone up, but not that much, it's because revenues haven't been growing in the most recent fiscal year revenue grew at one percent and in an expansion, it should be growing at three to five percent, but this recovery, this growth period in American history has been so weak because of regulations and because of flawed tax code quite frankly.

FORBES: The last decade was at the worst economic growth since the 1930s. And so that's why I think even deregulation sounds boring, but regulations are attacks and the fact they are moving regulations, Washington isn't getting up each morning figuring out how to make life more miserable for business, has already had an impact.

And you're going to see now that this thing is going to be actually in reality. You're going to see much more investment. And what democrats refuse to recognize is, if you want a higher standard of living, you have to have people making investments, creating those new products and services, there's better paying jobs.

And one of the things they should emphasize is not just going to keep more what you now earn, but your earnings, your pay is going to up.

MCDOWELL: Thank you. Thank you. To all of these democrats, not one democrat voter for this plan. And I tweeted this out earlier. "More than 80 percent of people, of taxpayers in this country, at least in the first year are going to get a tax cut. They're going to see more money in their paycheck.

They're going to get to keep more of the money that they earned. So try running on that, because the democrats think that the messaging is that again, the country that we -- this is a scam, whatever language that you want to pit.

But again, try running on giving people more of their money.

KELLY: Well, the problem is that democrats don't have any right to critic this plan because none of them voted for it. We're limited to $155 trillion. We've seen under the previous administration that they didn't even want to tackle deficits. So we're in this vicious circle where all of a sudden now the democrats have found religion when it comes to deficits.

But at the detriment of the American people that actually need strong growth, they've been under the thumb of rules and regulations including the Obamacare, as President Trump has alluded to.

But I think the important thing to take away from this is that it's cheaper is for companies to invest here in the United States than it is abroad, right?

But there was a detriment for them to invest here, when you can have four corporations coming in and compete at a lower tax rate. Look over at the U.K., right? Twenty percent corporate tax rate that are going to take to 17.5 percent.

We are nowhere near competitive. We have one of the highest corporate tax rates in the world. So, how do you get companies to invest here? You unleash prosperity through property plan, equipment when they can reinvest in a 21 percent rate.

FORBES: One of the things that republicans should learn from this is get rid of this constraint, from this congressional budget office, these fakes, projections out 10 years that assume the tax cuts don't do much for the economy, get rid of that. Assume 3.5 percent growth and by golly have greater muscular tax cuts. One must be a tax cut in the future.

MCDOWELL: I need to get this. This is what I want to you -- I want to get your answer on this and it goes to the way that the democrats have been messaging this. While markets are optimistic about this tax plan, business owners and operators are optimistic. It remains unpopular with the American people. Actually, it's become more unpopular.

This is a new "Wall Street Journal-NBC News" poll that found 41 percent of Americans say that the tax plan is a bad idea. Just 24 percent of it say it's a good idea. Top republicans insist the numbers will shift in the coming months. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MCCONNELL: My view of this, if we can't sell this to the American people, we ought to go into another line of work. I think this is an important accomplishment for the country, that people will value and appreciate, but obviously it requires us to continue this discussion.

REP. PAUL RYAN (R), WISCONSIN, SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: People are out there on TV telling mistruth, disguising the facts of this thing. That's going to make it unpopular. When we get this done, when people see the withholding improving, when they see the jobs occurring, when they see bigger paychecks, a fairer tax system, a simpler tax code, that's what's going to produce the results.

MCDOWELL: Richard Rubin is the reporter at "The Wall Street Journal" and he points out and I did as well on Twitter, 80 percent in the first year, 80 percent of households get a tax cut. At least, if not more than that. But 17 percent of people think they're getting tax cuts. That is unbelievable.

Bit to the democrats who are saying it's a scam. Tom Perez, the head of the DNC said in his statement taxes are going up. Yet, taxes are going up for people when these tax cuts expire, eight or ten years from now. That's a lie.

The American people are being told lies by the democrats. But I say to them, I say to these liberals who are messaging this, you know what? People are going to get more money back. They're going to see money in their paychecks. So good luck with that.

FORBES: You see, one of the problems with the mainstream media is located they're located in New York and California. Many of them won't see a tax cut because the loss of state and local deductions.

So in their little world this thing doesn't look so good. They forget the rest of the country. And one of the things republicans have got to do is more messaging. Not just say the results and speak for themselves, but explain to people why this is better and also start talking about payroll reform.

Six years ago, they allowed for a couple of years people to keep their first two points on the social security tax, even if you didn't pay income tax, which many Americans don't. You got a higher paycheck, so they should put that on the table, say, if we get reelected, everyone in the work is going to get another tax cut. Start throwing out things for the future.

MCDOWELL: We're not going to argue about that because the payroll tax -- well, the payroll tax goes to fund the benefit. It goes to fund social security and Medicare.

FORBES: But the fact of the matter is they use the general budget when they need it. And they've used this for political purposes to make sure everyone feels it for a couple of years and you do more muscular tax cuts. So it's part of a plan -- set of this kiddy credit, which is a giveaway for people

MCDOWELL: We have to go. But I want to point something out. When in this country did we start believing that Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer and democrats make better decisions with our money? This is my money. I think I make better decisions about my life, my health and my money than those elected officials who have their heels dug in down in D.C.

FORBES: Even a buffets of democrats, I'll trust him more than Nancy Pelosi.

MCDOWELL: Thank you.

Coming up, a big blow for Uber in Europe. A new ruling says that the company should be regulated like taxis. What it means for drivers and users of the popular ridesharing app?

Plus, Sean "Diddy" Combs, reportedly taking another step in its effort to buy the Carolina Panthers. New details on how Colin Kaepernick might be involved.

(MUSIC)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: This breaking news overnight. The E.U. dealing a major setback to Uber. Lauren Simonetti has the details. Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hey, Dagen, the European court of justice ruling that Uber should be regulated as a taxi company and not as a digital service. Uber has been trying to use courts to reduce their regulatory oversight. Uber claims that I's an app, so it could connect drivers with passengers that they pick up.

Uber adds that the ruling should not have an immediate impact on how it operates in Europe. Shares -- well, it's not a publicly traded company. Or at least not yet.

UPS ordering 125 of Tesla's all-electric semi-trucks. This is the largest public order for the big, thus far. The Tesla trucks will cost about $200,000 each. Tesla expects them to be in production by 2019.

This is where I'm going to show you shares of Tesla. They're up 1.1 percent at 334.92 in premarket trading.

Well, Sean "Diddy" Combs or Diddy, that's what his name is these days, serious about buying the Carolina Panthers. Yahoo Sports is reporting that Diddy is huddling with potential investors hoping to put together an ownership group.

Those efforts are expected to include Colin Kaepernick. He and Diddy, according to the report had a conversation and they discussed the former NFL quarterback's role in any potential deal. Panthers' owner Jerry Richardson announced that he would be putting the franchise up for sale amid sexual and racial misconduct allegations. Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Lauren.

SIMONETTI: Sure.

MCDOWELL: What do you think?

KELLY: I mean, I think it's pretty interesting. Well, getting back to the Uber situation that most of the rules and regulations that come on this technology companies, whether it's Google or Uber or any other is coming from Europe. And I think that's going to be a big thing going into next year.

I think there's going to be a lot of rules and regulations coming, especially to Facebook. So, I think that's pretty telling. We're starting to see the ripples now. We'll feel the effects next year.

FORBES: And also shows why Britain pulled out of the E.U. is that they're very anti-growth, anti-innovation. Always has this guild medieval mentality of something new comes along, we have much pressure and control it

And you're right though. In this country, the big tech companies don't realize they're going into a political buzz saw because of their alleged power and they haven't done -- in the old days, back before any of you were born, the old AT&T monopoly survived as long as it did, because it made sure everyone was serviced, everyone -- every politician got free phone, not free phone service during the campaign. But they got the phone service, every newspaper and the net. They covered all their bases.

These tech companies, especially Google discriminating against conservatives on what they're allowed to post. That stuff is going to get a political backlash. I wish they'd wake up to this.

MCDOWELL: I think that they are waking up. I think that they are waking up, that they realized the power of Washington and what they -- what might be brought to bear on them.

FORBES: They're still playing with the conservatives.

KELLY: They're the biggest donors to Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer, and so they're actually enabling this. And so they're kind of blinded by kind of their friends in Washington that aren't really going to be there to help them out.

FORBES: They have to realize there are two parties in this country.

KELLY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: We'll see the reaction of this tax reform because it's going to feel good to a lot of them.

Coming up, ISIS, threatening attacks here and in Europe over the holiday season. The latest target, New Year's Eve. How officials here in New York City are stepping up security a week after that subway bomb blast.

And the divide in the fight against opioid abuse. The overdose antidote helping victims, but it may also put law enforcement at risk. The controversy, ahead.

(MUSIC)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: A new terror warning. ISIS releasing several disturbing propaganda posters threatening attacks over the holiday season. The latest target? New Year's Eve. This comes a week and a half after an attempted suicide bombing in New York City.

New York's governor, Andrew Cuomo has announced tightened security measures over the holidays including increased personnel, bomb sniffing dogs and even radiation detectors.

Joining us this morning is national security analyst at the Clarion Project, professor of counterterrorism at Liberty University down at Lynchburg, Virginia, Ryan Mauro.

Ryan, what do you make of this?

RYAN MAURO, NATIONAL SECURITY ANALYST, CLARION PROJECT: Well, of course ISIS is going to be saying something like this. For me, what the message should be is even if they were to succeed in carrying out an attack, the so-called lonewolf for those doesn't actually exist. One guy goes off and he kill some people.

Overall, they're still a bunch of losers. Ninety-six percent of their caliphate has been destroyed. We need to start weaponizing Trump's trolling. Make fun of them for how many dumb things that they do and for a group that claims that Allah is blessing them and on their side, well, actually it kind of looks like if they all exist, he's on our side because we're really killing them.

GABRIELLE: You know, Ryan, I think you make such a good point because ISIS has lost ground in the Middle East, essentially what it's trying to establish is a cyber-caliphate and so it's trying to influence people. People who are crazy.

A lot of these people who are lonewolf attackers don't really have a real attachment to terrorist groups overseas, as you know. And instead what they're trying to do is reach people who are angry, people who want to take that anger and hate out on people and then essentially get to them through the internet.

But when you look at terror attacks in places like New York City, these lonewolf attacks, what's so difficult is trying to identify them ahead of time. So you have some 3,000 police officers patrolling down the subway systems for example in New York each day.

What they're really having to be able to do is assess people. So how can people better be able to asses people or officers and just people on the streets to see if maybe they're -- to have those assessments in mind in case they see some something and then they should say something.

MAURO: Sure. Great question. The average civilian is just looking at something like a backpack that's place somewhere. That's kind of obvious thing that made you uncomfortable reporting that type of thing. For law enforcement, I do a lot of training of law enforcement and what I'll teach them is look for these dramatic overhauls in someone's personality because that's what the radicalization process looks like. Obsession. He becomes obsessed with the ideology.

They usually start alienating their friends and family because they become real judgmental. But I would say that when you look into the backgrounds of these folks, yes, they may not initially have connections to a terrorist group, per say, but they will have connections to a supposedly nonviolent extremist movement.

You look far back into where these initial ideas kind of incubate and you'll see connections to groups around the world that are considered moderate by comparison, but still radical in repulsive and that's where I think our attention should and that's why I think that congress really need to investigate how the Obama administration impeded counterterrorism investigations and prosecutions because that's the foundation where this begins.

It's not about political points. It's about figuring out where these mistakes were made and going back and fixing them.

FORBED: One of the things that happen a few years ago is the New York police department had a good intelligence operation and then politically they forward it. Is that back up to full speed again?

MAURO: Not really. Because what happens is when something like that occurs, you influence the culture. And so you can still have investigations on the street level, but those specific programs that were shut down, even if you were to revive them --

MCDOWELL: Exactly. And you know what, people will be celebrating in the weeks or months to come when they realizes the Democrats have been lying to them and they're getting to keep more of the money that they earned. Thank you, Herman. Still ahead.

CAIN: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Still ahead. Breaking down what tax reform means for you. We will talk to the small business administrator Linda McMahon about the bill's potential impact on smaller businesses. And Stitch Fix unravels after its first post IPO earnings report. What is causing investor concerns this morning?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It is Wednesday, December 20th. Your top stories at 8:30 a.m. Eastern. History on Capitol Hill. The Senate bring the midnight oil to pass the largest tax code overhaul in three decades. The vote split right down party lines with not one single Democrat defecting in support of this bill.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JOSEPH CROWLEY (D), NEW YORK: You know how this bill is going to help? Corporate special interests. The wealthiest Americans and yes, the Trump family. My colleagues, if it looks like a scam, quirks like a scam, it is a scam. Can you vote for this bill with a clear conscience? Hell no, you can't.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Well, the Democrats didn't but the Republicans got in line and the House will vote on the updated bill today, likely sending it to the President's desk. We'll talk to small business administrator Linda McMahon about how this tax reform will impact the business that we truly care about, mom-and-pop shops, those small businesses. Optimism still fueling these markets. Look at, the Dow is really starting to take off as the morning moves on. 104-point gain on the Dow futures. Again, investors see this reform, this tax overhaul as fueling growth making this a better place to do business for everybody. In Europe, we have losses in France and Germany and in Asia overnight, stocks mostly lower there. What can Brown do for Tesla? UPS preorders, dozens of the company's upcoming semi-trucks and another show of confidence for electric automobiles, electric vehicles. And not the right fit for some investors. Why Stitch Fix shares are tumbling after the company's first post IPO earnings port.

Plus, spend the holidays with a new best friend, that's my best friend right there, that's Charlie dog. I'm taking to him about treats in that video. But we will have -- Charlie from animal care center here in New York City and we're going to see some dogs from ACC coming up in just a little while. Our top story this morning, Republicans close to sealing the deal on tax reform. One vote away from sending sweeping overhaul to the President's desk. Blake Burman at the White House with the very latest. Hey, Blake.

BLAKE BURMAN, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hey there, Dagen. Good morning to you. The ping-ponging of this $1.5 trillion tax bill is set to reach match point at some point later today. In the early morning hours at about 12:45 in the morning earlier today, the Senate strictly partisan lines. 51 Republicans to 48 Democrats passed the tax bill.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MCCONNELL: After eight straight years of slow growth and underperformance America is ready to take off. The very, very wealthy. The highest spectrum gets almost all the benefits.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Now on Tuesday, the House had actually passed the tax bill first when it got over to the Senate. Some provisions of it were stripped -- were stripped out due to Senate rules. So that is why it has to go back to the House again. Earlier this morning, the Speaker of the House Paul Ryan described it as bizarre Senate rules in his words and he says, essentially, what will happen later this morning is a mere formality.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RYAN: We didn't think they should have dropped off but they did, it doesn't really, materially affect the bill very much. And so we will revote and pass it out again today.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: And Dagen when that happens later this morning after that it will all be done. And then it will be ready, the tax bill for the President to sign however he will not do this immediately. The basis for how all of this work is because this bill is so large, it will likely take several days for it to be enrolled, get to President over his Christmas break. So the options that he would have would be to sign it over Christmas break or potentially sign it in January when he gets back here to the White House as one senior White House official put it to me, Dagen, that would allow them to start the year off with a bang. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: And over Christmas like Christmas Eve, Christmas day, the President wouldn't get that much media coverage I wouldn't think of the signing and he is a media master, so I don't know if he would sign it on Christmas.

BURMAN: We love it when the -- when the televisions are on but we also know on Christmas Eve or Christmas day a lot of them are off.

MCDOWELL: Yes. But, you know -

BURMAN: And they know that here -- they know that here too. So we'll see how these all shakes out.

MCDOWELL: But Blake, Twitter never sleeps. We know that.

BURMAN: If I learned anything, Dagen, these last 11 months, it is that.

MCDOWELL: Amen. Thank you. Blake.

BURMAN: You got it.

MCDOWELL: Blake Burman at the White House. There is a lot in this bill for small businesses. One of the biggest changes is the way that pass- through -- pass-through entities are taxed. Pass-through entities now get a 20 percent deduction that will -- and off of a 30 percent top tax rate, that will take the top rate on pass-through entities down to 29.6 percent. And then there are rules that now if you -- these deduction phases out for married couples at $315,000 for a married couple. Joining me now to explain this and the benefits of it is administrator of the small business administration, Linda McMahon. Linda, that's what Steve Forbes said this and I've have been talking about this. One of the issues, if we have to find fault with this is that there is some complexity in this soon-to-be law that applies to these pass-through entities. How do you get around that?

LINDA MCMAHON, ADMINISTRATOR, SMALL BUSINESS ADMINISTRATION: Well, good morning, Dagen. Thank so much and, you know, there is no complexity to it but honestly when our small businesses get through this work through this and I don't think it's going to be that burdensome for them because they've been -- they're been accustomed to a little complexity in the past and when they look at the fact that they're going to get a 20 percent deduction from their income and they're already now in different tax brackets, they're going to have about double for their standard deduction.

These are real benefits for small businesses and I've traveled the country over the last several months. I've been to about 26 states. I've met with over 500 small business and talked to them and toured their facilities and they really were looking so forward to this reduction because they have told me without fail, they will reinvest any of these savings back into their businesses. So they're excited about it and I think if we look at the enthusiasm that's already in the marketplace, even before the tax bill was passed and in anticipation of it, we're going to see small businesses continue to grow.

MCDOWELL: But to add to what I was talking about. So for people married couples who make $315,000 or more, this deduction is limited and it's phased out entirely for people in some types of businesses, service as businesses including medical, legal, consulting and then there were some criticism of -- in addition regarding real estate investors. Senator Bob Corker criticized on that, wait if a test that allows businesses to qualify for this pass -- for the pass-through based on theirs. But I want to know, is this something that you could ultimately fix and broaden this tax break down the road. Is that something that is even up for discussion at this point?

MCMAHON: I have not heard discussion at this point, we've been focused so much working, you know, with Congress and being out in the marketplace and really hearing from our small businesses about what they would like to see, and I think that's really where the focus has been but of course, you know, we'll continue to be advocates for our almost 30 million small businesses around the country because they really are -- they are the backbone of our economy, and the engine of our economy. So we want to keep them strong and they are very excited about getting tax deductions. So, I'm in their corner all the way.

MCDOWELL: Being the daughter of two individuals who own and ran a small business my entire life, they feel like they always felt like that politicians always promised one thing and then delivered another. But in fact it seems to be the reverse now at least on some polls, Administrator, where you guys have stepped up and actually delivered something on cutting pass-through rates but many Americans don't favor this tax plan. That you -- in the Wall Street Journal poll, only 17 percent of people who were polled think that they're going to get a tax cut when in fact it's 80 percent or more broadly speaking. Because you've been out there messaging and talking to these business owners. Why isn't it connecting more broadly with American taxpayers and Americans in general?

MCMAHON: Well, I think the proof is going to be in the pudding, Dagen. We're going to see these benefits, our taxpayers and our small businesses are going to see more money in their pockets, less money coming out of their paychecks. And once this is happening, once the benefits are there, once our economy is continuing to grow, I think the proof is going to be in the pudding and I didn't hear any of the small businesses that I talked to pushing back, saying, boy we're not in favor of tax cuts, we are not in favor of, you know, paying less to the government. We like to keep that money and invest in our business. I didn't hear that at all.

MCDOWELL: Administrator, however, the individual cuts expire in 2025, so do changes for pass-through entities. That has to be something that members of your party, the Republicans are talking about trying to extend at this point because that's going to be -- a lot of the criticism has been unfair or outright lies from Democrats but that will be something that they try to hit home and they have been, they keep saying that, oh, half of Americans are going to have their taxes going up. Well, that's because these cuts expire. So can you fix that in the next few years?

MCMAHON: Well, I think we have seen individual tax cuts extended before, you know, when they expired and all of this is working and working well, I don't think anyone is going to vote to let them expire. And let's look at it, yes, they do have an expiration date but we're talking almost 10 years. Let's take the benefit of that today and let's work through -- let's continue to grow our economy, let's get more towards that four percent that the President is talking about because I think that really what on the minds of our small businesses today.

They're ready to go, they're ready to start more businesses, they're ready to invest that income, and they are not really talking about, well, Jeez, I don't know -- 10 years from now I don't know how that's going to effect. They want today, they're ready for it. And they've been promised, the anticipation level is high and so now it's here and now we're going to see them -- I think we're going to see them really employ more people and raise wages and start more business.

MCDOWELL: How fast do you think the economy can grow with this? You want to throw out a number?

MCMAHON: I'll leave that up to the President to project that in Congress. But I think it's going -- I think we're going to see it and the -- I think we've got the wind in our back and momentum is clearly there.

MCDOWELL: Confidence among independent businesses, national federation of independent business at an all-time high, a record high in November. Administrator, thank you. Linda Mcmahon.

MCMAHON: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Administrator of a small business administration. Still ahead, Varney down the big winners of the tax deal and then for the long haul, UPS betting big on Tesla and the electric automaker's upcoming semi-truck. Details on the deal, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Tesla getting its largest public preorder for its electric big rig. Nicole Petallides at the New York Stock Exchange with more. Nicole?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning, Dagen. Well, Tesla unveiled their big rig the Semis last month, they're going to go into production 2019 and they continue to get orders, the latest one, and its biggest one ever, now comes from UPS, reserving 125 Tesla Semis. Both the stocks are higher today. And it would be about 200,000 each to a total of about 25 million. And this comes on the heels of orders from Wal-Mart, also Sysco Foods, and J.B. Hunt Transportation.

How about FedEx? FedEx is likely to hit a new high at the opening bell today. They came out with profits that beat strong global demand. They did face a cost from that cyber-attack on their acquisition of TNT Express, and -- but we know that FedEx and UPS have been all ramping it up for e- commerce.

Last but not the least, a quick look at Stitch Fix, this is a fashion start-up, went public, they were pinched by some costs, and that stock, Dagen, is down 11-1/2 percent this morning.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Nicole. Nicole Petallides at the New York Stock Exchange. Republicans on the verge of a sweeping tax reform victory, the House set to vote on the final version of the plan this morning, the center of -- Senate approving the bill late last night. Joining me now is the host of "Varney & Company," Stuart Varney.

STUART VARNEY, FBN HOST: May I list the winners for you, if I may, according to moi?

MCDOWELL: Yes, Stu.

VARNEY: Here we go. First of all, business, huge winner. When you drop the top rate of tax from 35 to 21 percent, you're increasing the profitability of major American corporations in a very big way. Second, the economy, because I think those corporations will use a lot of that extra money that's coming at them to reinvest, plant an equipment that can -- not depreciate -- that can expense 100 percent immediately. I think this is very good for the economy, it boosts growth with all that extra money flowing in. Third, I think it's really good news for low tax states because A, they're going to get an influx of high-income earners from high- tax states, and B, the removal of the deduction for state and local taxes means nothing in Texas and Florida because they don't have local taxes to deduct.

I think that's a winner. I, myself, am a loser in all of this as are many of my colleagues in New York and New Jersey because we will end up paying more overall in tax than we do now. Nonetheless, I support it 100 percent because I think it brings America back to prosperity. And we need that more than anything else. Prosperity is the glue that binds us together. We all win from growth. And that's Elizabeth McDonald making a very early appearance on the show.

MCDOWELL: No, I love it, Stuart, and I agree with you, New York, these blue states are going to be -- if we're going to have a hard time with it, but I want -- I want businesses and I want the people like my mom and dad who worked so hard so many years and never got help from the government, I want them -- I want them to feel the benefits of this, so I'm wholeheartedly in agreement with you.

VARNEY: Everybody -- you may say that some individuals don't get an immediate benefit, and that would be true, but, overall, our society gets a huge benefit from growth and prosperity. We all win from that.

MCDOWELL: I agree.

VARNEY: Just my opinion.

MCDOWELL: Stuart Varney, "VARNEY & COMPANY" starts almost exactly 10 minutes from now. Stuart, I was looking away because we have some special guests in the studio. Not Elizabeth McDonald, but -- Stuart Varney at 9:00 a.m., Monday through Friday. Stuart is unbelievable, incredible man.

Still ahead, why was I looking away? Because Santa Claus is coming to town. Santa Claus is in the studio right now. That's my Charlie dog who came from New York's ACC. And we have two dogs who need adopting. They're in the studio. Merry Christmas, guys. Yes. Hi, Buddy. Hi, Maris. Hi, Maris.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: One of the best things you can do is give a pet a home, go out and rescue a dog particularly this close to the holiday season. Our next guests are looking to do that. The organization is central to New York in rescuing animals. Joining me now is Katie Hanson, she's Marketing and Communications Director with Animal Care Centers of New York City. She brought some friends here. Katie, this is Kelly, and this is Maris. Maris is how old? Seven?

KATIE HANSON, MARKETING AND COMMUNICATIONS DIRECTOR, ANIMAL CARE CENTER: Seven.

MCDOWELL: And Kelly is two.

HANSON: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And you guys are super special. And Maris was barking at my Charlie dog on the T.V. But people need to understand and we were talking about this, essentially, ACC is where all of the animals go that are abandoned. If a police officer in New York City finds a dog or finds an animal in need, this is where these animals go.

HANSON: Exactly, we're the only -- it's called an open admissions shelter and we are the only one in New York City that takes in all of the animals, so we take in about 30 -- between 30,000 and 35,000 animals a year.

MCDOWELL: And you've rescue -- your rescue rate or your adoption rate is sky high. You've adopted out how many animals so far this year?

HANSON: So, so far this year, we've placed 94 percent of the animals that have come in of the dogs and cats that have come in. And that is through direct adoptions, and also, we work with like about 200 rescue partners.

MCDOWELL: There are a lot of other -- my Charlie dog, by the way, you were seeing a video of him, came from ACC. He was an owner surrender. That literally his owners had him for six years, never took care of him, and he was sick, and they dumped him with you guys. And you just see that so often. And Charlie was sick which is not that old, but I want to encourage people also not only do not go out and buy a dog, go rescue, it makes me crazy. I had a conversation the other day with somebody about this, that they were going to go to a pet store and buy a dog, and I said, there's so many animals in need, particularly, Maris -- hi, buddy. Maris, how you doing?

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: He's seven so he's almost -- he's a little bit older, particularly senior dog and he's barking at the --

HANSON: Oh, sees himself.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Maris. Maris can't be fixed. So, that's why he's -- because of his age. So, that's why he's loving on Kelly a little bit.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: But really quickly, you also go out and rescue seniors, too?

HANSON: Yes, exactly, because they -- and they're actually so much easier --

MCDOWELL: Come here.

HANSON: -- because they're already house-trained that just kind of want to hang out and give you love and kisses, so --

MCDOWELL: Yes, he just gave me a kiss on the leg. Yes, he did. And also you're not -- your -- you started that campaign where you're not identifying the breeds because these would be referred to as a pit bull but, again, bad rap.

HANSON: Bad rap. So, they're basically just large free dogs. And as you can see, they're totally individual. Couch potato, a little rambunctious, so it's really just based on the individuals. So, they're both large breed dogs, but they have unique personality.

MCDOWELL: And check out -- and really --

HANSON: They're boroughbred, yes.

MCDOWELL: Come and visit. Come and visit.

HANSON: Yes, come to the shelter.

MCDOWELL: Again, Charlie dog is my -- is my life, he is my best friend and our other dog Ramon, and he came right from ACC. Ramon and Charlie.

HANSON: Thank you so much for having us on. This is great exposure for them.

MCDOWELL: We'll be right back. Thank you, Katie.

HANSON: Thank you so much.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Thanks to Lea, Kevin, and Steve. And happy anniversary to Lea's parents, love you all. That does it for us, "VARNEY & COMPANY," is right now. Stuart?

END

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: I can't believe that we work in industries where we have to wear make-up every day and worry about like flight delays. I can't believe it. Thank you, ladies. Good to see you, guys.

Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Wednesday, December 20th. Your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

The Senate making history. Republicans approving the largest overhaul of our country's tax system in about 30 years, early this morning.

(BEING VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. MITCH MCCONNELL (R), KENTUCKY: I'm a little surprised the democrats all decided voting against middle class tax relief and make American business more competitive as a smart vote and that's an argument we're more than happy to have.

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D), NEW YORK: Eighty-three percent of the middle class will get -- will either pay more in taxes or get little breadcrumbs. Is that this great bill that's helping the middle class? Absolutely not.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The house will vote on the bill later today, likely sending it to the President Trump's desk to sign.

The house originally did pass it yesterday, but there was a procedural snag that is forced the second vote. It was a snag over in the senate. Following the passage in the senate, futures are showing this happening in the markets. We had a slight full back in the Dow yesterday, off about 37 points. But we're seeing possibly new all-time highs for all your major market gauges.

By the way, you have highs on the transports earlier in the week on the Russell 2000. Literally every single market gauge in the U.S. has been moving in sync on the optimism from this tax reform package.

Over in Europe, checking on England, France and Germany, we have losses across the board. All those slight, all markets there down, lessen, about two tenths of a percent.

In Asia overnight stocks mostly lower as well. The Nikkei in Japan up ever so slightly.

ISIS threatening America. The terror group warning of the New Year's Eve attack. The latest as New York Governor, Andrew Cuomo announces heightened security measures for the holidays.

Uber, dealt a blow in Europe. The EU's top core has ruled that the ridesharing company is a taxi service and should be regulated as such. We break down the major implications of that ruling.

What can brown do for Tesla? The details as UPS delivers a big bet on the company's electric semi-truck.

And Diddy making moves to be the top cat down in Carolina. The music mogul reportedly meeting with ambassadors in his bid to buy the Panthers. How the teams could soon have a new owner. All of that and so much more coming up this morning.

Fox News correspondent, Lea Gabrielle, Benchmark managing partner, Kevin Kelly and Forbes Media chairman, former republican presidential candidate, Steve Forbes.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Nicole. Nicole Petallides at the New York Stock Exchange. Republicans on the verge of a sweeping tax reform victory, the House set to vote on the final version of the plan this morning, the center of -- Senate approving the bill late last night. Joining me now is the host of "Varney & Company," Stuart Varney.

STUART VARNEY, FBN HOST: May I list the winners for you, if I may, according to moi?

MCDOWELL: Yes, Stu.

VARNEY: Here we go. First of all, business, huge winner. When you drop the top rate of tax from 35 to 21 percent, you're increasing the profitability of major American corporations in a very big way. Second, the economy, because I think those corporations will use a lot of that extra money that's coming at them to reinvest, plant an equipment that can -- not depreciate -- that can expense 100 percent immediately. I think this is very good for the economy, it boosts growth with all that extra money flowing in. Third, I think it's really good news for low tax states because A, they're going to get an influx of high-income earners from high- tax states, and B, the removal of the deduction for state and local taxes means nothing in Texas and Florida because they don't have local taxes to deduct.

I think that's a winner. I, myself, am a loser in all of this as are many of my colleagues in New York and New Jersey because we will end up paying more overall in tax than we do now. Nonetheless, I support it 100 percent because I think it brings America back to prosperity. And we need that more than anything else. Prosperity is the glue that binds us together. We all win from growth. And that's Elizabeth McDonald making a very early appearance on the show.

MCDOWELL: No, I love it, Stuart, and I agree with you, New York, these blue states are going to be -- if we're going to have a hard time with it, but I want -- I want businesses and I want the people like my mom and dad who worked so hard so many years and never got help from the government, I want them -- I want them to feel the benefits of this, so I'm wholeheartedly in agreement with you.

VARNEY: Everybody -- you may say that some individuals don't get an immediate benefit, and that would be true, but, overall, our society gets a huge benefit from growth and prosperity. We all win from that.

MCDOWELL: I agree.

VARNEY: Just my opinion.

MCDOWELL: Stuart Varney, "VARNEY & COMPANY" starts almost exactly 10 minutes from now. Stuart, I was looking away because we have some special guests in the studio. Not Elizabeth McDonald, but -- Stuart Varney at 9:00 a.m., Monday through Friday. Stuart is unbelievable, incredible man.

Still ahead, why was I looking away? Because Santa Claus is coming to town. Santa Claus is in the studio right now. That's my Charlie dog who came from New York's ACC. And we have two dogs who need adopting. They're in the studio. Merry Christmas, guys. Yes. Hi, Buddy. Hi, Maris. Hi, Maris.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: One of the best things you can do is give a pet a home, go out and rescue a dog particularly this close to the holiday season. Our next guests are looking to do that. The organization is central to New York in rescuing animals. Joining me now is Katie Hanson, she's Marketing and Communications Director with Animal Care Centers of New York City. She brought some friends here. Katie, this is Kelly, and this is Maris. Maris is how old? Seven?

KATIE HANSON, MARKETING AND COMMUNICATIONS DIRECTOR, ANIMAL CARE CENTER: Seven.

MCDOWELL: And Kelly is two.

HANSON: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And you guys are super special. And Maris was barking at my Charlie dog on the T.V. But people need to understand and we were talking about this, essentially, ACC is where all of the animals go that are abandoned. If a police officer in New York City finds a dog or finds an animal in need, this is where these animals go.

HANSON: Exactly, we're the only -- it's called an open admissions shelter and we are the only one in New York City that takes in all of the animals, so we take in about 30 -- between 30,000 and 35,000 animals a year.

MCDOWELL: And you've rescue -- your rescue rate or your adoption rate is sky high. You've adopted out how many animals so far this year?

HANSON: So, so far this year, we've placed 94 percent of the animals that have come in of the dogs and cats that have come in. And that is through direct adoptions, and also, we work with like about 200 rescue partners.

MCDOWELL: There are a lot of other -- my Charlie dog, by the way, you were seeing a video of him, came from ACC. He was an owner surrender. That literally his owners had him for six years, never took care of him, and he was sick, and they dumped him with you guys. And you just see that so often. And Charlie was sick which is not that old, but I want to encourage people also not only do not go out and buy a dog, go rescue, it makes me crazy. I had a conversation the other day with somebody about this, that they were going to go to a pet store and buy a dog, and I said, there's so many animals in need, particularly, Maris -- hi, buddy. Maris, how you doing?

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: He's seven so he's almost -- he's a little bit older, particularly senior dog and he's barking at the --

HANSON: Oh, sees himself.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Maris. Maris can't be fixed. So, that's why he's -- because of his age. So, that's why he's loving on Kelly a little bit.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: But really quickly, you also go out and rescue seniors, too?

HANSON: Yes, exactly, because they -- and they're actually so much easier --

MCDOWELL: Come here.

HANSON: -- because they're already house-trained that just kind of want to hang out and give you love and kisses, so --

MCDOWELL: Yes, he just gave me a kiss on the leg. Yes, he did. And also you're not -- your -- you started that campaign where you're not identifying the breeds because these would be referred to as a pit bull but, again, bad rap.

HANSON: Bad rap. So, they're basically just large free dogs. And as you can see, they're totally individual. Couch potato, a little rambunctious, so it's really just based on the individuals. So, they're both large breed dogs, but they have unique personality.

MCDOWELL: And check out -- and really --

HANSON: They're boroughbred, yes.

MCDOWELL: Come and visit. Come and visit.

HANSON: Yes, come to the shelter.

MCDOWELL: Again, Charlie dog is my -- is my life, he is my best friend and our other dog Ramon, and he came right from ACC. Ramon and Charlie.

HANSON: Thank you so much for having us on. This is great exposure for them.

MCDOWELL: We'll be right back. Thank you, Katie.

HANSON: Thank you so much.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Thanks to Lea, Kevin, and Steve. And happy anniversary to Lea's parents, love you all. That does it for us, "VARNEY & COMPANY," is right now. Stuart?

END
