urn:contentItem:5VKT-36X1-DY0W-44Y2-00000-00Senate Passes Tax Bill; EU Delivers Blow to Uber; Diddy Makes Moves; UPS Orders 125 Tesla Trucks; Thwarting ISIS; Law Enforcement Divided Over2017-12-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:47ZLexisNexisSenate Passes Tax Bill; EU Delivers Blow to Uber; Diddy Makes Moves; UPS Orders 125 Tesla Trucks; Thwarting ISIS; Law Enforcement Divided OverLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: I can't believe that we work in industries where we have to wear make-up every day and worry about like flight delays. I can't believe it. Thank you, ladies. Good to see you, guys.

Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Wednesday, December 20th. Your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

The Senate making history. Republicans approving the largest overhaul of our country's tax system in about 30 years, early this morning.

(BEING VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. MITCH MCCONNELL (R), KENTUCKY: I'm a little surprised the democrats all decided voting against middle class tax relief and make American business more competitive as a smart vote and that's an argument we're more than happy to have.

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D), NEW YORK: Eighty-three percent of the middle class will get -- will either pay more in taxes or get little breadcrumbs. Is that this great bill that's helping the middle class? Absolutely not.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The house will vote on the bill later today, likely sending it to the President Trump's desk to sign.

The house originally did pass it yesterday, but there was a procedural snag that is forced the second vote. It was a snag over in the senate. Following the passage in the senate, futures are showing this happening in the markets. We had a slight full back in the Dow yesterday, off about 37 points. But we're seeing possibly new all-time highs for all your major market gauges.

By the way, you have highs on the transports earlier in the week on the Russell 2000. Literally every single market gauge in the U.S. has been moving in sync on the optimism from this tax reform package.

Over in Europe, checking on England, France and Germany, we have losses across the board. All those slight, all markets there down, lessen, about two tenths of a percent.

In Asia overnight stocks mostly lower as well. The Nikkei in Japan up ever so slightly.

ISIS threatening America. The terror group warning of the New Year's Eve attack. The latest as New York Governor, Andrew Cuomo announces heightened security measures for the holidays.

Uber, dealt a blow in Europe. The EU's top core has ruled that the ridesharing company is a taxi service and should be regulated as such. We break down the major implications of that ruling.

What can brown do for Tesla? The details as UPS delivers a big bet on the company's electric semi-truck.

And Diddy making moves to be the top cat down in Carolina. The music mogul reportedly meeting with ambassadors in his bid to buy the Panthers. How the teams could soon have a new owner. All of that and so much more coming up this morning.

Fox News correspondent, Lea Gabrielle, Benchmark managing partner, Kevin Kelly and Forbes Media chairman, former republican presidential candidate, Steve Forbes.

When you walked in this morning, I went I am so glad you're here. Any day, but particularly this day, Mr. Forbes.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good to be with you.

MCDOWELL: Because we have the same feeling about this tax cut package. But if you listen to the democrats, we're going to hell. That's pretty much the message. The country is going hell. It's savory and I just say, poppycock to that. So we're going to get into that immediately.

FORBES: Yes, it's a good word to use on a family channel.

MCDOWELL: Yes. I have an entire lexicon of things like that, like gooey and poppycock, and balderdash. So I will break all of that out.

KEVIN KELLY, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: I think I heard you called the democrats when it's coming into this plain nincompoops.

LEA GABRIELLE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: You know what? I actually called the republicans nincompoops.

KELLY: That's what it is.

MCDOWELL: As thy are putting this together, this is --

FORBES: Another old word is knuckleheads.

MCDOWELL: Knuckleheads. This is what we're going to talk about though, that why do people not yet feel good about this tax reform? Part of it is the problem of how they put it together. So we're going to talk about that in two seconds. I just want to tease our guests that are coming up, Illinois congressman, Peter Roskam. Fox News senior judicial analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. Louisiana senator, John Kennedy. Former republican presidential candidate, Herman Cain. And administrator of the small business administration, Linda McMahaon. There's a lot in this package for small businesses as well.

But first, on the verge of a big tax victory. Republicans are set to give their final approval to a sweeping tax overhaul today after the senate passed a plan and a late night vote.

House are scheduled a final vote this morning on the plan ready to send it to President Trump's desk to sign it into law.

Senate Majority Leader, Mitch McConnell says that both American businesses and individual tax payers will see the benefit.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MCCONNELL: We had three, two quarters in a row of three percent growth. Stock market is up. Optimism is high. Coupled with this tax reform, America is ready to start performing as they should have for a number of years.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The president congratulating lawmakers on Twitter, writing "The United States senate just passed the biggest in history tax cut in reform barrel. Terrible individual mandate, Obamacare repealed. Goes to the house tomorrow morning for a final vote. If approved, there will be a news conference at the White House at approximately 1:00 p.m.

Steve Forbes, we're on the precipice of passing this first major tax overhaul. "The Wall Street Journal" is saying certainly on the business side, it actually does more in some ways than the '86 tax reform did in terms of reforming corporate taxes.

FORBES: The big news on the business side reducing the rate, corporate rate down to 21 and pastors and its partnerships, Ascopr in the like which how most American businesses organize for tax purposes. They got that rate down. Looks like 29.6. We'll have to see the final details on that.

Overseas earnings, no longer being penalized and bringing some of that cash back home. Instant expensing. So if there are no sleepers in this bill, and the market, I think would have fare the amount by now. They did good on that side. The individual side is where they've got to do work the next time.

And I hope today --

GABRIELLE: When is the next time? When is that?

FORBES: Well, this is what they should announce today. That oh, yes, it's great history, since 1986 and all that good stuff. What they should also announce is this is a down payment. This is the first of many big tax cuts to come. Give people anticipation, especially on the individual side. We're going to keep slashing taxes because you the Americans create the resources and can employ them better than Washington bureaucrats.

GABRIELLE: I think the question though for many of us, is that really possible if you look at the debt worth, 20 trillion in debt and people can show that a national security issue. So, can you -- is it really feasible --

FORBES: What history shows -- experience shows is the only way you get a balanced budget, if you want that is what the booming economy. Late 1960s. Kennedy tax cuts, finally in the 90s, after the Cold War and Reagan's Cold War victory massive tax cuts. So if you want to get the Russian's fiscal situation under control, that economy where people feel good.

MCDOWELL: On that note, Steve, the budget deficit has grown in the last two years. Spending has gone up, but not that much, it's because revenues haven't been growing in the most recent fiscal year revenue grew at one percent and in an expansion, it should be growing at three to five percent, but this recovery, this growth period in American history has been so weak because of regulations and because of flawed tax code quite frankly.

FORBES: The last decade was at the worst economic growth since the 1930s. And so that's why I think even deregulation sounds boring, but regulations are attacks and the fact they are moving regulations, Washington isn't getting up each morning figuring out how to make life more miserable for business, has already had an impact.

And you're going to see now that this thing is going to be actually in reality. You're going to see much more investment. And what democrats refuse to recognize is, if you want a higher standard of living, you have to have people making investments, creating those new products and services, there's better paying jobs.

And one of the things they should emphasize is not just going to keep more what you now earn, but your earnings, your pay is going to up.

MCDOWELL: Thank you. Thank you. To all of these democrats, not one democrat voter for this plan. And I tweeted this out earlier. "More than 80 percent of people, of taxpayers in this country, at least in the first year are going to get a tax cut. They're going to see more money in their paycheck.

They're going to get to keep more of the money that they earned. So try running on that, because the democrats think that the messaging is that again, the country that we -- this is a scam, whatever language that you want to pit.

But again, try running on giving people more of their money.

KELLY: Well, the problem is that democrats don't have any right to critic this plan because none of them voted for it. We're limited to $155 trillion. We've seen under the previous administration that they didn't even want to tackle deficits. So we're in this vicious circle where all of a sudden now the democrats have found religion when it comes to deficits.

But at the detriment of the American people that actually need strong growth, they've been under the thumb of rules and regulations including the Obamacare, as President Trump has alluded to.

But I think the important thing to take away from this is that it's cheaper is for companies to invest here in the United States than it is abroad, right?

But there was a detriment for them to invest here, when you can have four corporations coming in and compete at a lower tax rate. Look over at the U.K., right? Twenty percent corporate tax rate that are going to take to 17.5 percent.

We are nowhere near competitive. We have one of the highest corporate tax rates in the world. So, how do you get companies to invest here? You unleash prosperity through property plan, equipment when they can reinvest in a 21 percent rate.

FORBES: One of the things that republicans should learn from this is get rid of this constraint, from this congressional budget office, these fakes, projections out 10 years that assume the tax cuts don't do much for the economy, get rid of that. Assume 3.5 percent growth and by golly have greater muscular tax cuts. One must be a tax cut in the future.

MCDOWELL: I need to get this. This is what I want to you -- I want to get your answer on this and it goes to the way that the democrats have been messaging this. While markets are optimistic about this tax plan, business owners and operators are optimistic. It remains unpopular with the American people. Actually, it's become more unpopular.

This is a new "Wall Street Journal-NBC News" poll that found 41 percent of Americans say that the tax plan is a bad idea. Just 24 percent of it say it's a good idea. Top republicans insist the numbers will shift in the coming months. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MCCONNELL: My view of this, if we can't sell this to the American people, we ought to go into another line of work. I think this is an important accomplishment for the country, that people will value and appreciate, but obviously it requires us to continue this discussion.

REP. PAUL RYAN (R), WISCONSIN, SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: People are out there on TV telling mistruth, disguising the facts of this thing. That's going to make it unpopular. When we get this done, when people see the withholding improving, when they see the jobs occurring, when they see bigger paychecks, a fairer tax system, a simpler tax code, that's what's going to produce the results.

MCDOWELL: Richard Rubin is the reporter at "The Wall Street Journal" and he points out and I did as well on Twitter, 80 percent in the first year, 80 percent of households get a tax cut. At least, if not more than that. But 17 percent of people think they're getting tax cuts. That is unbelievable.

Bit to the democrats who are saying it's a scam. Tom Perez, the head of the DNC said in his statement taxes are going up. Yet, taxes are going up for people when these tax cuts expire, eight or ten years from now. That's a lie.

The American people are being told lies by the democrats. But I say to them, I say to these liberals who are messaging this, you know what? People are going to get more money back. They're going to see money in their paychecks. So good luck with that.

FORBES: You see, one of the problems with the mainstream media is located they're located in New York and California. Many of them won't see a tax cut because the loss of state and local deductions.

So in their little world this thing doesn't look so good. They forget the rest of the country. And one of the things republicans have got to do is more messaging. Not just say the results and speak for themselves, but explain to people why this is better and also start talking about payroll reform.

Six years ago, they allowed for a couple of years people to keep their first two points on the social security tax, even if you didn't pay income tax, which many Americans don't. You got a higher paycheck, so they should put that on the table, say, if we get reelected, everyone in the work is going to get another tax cut. Start throwing out things for the future.

MCDOWELL: We're not going to argue about that because the payroll tax -- well, the payroll tax goes to fund the benefit. It goes to fund social security and Medicare.

FORBES: But the fact of the matter is they use the general budget when they need it. And they've used this for political purposes to make sure everyone feels it for a couple of years and you do more muscular tax cuts. So it's part of a plan -- set of this kiddy credit, which is a giveaway for people

MCDOWELL: We have to go. But I want to point something out. When in this country did we start believing that Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer and democrats make better decisions with our money? This is my money. I think I make better decisions about my life, my health and my money than those elected officials who have their heels dug in down in D.C.

FORBES: Even a buffets of democrats, I'll trust him more than Nancy Pelosi.

MCDOWELL: Thank you.

Coming up, a big blow for Uber in Europe. A new ruling says that the company should be regulated like taxis. What it means for drivers and users of the popular ridesharing app?

Plus, Sean "Diddy" Combs, reportedly taking another step in its effort to buy the Carolina Panthers. New details on how Colin Kaepernick might be involved.

(MUSIC)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: This breaking news overnight. The E.U. dealing a major setback to Uber. Lauren Simonetti has the details. Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hey, Dagen, the European court of justice ruling that Uber should be regulated as a taxi company and not as a digital service. Uber has been trying to use courts to reduce their regulatory oversight. Uber claims that I's an app, so it could connect drivers with passengers that they pick up.

Uber adds that the ruling should not have an immediate impact on how it operates in Europe. Shares -- well, it's not a publicly traded company. Or at least not yet.

urn:contentItem:5R7G-FH81-DY0W-40R7-00000-00Senate Passes Tax Bill; EU Delivers Blow to Uber; Diddy Makes Moves; UPS Orders 125 Tesla Trucks; Thwarting ISIS; Law Enforcement Divided Over2017-12-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:47ZLexisNexisSenate Passes Tax Bill; EU Delivers Blow to Uber; Diddy Makes Moves; UPS Orders 125 Tesla Trucks; Thwarting ISIS; Law Enforcement Divided OverLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: I can't believe that we work in industries where we have to wear make-up every day and worry about like flight delays. I can't believe it. Thank you, ladies. Good to see you, guys.

Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Wednesday, December 20th. Your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

The Senate making history. Republicans approving the largest overhaul of our country's tax system in about 30 years, early this morning.

(BEING VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. MITCH MCCONNELL (R), KENTUCKY: I'm a little surprised the democrats all decided voting against middle class tax relief and make American business more competitive as a smart vote and that's an argument we're more than happy to have.

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D), NEW YORK: Eighty-three percent of the middle class will get -- will either pay more in taxes or get little breadcrumbs. Is that this great bill that's helping the middle class? Absolutely not.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The house will vote on the bill later today, likely sending it to the President Trump's desk to sign.

The house originally did pass it yesterday, but there was a procedural snag that is forced the second vote. It was a snag over in the senate. Following the passage in the senate, futures are showing this happening in the markets. We had a slight full back in the Dow yesterday, off about 37 points. But we're seeing possibly new all-time highs for all your major market gauges.

By the way, you have highs on the transports earlier in the week on the Russell 2000. Literally every single market gauge in the U.S. has been moving in sync on the optimism from this tax reform package.

Over in Europe, checking on England, France and Germany, we have losses across the board. All those slight, all markets there down, lessen, about two tenths of a percent.

In Asia overnight stocks mostly lower as well. The Nikkei in Japan up ever so slightly.

ISIS threatening America. The terror group warning of the New Year's Eve attack. The latest as New York Governor, Andrew Cuomo announces heightened security measures for the holidays.

Uber, dealt a blow in Europe. The EU's top core has ruled that the ridesharing company is a taxi service and should be regulated as such. We break down the major implications of that ruling.

What can brown do for Tesla? The details as UPS delivers a big bet on the company's electric semi-truck.

And Diddy making moves to be the top cat down in Carolina. The music mogul reportedly meeting with ambassadors in his bid to buy the Panthers. How the teams could soon have a new owner. All of that and so much more coming up this morning.

Fox News correspondent, Lea Gabrielle, Benchmark managing partner, Kevin Kelly and Forbes Media chairman, former republican presidential candidate, Steve Forbes.

When you walked in this morning, I went I am so glad you're here. Any day, but particularly this day, Mr. Forbes.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good to be with you.

MCDOWELL: Because we have the same feeling about this tax cut package. But if you listen to the democrats, we're going to hell. That's pretty much the message. The country is going hell. It's savory and I just say, poppycock to that. So we're going to get into that immediately.

FORBES: Yes, it's a good word to use on a family channel.

MCDOWELL: Yes. I have an entire lexicon of things like that, like gooey and poppycock, and balderdash. So I will break all of that out.

KEVIN KELLY, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: I think I heard you called the democrats when it's coming into this plain nincompoops.

LEA GABRIELLE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: You know what? I actually called the republicans nincompoops.

KELLY: That's what it is.

MCDOWELL: As thy are putting this together, this is --

FORBES: Another old word is knuckleheads.

MCDOWELL: Knuckleheads. This is what we're going to talk about though, that why do people not yet feel good about this tax reform? Part of it is the problem of how they put it together. So we're going to talk about that in two seconds. I just want to tease our guests that are coming up, Illinois congressman, Peter Roskam. Fox News senior judicial analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. Louisiana senator, John Kennedy. Former republican presidential candidate, Herman Cain. And administrator of the small business administration, Linda McMahaon. There's a lot in this package for small businesses as well.

But first, on the verge of a big tax victory. Republicans are set to give their final approval to a sweeping tax overhaul today after the senate passed a plan and a late night vote.

House are scheduled a final vote this morning on the plan ready to send it to President Trump's desk to sign it into law.

Senate Majority Leader, Mitch McConnell says that both American businesses and individual tax payers will see the benefit.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MCCONNELL: We had three, two quarters in a row of three percent growth. Stock market is up. Optimism is high. Coupled with this tax reform, America is ready to start performing as they should have for a number of years.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The president congratulating lawmakers on Twitter, writing "The United States senate just passed the biggest in history tax cut in reform barrel. Terrible individual mandate, Obamacare repealed. Goes to the house tomorrow morning for a final vote. If approved, there will be a news conference at the White House at approximately 1:00 p.m.

Steve Forbes, we're on the precipice of passing this first major tax overhaul. "The Wall Street Journal" is saying certainly on the business side, it actually does more in some ways than the '86 tax reform did in terms of reforming corporate taxes.

FORBES: The big news on the business side reducing the rate, corporate rate down to 21 and pastors and its partnerships, Ascopr in the like which how most American businesses organize for tax purposes. They got that rate down. Looks like 29.6. We'll have to see the final details on that.

Overseas earnings, no longer being penalized and bringing some of that cash back home. Instant expensing. So if there are no sleepers in this bill, and the market, I think would have fare the amount by now. They did good on that side. The individual side is where they've got to do work the next time.

And I hope today --

GABRIELLE: When is the next time? When is that?

FORBES: Well, this is what they should announce today. That oh, yes, it's great history, since 1986 and all that good stuff. What they should also announce is this is a down payment. This is the first of many big tax cuts to come. Give people anticipation, especially on the individual side. We're going to keep slashing taxes because you the Americans create the resources and can employ them better than Washington bureaucrats.

GABRIELLE: I think the question though for many of us, is that really possible if you look at the debt worth, 20 trillion in debt and people can show that a national security issue. So, can you -- is it really feasible --

FORBES: What history shows -- experience shows is the only way you get a balanced budget, if you want that is what the booming economy. Late 1960s. Kennedy tax cuts, finally in the 90s, after the Cold War and Reagan's Cold War victory massive tax cuts. So if you want to get the Russian's fiscal situation under control, that economy where people feel good.

MCDOWELL: On that note, Steve, the budget deficit has grown in the last two years. Spending has gone up, but not that much, it's because revenues haven't been growing in the most recent fiscal year revenue grew at one percent and in an expansion, it should be growing at three to five percent, but this recovery, this growth period in American history has been so weak because of regulations and because of flawed tax code quite frankly.

FORBES: The last decade was at the worst economic growth since the 1930s. And so that's why I think even deregulation sounds boring, but regulations are attacks and the fact they are moving regulations, Washington isn't getting up each morning figuring out how to make life more miserable for business, has already had an impact.

And you're going to see now that this thing is going to be actually in reality. You're going to see much more investment. And what democrats refuse to recognize is, if you want a higher standard of living, you have to have people making investments, creating those new products and services, there's better paying jobs.

And one of the things they should emphasize is not just going to keep more what you now earn, but your earnings, your pay is going to up.

MCDOWELL: Thank you. Thank you. To all of these democrats, not one democrat voter for this plan. And I tweeted this out earlier. "More than 80 percent of people, of taxpayers in this country, at least in the first year are going to get a tax cut. They're going to see more money in their paycheck.

They're going to get to keep more of the money that they earned. So try running on that, because the democrats think that the messaging is that again, the country that we -- this is a scam, whatever language that you want to pit.

But again, try running on giving people more of their money.

KELLY: Well, the problem is that democrats don't have any right to critic this plan because none of them voted for it. We're limited to $155 trillion. We've seen under the previous administration that they didn't even want to tackle deficits. So we're in this vicious circle where all of a sudden now the democrats have found religion when it comes to deficits.

But at the detriment of the American people that actually need strong growth, they've been under the thumb of rules and regulations including the Obamacare, as President Trump has alluded to.

But I think the important thing to take away from this is that it's cheaper is for companies to invest here in the United States than it is abroad, right?

But there was a detriment for them to invest here, when you can have four corporations coming in and compete at a lower tax rate. Look over at the U.K., right? Twenty percent corporate tax rate that are going to take to 17.5 percent.

We are nowhere near competitive. We have one of the highest corporate tax rates in the world. So, how do you get companies to invest here? You unleash prosperity through property plan, equipment when they can reinvest in a 21 percent rate.

FORBES: One of the things that republicans should learn from this is get rid of this constraint, from this congressional budget office, these fakes, projections out 10 years that assume the tax cuts don't do much for the economy, get rid of that. Assume 3.5 percent growth and by golly have greater muscular tax cuts. One must be a tax cut in the future.

MCDOWELL: I need to get this. This is what I want to you -- I want to get your answer on this and it goes to the way that the democrats have been messaging this. While markets are optimistic about this tax plan, business owners and operators are optimistic. It remains unpopular with the American people. Actually, it's become more unpopular.

This is a new "Wall Street Journal-NBC News" poll that found 41 percent of Americans say that the tax plan is a bad idea. Just 24 percent of it say it's a good idea. Top republicans insist the numbers will shift in the coming months. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MCCONNELL: My view of this, if we can't sell this to the American people, we ought to go into another line of work. I think this is an important accomplishment for the country, that people will value and appreciate, but obviously it requires us to continue this discussion.

REP. PAUL RYAN (R), WISCONSIN, SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: People are out there on TV telling mistruth, disguising the facts of this thing. That's going to make it unpopular. When we get this done, when people see the withholding improving, when they see the jobs occurring, when they see bigger paychecks, a fairer tax system, a simpler tax code, that's what's going to produce the results.

MCDOWELL: Richard Rubin is the reporter at "The Wall Street Journal" and he points out and I did as well on Twitter, 80 percent in the first year, 80 percent of households get a tax cut. At least, if not more than that. But 17 percent of people think they're getting tax cuts. That is unbelievable.

Bit to the democrats who are saying it's a scam. Tom Perez, the head of the DNC said in his statement taxes are going up. Yet, taxes are going up for people when these tax cuts expire, eight or ten years from now. That's a lie.

The American people are being told lies by the democrats. But I say to them, I say to these liberals who are messaging this, you know what? People are going to get more money back. They're going to see money in their paychecks. So good luck with that.

FORBES: You see, one of the problems with the mainstream media is located they're located in New York and California. Many of them won't see a tax cut because the loss of state and local deductions.

So in their little world this thing doesn't look so good. They forget the rest of the country. And one of the things republicans have got to do is more messaging. Not just say the results and speak for themselves, but explain to people why this is better and also start talking about payroll reform.

Six years ago, they allowed for a couple of years people to keep their first two points on the social security tax, even if you didn't pay income tax, which many Americans don't. You got a higher paycheck, so they should put that on the table, say, if we get reelected, everyone in the work is going to get another tax cut. Start throwing out things for the future.

MCDOWELL: We're not going to argue about that because the payroll tax -- well, the payroll tax goes to fund the benefit. It goes to fund social security and Medicare.

FORBES: But the fact of the matter is they use the general budget when they need it. And they've used this for political purposes to make sure everyone feels it for a couple of years and you do more muscular tax cuts. So it's part of a plan -- set of this kiddy credit, which is a giveaway for people

MCDOWELL: We have to go. But I want to point something out. When in this country did we start believing that Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer and democrats make better decisions with our money? This is my money. I think I make better decisions about my life, my health and my money than those elected officials who have their heels dug in down in D.C.

FORBES: Even a buffets of democrats, I'll trust him more than Nancy Pelosi.

MCDOWELL: Thank you.

Coming up, a big blow for Uber in Europe. A new ruling says that the company should be regulated like taxis. What it means for drivers and users of the popular ridesharing app?

Plus, Sean "Diddy" Combs, reportedly taking another step in its effort to buy the Carolina Panthers. New details on how Colin Kaepernick might be involved.

(MUSIC)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: This breaking news overnight. The E.U. dealing a major setback to Uber. Lauren Simonetti has the details. Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hey, Dagen, the European court of justice ruling that Uber should be regulated as a taxi company and not as a digital service. Uber has been trying to use courts to reduce their regulatory oversight. Uber claims that I's an app, so it could connect drivers with passengers that they pick up.

Uber adds that the ruling should not have an immediate impact on how it operates in Europe. Shares -- well, it's not a publicly traded company. Or at least not yet.

UPS ordering 125 of Tesla's all-electric semi-trucks. This is the largest public order for the big, thus far. The Tesla trucks will cost about $200,000 each. Tesla expects them to be in production by 2019.

This is where I'm going to show you shares of Tesla. They're up 1.1 percent at 334.92 in premarket trading.

Well, Sean "Diddy" Combs or Diddy, that's what his name is these days, serious about buying the Carolina Panthers. Yahoo Sports is reporting that Diddy is huddling with potential investors hoping to put together an ownership group.

Those efforts are expected to include Colin Kaepernick. He and Diddy, according to the report had a conversation and they discussed the former NFL quarterback's role in any potential deal. Panthers' owner Jerry Richardson announced that he would be putting the franchise up for sale amid sexual and racial misconduct allegations. Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Lauren.

SIMONETTI: Sure.

MCDOWELL: What do you think?

KELLY: I mean, I think it's pretty interesting. Well, getting back to the Uber situation that most of the rules and regulations that come on this technology companies, whether it's Google or Uber or any other is coming from Europe. And I think that's going to be a big thing going into next year.

I think there's going to be a lot of rules and regulations coming, especially to Facebook. So, I think that's pretty telling. We're starting to see the ripples now. We'll feel the effects next year.

FORBES: And also shows why Britain pulled out of the E.U. is that they're very anti-growth, anti-innovation. Always has this guild medieval mentality of something new comes along, we have much pressure and control it

And you're right though. In this country, the big tech companies don't realize they're going into a political buzz saw because of their alleged power and they haven't done -- in the old days, back before any of you were born, the old AT&T monopoly survived as long as it did, because it made sure everyone was serviced, everyone -- every politician got free phone, not free phone service during the campaign. But they got the phone service, every newspaper and the net. They covered all their bases.

These tech companies, especially Google discriminating against conservatives on what they're allowed to post. That stuff is going to get a political backlash. I wish they'd wake up to this.

MCDOWELL: I think that they are waking up. I think that they are waking up, that they realized the power of Washington and what they -- what might be brought to bear on them.

FORBES: They're still playing with the conservatives.

KELLY: They're the biggest donors to Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer, and so they're actually enabling this. And so they're kind of blinded by kind of their friends in Washington that aren't really going to be there to help them out.

FORBES: They have to realize there are two parties in this country.

KELLY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: We'll see the reaction of this tax reform because it's going to feel good to a lot of them.

Coming up, ISIS, threatening attacks here and in Europe over the holiday season. The latest target, New Year's Eve. How officials here in New York City are stepping up security a week after that subway bomb blast.

And the divide in the fight against opioid abuse. The overdose antidote helping victims, but it may also put law enforcement at risk. The controversy, ahead.

(MUSIC)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: A new terror warning. ISIS releasing several disturbing propaganda posters threatening attacks over the holiday season. The latest target? New Year's Eve. This comes a week and a half after an attempted suicide bombing in New York City.

New York's governor, Andrew Cuomo has announced tightened security measures over the holidays including increased personnel, bomb sniffing dogs and even radiation detectors.

Joining us this morning is national security analyst at the Clarion Project, professor of counterterrorism at Liberty University down at Lynchburg, Virginia, Ryan Mauro.

Ryan, what do you make of this?

RYAN MAURO, NATIONAL SECURITY ANALYST, CLARION PROJECT: Well, of course ISIS is going to be saying something like this. For me, what the message should be is even if they were to succeed in carrying out an attack, the so-called lonewolf for those doesn't actually exist. One guy goes off and he kill some people.

Overall, they're still a bunch of losers. Ninety-six percent of their caliphate has been destroyed. We need to start weaponizing Trump's trolling. Make fun of them for how many dumb things that they do and for a group that claims that Allah is blessing them and on their side, well, actually it kind of looks like if they all exist, he's on our side because we're really killing them.

GABRIELLE: You know, Ryan, I think you make such a good point because ISIS has lost ground in the Middle East, essentially what it's trying to establish is a cyber-caliphate and so it's trying to influence people. People who are crazy.

A lot of these people who are lonewolf attackers don't really have a real attachment to terrorist groups overseas, as you know. And instead what they're trying to do is reach people who are angry, people who want to take that anger and hate out on people and then essentially get to them through the internet.

But when you look at terror attacks in places like New York City, these lonewolf attacks, what's so difficult is trying to identify them ahead of time. So you have some 3,000 police officers patrolling down the subway systems for example in New York each day.

What they're really having to be able to do is assess people. So how can people better be able to asses people or officers and just people on the streets to see if maybe they're -- to have those assessments in mind in case they see some something and then they should say something.

MAURO: Sure. Great question. The average civilian is just looking at something like a backpack that's place somewhere. That's kind of obvious thing that made you uncomfortable reporting that type of thing. For law enforcement, I do a lot of training of law enforcement and what I'll teach them is look for these dramatic overhauls in someone's personality because that's what the radicalization process looks like. Obsession. He becomes obsessed with the ideology.

They usually start alienating their friends and family because they become real judgmental. But I would say that when you look into the backgrounds of these folks, yes, they may not initially have connections to a terrorist group, per say, but they will have connections to a supposedly nonviolent extremist movement.

You look far back into where these initial ideas kind of incubate and you'll see connections to groups around the world that are considered moderate by comparison, but still radical in repulsive and that's where I think our attention should and that's why I think that congress really need to investigate how the Obama administration impeded counterterrorism investigations and prosecutions because that's the foundation where this begins.

It's not about political points. It's about figuring out where these mistakes were made and going back and fixing them.

FORBED: One of the things that happen a few years ago is the New York police department had a good intelligence operation and then politically they forward it. Is that back up to full speed again?

MAURO: Not really. Because what happens is when something like that occurs, you influence the culture. And so you can still have investigations on the street level, but those specific programs that were shut down, even if you were to revive them --

MCDOWELL: Muslim communities and mosques just trying to figure out if there is a would-be terrorist where the individual was working, where the individual might be living and basically in secret. But do you think -- New Yorkers are angry.

New Yorkers are angry that in 14 months, we've had three terror attacks. Eight people killed over near the Westside highway on a bike path and then after the fact, they put up concrete barricades, some of which are decorated for Christmas. People are irritated, they're angry, they're -- you know what and what is New York going to do about it?

MAURO: Well, there a few different programs that were conflated. The biggest amount of lying that went on in the media and also pushed by certain activist organizations was this idea that the NYPD was just spying on Muslims for simply Muslim.

If you look at the stuff that real resources were put into, there are always indications of extremism such as classes on how to disarm police. If you get into a fight with cops. That's a sign of extremism. Start there.

Believe it or not, those type of indicators are all over the place and that's where you start. And if you look at this as an ideological insurgency, not a criminal intelligence problem, not even terrorism problem, but an ideological insurgency and you say what is the infrastructure for this problem. Start there. You'll find the bad guys. It just requires some political incorrectness.

MCDOWELL: Ryan, good to see you. Thank you so much. Ryan Mauro. Again, be vigilant. Be vigilant.

Coming up, Facebook expanding the use of its facial recognition, but it's raising new concerns over privacy.

And do you have one of the most popular computer passwords of the year? We'll tell you why that's not a good thing.

(MUSIC)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Good morning, I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Wednesday, December 20th, your top stories at 6:30 a.m. Eastern. Clearing the final hurdles to tax reform, the Senate burning the midnight oil to pass the largest tax code overhaul in three decades, the votes split straight down party line, not one single Democrat defecting in support of this bill.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. MITCH MCCONNELL (R-KY), MAJORITY LEADER OF THE SENATE: I think every Democrat who votes against this and apparently, that's all of them in the House and Senate, are saying, in effect, we are satisfied of where we are. They're simply not interested in doing the kind of things that economists believe will get the country growing again.

REP. STENY HOYER (D), MARYLAND: There was no inclusion of Democrats in this process. When the senator says, you know, we want to give tax cut, frankly, we want to give tax cut as well.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The House will vote on the updated bill today, likely sending it to the President's desk. Optimism over tax reform still fuelling these markets, futures are showing gains across the board, 75 point gain on the Dow futures right now. It has been an incredible year for stocks. Dow was down about 37 points yesterday, but we are seeing the optimism return.

In Europe, we have losses across the board in England, France, and Germany, and seems like the sung is picking up a little bit of steam in France and Germany right now. In Asia overnight, stocks mostly lower as well, the slight gain for the Nikkei in Japan.

Tragedy in Mexico, a tour bus carrying American cruise ship passengers crashes, killing at least 12 people. We have the latest from that investigation ahead. The opioid epidemic striking the workplace, alcohol and drug-related overdoses at work, spike to new levels, how the government is working to combat that growing health crisis.

And putting the face in Facebook, the social media site sparking privacy concern with new facial recognition technology, why the company says it added the feature, ahead. And these aren't the passwords you're looking for, Star Wars make its debut on the annual list of the worst passwords, we will let you know what took the top spot this year.

But to our top story this half hour, the opioid epidemic hitting the workplace, according to a new report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, unintentional drug and alcohol overdose deaths at work spiked 32 percent in 2016. The number tripling since the bureau began compiling data back in 2011. Joining us this morning is Opiant Pharmaceuticals CEO, Doctor Roger Crystal, Doctor, your company develops the easy-to-use overdose antidote, NARCAN, which is a nasal spray, so you're at the forefront of combating this opioid epidemic. What do you think of these new statistics?

DR. ROGER CRYSTAL, CEO OF OPIANT PHARMACEUTICALS: For me, given my background, this really isn't a surprise, actually, unfortunately. The opioid crisis has just continued to grow. I'm from the U.K., originally, and trained as a surgeon and there are those types of numbers that don't yet exist, but part of that, kind of, the big driver of that has been, unfortunately, in the past. The over-prescribing of opioid painkillers, and that's something that we need to address as a country alongside treating all of these people who are unfortunately addicted to opioids and alcohol.

MCDOWELL: Aren't we already doing that in terms of really reining in the amount of opioids prescribed. I mean, I personally experienced it with all my doctors, you have -- you have dental surgery, they do not give you Vicodin any longer. In terms of it, even at the state level, it's -- you have -- it is very, very hard to get a prescription for anything as powerful as, like, Oxycodone or Oxycontin at this point.

CRYSTAL: That's true that there are some measures in place already, so I hope we do -- we will see a reduction. I will say that even recently as last year, there were still over 200 million opioid prescriptions made out to approximately 20 million people. So this is a huge issue and that doesn't also address the two and a half million opioid addicts who we have in this country already. So we are really not there yet, I'm afraid. . KELLY: Yes, so getting back to your product and what you guys do, you guys have a nasal spray that people that are currently addicted to heroin take or can you explain to us the product and you've got FDA approval and, kind of, walk us through what you guys are doing.

CRYSTAL: So, the product is called the NARCAN Nasal Spray and this saves lives if someone with overdose from an opioid. And when we say opioid, yes, correct, it is something like heroin or Fentanyl, unfortunately, we see there now, but also, just routine normal painkillers such as Oxycontin and Vicodin and was -- I agree that they are being prescribed less.

They are still overprescribed, and it's not for someone who's even necessarily an addict. I'm in good health, I don't abuse opioids, if my dentist were to prescribe me Oxycontin, I will still be at risk of an opioid overdose (INAUDIBLE) prudent for me to be prescribed the NARCAN Nasal Spray alongside any opioid as a -- as a just in case measure.

MCDOWELL: I just want to get to why you're talking about NARCAN. There was a report recently that police departments are split over the use of NARCAN, that some police officials are talking about like a resources for obtaining, maintaining and tracking supplies, and for training in and when how to use it, are you seeing any pushback from police departments when they encounter rescue squads, ambulance services, paramedics, when they encounter people who have overdosed for them using NARCAN?

CRYSTAL: The feedback from ourselves and from our partners adapt farmers as well. There's no real pushback in terms of not wanting to recede the NARCAN Nasal Spray. It's easy to use, it saves lives, it's been FDA approved. So there's a real gratitude when they finally can get hold of it because actually, it's something that people are then able to use and save lives, the challenge about resources that is more -- a broader issue about funding.

GABRIELLE: That's true for some, but I know that Sheriff Jones in Butler County Ohio, does not want his officers carrying this and it's because for one thing. They say that, you know, law enforcement officials are supposed to be able to enforce the law, not end up, basically, treating people who are going to overdose again and again, and they see these repeat offenders.

You know, they also say that sometimes, people come to and they actually assault the person who was trying to help them. There was an incident about in Middle town where an injured firefighter was injured. And so you look at this, and you go, a firefighter is supposed to be fighting fires, yet, they do, you know, give emergency medical help as well. But gosh, like, should they be carrying this around and then being put in this position where they are -- they are expanding their duties to something that they really are not supposed to be doing?

CRYSTAL: Well, that represents this issue, a vast minority of people and certainly, the (INAUDIBLE) you mentioned is very outspoken and that's particularly rare. The emergency responders in general, that is their chance (INAUDIBLE) overall is to respond to an emergency, why, to ultimately save lives and this is -- this is a very successful way of saving a life if given appropriately. And people if they get the right training, should absolutely be well-handled to do so.

MCDOWELL: Your company got some good news about feasibility of a heroin vaccine that's getting worse. Tell us about that.

CRYSTAL: So this is an early stage program that we are very fortunate to have partnered with the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research and neither the National Institute of Drug Abuse, so we have this program and we got some recent news that's going to be published around the feasibility of this heroin vaccine. It's showing that not only does the vaccine seem to work in an animal model against heroin, but also, activity with some of these opioid painkillers as well.

We are encouraged by that. We also have the data to show that this can potentially be scaled up and therefore, truly manufactured on the commercial level once it gets into the clinics, so this is very important even at this stage, when we are thinking about this as a proper product to get out there.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN AND EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, FORBES MEDIA: Can we get a balance in pain management as, you know, 15 years ago, the rap against medical profession was they weren't doing enough people in pain which led to for whatever reason we have the crisis today. What is the balance?

CRYSTAL: The balance is a tough one to strike. And I talked about my experience in the U.K. as a surgeon there. And by no means is the U.K. perfect at all. We probably didn't prescribe sufficient analgesia. The balance, really, to think about how we address that is starting off with medical schools, and I say, medical, not just the M.D. medical, but dental schools and anyone else who's interfacing with patients who are in pain. Pain just doesn't need to be addressed with painkillers.

I think that's the first thing that's really important to think about here. Often physical therapy can be extremely helpful and in fact, patients need to understand that some pain isn't, in fact, a bad thing, if they are reassured, psychologically, that this is part of healing.

MCDOWELL: But the backlash has been toward, and I speak from personal experience, family experience, that people who are in critical pain, who need opioids, who need Oxycontin, who need Oxycodone, who are fighting stage 4 bone cancer. It is incredibly difficult now to get prescription refilled, that you have to have, and the supplies -- they give you a very short supply.

But these are people who literally can't get addicted because of the pain levels they're experiencing. These are deadly diseases and they're just trying to manage their pain, but it's incredibly difficult. Now, for these people to even -- to go -- you have to drive -- my mother has to drive two hours to get a paper prescription from her doctor every couple of weeks, literally.

CRYSTAL: No, absolutely. And that's very unfortunate and the fact that people who generally do require opioids, potentially are finding harder to get access. I absolutely sympathize tremendously in that situation. The issue we have is the vast majority of people probably not to be on opioids in the first place.

MCDOWELL: Right.

CRYSTAL: I mean, that's what's so --

MCDOWELL: Well, there it lies the personal responsibility, I have conversations with friends and family all of the time, that if a doctor ever offers to give you an opioid, you say no, I just had tooth pulled, I don't need Vicodin for that. And people are hesitant now, I think, at least through the communication through the media, people are hesitant to take opioids at all because they know they're so highly addictive, I mean, it doesn't take much for some people to become chronically addicted to the point that they can't stop taking it.

CRYSTAL: Absolutely. And the issue that we have here is that not everyone is so willing to challenge (INAUDIBLE) and actually, it's a multifaceted approach. So, it's the historical marketing of drugs, it's the fact that doctors have been overprescribing, it's the fact that patients aren't as empowered as perhaps they have been, so it's very difficult to say there's one specific area of responsibility but recognizing we have this crisis.

We need to do something about it. Part of it is to stop the overprescribing and misprescribing of opioids and for where we play a role as a company, is to treat addictions themselves. Anyone who is an opioid addict, the sooner you can get on definitive medical care and the longer you can receive medical treatment, the far greater the likelihood of not relapsing and actually going into long-term recovery and that's what we are committed to.

MCDOWELL: Doctor Crystal, it's good to see you. Doctor Roger Crystal, thank you so much for being here. Coming up, Delta says, pay up, the airline calling on officials at Atlanta's Airport for compensation after the massive power outage caused Delta to lose millions of dollars in revenue because thousands of flights have to be canceled. And (INAUDIBLE) shares of the popular online retailer, Stitch Fix, tumbling after its first earnings report as a public company, the details are next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Welcome back, futures reporting to a higher open, 78-point gain on the Dow Futures right now.

We're looking at a few stocks on the move. Stitch Fix shares unraveling in pre-market following its first earnings report since its IPO. The personalized apparel company reporting strong customer gains, but it only narrowly beat profit expectations because of expansion costs. The company is also struggled to convince investors it can keep up the growth. Shares are down 12 percent in premarket trading.

And can the Blackberry turn around continue? The former smartphone giant is set to report its third-quarter earnings before the bell today. Analysts are expecting revenue of about $215 million. The company has recently pivoted away from phones to cybersecurity software. Blackberry shares are up nearly 60 percent so far, this year.

12 people are dead after a tour bus crashes in Mexico, Lauren Simonetti has details, Lauren.

SIMONETTI: Such a terrible story, Dagen. The bus was carrying cruise ship passengers on an (INAUDIBLE) in Mexico when it flipped over on a narrow highway yesterday, killing 12 people; 20 others injured, including seven Americans. Royal Caribbean says passengers from two of its ships were on that bus. Investigators now are working to go figure out what caused the crash.

Well, Delta wants some money back. The airline is seeking to be repaid for lost revenue after Sunday's power outage at Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport in Atlanta. Delta CEO Bastian says, the airline may have lost between 25 and $50 million of revenue as a result, and he plans to talk to both the airport as well as Georgia Power. That outage caused Delta to cancel about 1400 flights, and they also had to put stranded passengers up in hotel rooms. Hartsfield-Jackson is Delta's main hub. Taking a look at shares of the company, this year up about 13 percent.

And can you believe that in 2017 people are still using password as their password? Here is a list of this year's most common password. We'll start with number three: 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 8, really, I swear. And second place is: password, for the fourth year in a row. The most common password of the year: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. I don't even know how this is possible. Because many Web sites, at least the one I use, make you change your password, and then you have to have the capital letter, the number, the symbol that you can't remember it, so you're constantly changing it. Anyway, for those of you who still use "password", we have new passwords that you might want to change to. None of these are good, but they are popular: "let me in", "monkey", and "Star Wars", made to the list of the most common new password. Dagen, what are your passwords?

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: You know what, I can't even remember them.

SIMONETTI: I know.

MCDOWELL: I only know them on the QWERTY keyboard by the keystrokes. But it's never -- you're not supposed to actually use a word ever, no word in the dictionary, there should never be a word in your password.

SIMONETTI: Impossible to remember.

KELLY: Can I just say that hope that one of the brain trusts of the Democratic Party John Podesta watch this segment, the password for his e- mail which WikiLeaks got was "p@ssword" and the "a" was the "@" symbol. So, hopefully, he watches this --

GABRIELLE: I thought that was pretty classy.

KELLY: He knows not -- hopefully he didn't change it to "Let me In", or "Monkey," or "Star Wars."

FORBES: I hope the used the password for Democrats, tax cuts.

(LAUGHTER)

GABRIELLE: And needed little @.

MCDOWELL: If you put in #tax, if you're going to tweet, the first thing that comes up tax cut scam. And it just makes me so angry because it's not a -- the Democrats weren't involved in it, that doesn't mean it's a scam.

(LAUGHTER)

FORBES: No.

GABRIELLE: But that's good marketing.

KELLY: No, it's a scam when you get to keep more of your own money. It's ridiculous.

MCDOWELL: Yes. But all hat -- all hat no cattle, is what that is. Good marketing, yes. Good words, no action. Coming up, control or creepy? Facebook's expanded facial recognition, which will alert you if your picture is posted through the social media site even if you're not tagged in it.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Facebook raising new privacy concerns. The company expanding its facial recognition technology, it will now alert you if your photo is posted to the social media site even if you're not tagged in it. But Facebook has a different spin, Gerry Willis is here with the details. I don't think it sounds like the worst idea, actually.

GERRI WILLIS, FBN HOST: It doesn't, and they're not saying that at all, that we're going to hurt your privacy. In fact, they're saying 180-degree the opposite. Here's what they say, if someone uploads a photo of your face to Facebook, the company usually knows that it's you, thanks to facial recognition technology. Facebook will now alert people that a friend or a friend of a friend, whoever uploaded a photo of them, even they haven't been tagged in the picture.

This is what Facebook says, "We're doing this to prevent from people from impersonating others on Facebook." Facebook says it has no plans to use facial recognition to enhance ads targeting. That's the first thing I thought of, that this has something to do with advertising. Like, sharing you more news feed post from friends who post and tag photos of you, or as related to locations where you appear in untagged photos.

For example, if you're in somebody's profile photo, which is always public, you'll always be notified. For other photos, though, you'll only get notified if you're in the audience for that photo so as to protect the uploader's privacy, and not alert you about photos you're not allowed to see. Facebook says, the feature is designed to give people more control and make them feel safer because that's the ultimate goal in this society that they're, at least, that everybody feels safe.

MCDOWELL: Well, impersonation is a huge problem on Facebook. And I had -- somebody came -- was on air with us years ago and literally took, I'm not joking, more than 30 photos in the building of themselves, and they tagged me in every single photo and I wasn't in one of them. And it was like the most bizarre thing. And so, why would you do that? This is way -- this is another step in preventing some kind of nonsense like that.

WILLIS: If you're not convinced to this? You can have it undone of your Facebook. There's a way to delete it so that you don't have to be part of this if you don't want to. But I see what you're saying and makes a lot of sense for people who are worried about impersonation.

GABRIELLE: In fact, delete it from people who are trying to impersonate people. In others words --

WILLIS: It will just alert. It will tell you that somebody -- so, Dagen who've known.

GABRIELLE: What I mean is that there's a way in your security options or something to prevent it from being in effect? So, for somebody who wants to try to impersonate somebody else --

WILLIS: Go find those people.

GABRIELLE: They can figure it out.

MCDOWELL: We will know that something is not right if something's up if you start like, if I have a pimple on my face and I start getting ads -- no, I start getting ads for Clear Fill.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: It's a proactive face watch. And I'm like, wait a minute.

GABRIELLE: Dagen, never gets a pimple.

MCDOWELL: Oh, that's not true.

KELLY: I think this highlight, though, the omnipotent power of Facebook, whether you recognize it or not. Because they know you're in the photo. So, you know, whether you're tagged it's you -- they know who are, and that's how they track.

WILLIS: I gave up with privacy a long time ago.

KELLY: You are the product. That's what it is.

GABRIELLE: Not just that but it's a --

FORBES: In a way.

MCDOWELL: In a way. We'll leave it. Gerri, thank you. Gerri Willis. Still ahead, cellphone use, a public health issue. It's what health officials in California are warning. The details are coming up on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

urn:contentItem:5R74-4GH1-JB20-G10K-00000-00Senate Passes Tax Bill; EU Delivers Blow to Uber; Diddy Makes Moves; UPS Orders 125 Tesla Trucks; Thwarting ISIS; Law Enforcement Divided Over Use of Opioid Overdose Antidote; Facebook Expands Facial Recognition Feature For User Photos2017-12-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:47ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTSteve Forbes, Kevin Kelly, Ryan Mauro,m Roger CrystalSHOWFinancial122001cb.231Senate Passes Tax Bill; EU Delivers Blow to Uber; Diddy Makes Moves; UPS Orders 125 Tesla Trucks; Thwarting ISIS; Law Enforcement Divided Over Use of Opioid Overdose Antidote; Facebook Expands Facial Recognition Feature For User PhotosDagen McDowell, Lauren Simonetti, Lea Gabrielle, Gerri Willis

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: I can't believe that we work in industries where we have to wear make-up every day and worry about like flight delays. I can't believe it. Thank you, ladies. Good to see you, guys.

Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Wednesday, December 20th. Your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

The Senate making history. Republicans approving the largest overhaul of our country's tax system in about 30 years, early this morning.

(BEING VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. MITCH MCCONNELL (R), KENTUCKY: I'm a little surprised the democrats all decided voting against middle class tax relief and make American business more competitive as a smart vote and that's an argument we're more than happy to have.

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D), NEW YORK: Eighty-three percent of the middle class will get -- will either pay more in taxes or get little breadcrumbs. Is that this great bill that's helping the middle class? Absolutely not.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The house will vote on the bill later today, likely sending it to the President Trump's desk to sign.

The house originally did pass it yesterday, but there was a procedural snag that is forced the second vote. It was a snag over in the senate. Following the passage in the senate, futures are showing this happening in the markets. We had a slight full back in the Dow yesterday, off about 37 points. But we're seeing possibly new all-time highs for all your major market gauges.

By the way, you have highs on the transports earlier in the week on the Russell 2000. Literally every single market gauge in the U.S. has been moving in sync on the optimism from this tax reform package.

Over in Europe, checking on England, France and Germany, we have losses across the board. All those slight, all markets there down, lessen, about two tenths of a percent.

In Asia overnight stocks mostly lower as well. The Nikkei in Japan up ever so slightly.

ISIS threatening America. The terror group warning of the New Year's Eve attack. The latest as New York Governor, Andrew Cuomo announces heightened security measures for the holidays.

Uber, dealt a blow in Europe. The EU's top core has ruled that the ridesharing company is a taxi service and should be regulated as such. We break down the major implications of that ruling.

What can brown do for Tesla? The details as UPS delivers a big bet on the company's electric semi-truck.

And Diddy making moves to be the top cat down in Carolina. The music mogul reportedly meeting with ambassadors in his bid to buy the Panthers. How the teams could soon have a new owner. All of that and so much more coming up this morning.

Fox News correspondent, Lea Gabrielle, Benchmark managing partner, Kevin Kelly and Forbes Media chairman, former republican presidential candidate, Steve Forbes.

When you walked in this morning, I went I am so glad you're here. Any day, but particularly this day, Mr. Forbes.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good to be with you.

MCDOWELL: Because we have the same feeling about this tax cut package. But if you listen to the democrats, we're going to hell. That's pretty much the message. The country is going hell. It's savory and I just say, poppycock to that. So we're going to get into that immediately.

FORBES: Yes, it's a good word to use on a family channel.

MCDOWELL: Yes. I have an entire lexicon of things like that, like gooey and poppycock, and balderdash. So I will break all of that out.

KEVIN KELLY, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: I think I heard you called the democrats when it's coming into this plain nincompoops.

LEA GABRIELLE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: You know what? I actually called the republicans nincompoops.

KELLY: That's what it is.

MCDOWELL: As thy are putting this together, this is --

FORBES: Another old word is knuckleheads.

MCDOWELL: Knuckleheads. This is what we're going to talk about though, that why do people not yet feel good about this tax reform? Part of it is the problem of how they put it together. So we're going to talk about that in two seconds. I just want to tease our guests that are coming up, Illinois congressman, Peter Roskam. Fox News senior judicial analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. Louisiana senator, John Kennedy. Former republican presidential candidate, Herman Cain. And administrator of the small business administration, Linda McMahaon. There's a lot in this package for small businesses as well.

That outage caused Delta to cancel about 1400 flights, and they also had to put stranded passengers up in hotel rooms. Hartsfield-Jackson is Delta's main hub. Taking a look at shares of the company, this year up about 13 percent.

And can you believe that in 2017 people are still using password as their password? Here is a list of this year's most common password. We'll start with number three: 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 8, really, I swear. And second place is: password, for the fourth year in a row. The most common password of the year: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. I don't even know how this is possible. Because many Web sites, at least the one I use, make you change your password, and then you have to have the capital letter, the number, the symbol that you can't remember it, so you're constantly changing it. Anyway, for those of you who still use "password", we have new passwords that you might want to change to. None of these are good, but they are popular: "let me in", "monkey", and "Star Wars", made to the list of the most common new password. Dagen, what are your passwords?

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: You know what, I can't even remember them.

SIMONETTI: I know.

MCDOWELL: I only know them on the QWERTY keyboard by the keystrokes. But it's never -- you're not supposed to actually use a word ever, no word in the dictionary, there should never be a word in your password.

SIMONETTI: Impossible to remember.

KELLY: Can I just say that hope that one of the brain trusts of the Democratic Party John Podesta watch this segment, the password for his e- mail which WikiLeaks got was "p@ssword" and the "a" was the "@" symbol. So, hopefully, he watches this --

GABRIELLE: I thought that was pretty classy.

KELLY: He knows not -- hopefully he didn't change it to "Let me In", or "Monkey," or "Star Wars."

FORBES: I hope the used the password for Democrats, tax cuts.

(LAUGHTER)

GABRIELLE: And needed little @.

MCDOWELL: If you put in #tax, if you're going to tweet, the first thing that comes up tax cut scam. And it just makes me so angry because it's not a -- the Democrats weren't involved in it, that doesn't mean it's a scam.

(LAUGHTER)

FORBES: No.

GABRIELLE: But that's good marketing.

KELLY: No, it's a scam when you get to keep more of your own money. It's ridiculous.

MCDOWELL: Yes. But all hat -- all hat no cattle, is what that is. Good marketing, yes. Good words, no action. Coming up, control or creepy? Facebook's expanded facial recognition, which will alert you if your picture is posted through the social media site even if you're not tagged in it.

MCDOWELL: Facebook raising new privacy concerns. The company expanding its facial recognition technology, it will now alert you if your photo is posted to the social media site even if you're not tagged in it. But Facebook has a different spin, Gerry Willis is here with the details. I don't think it sounds like the worst idea, actually.

GERRI WILLIS, FBN HOST: It doesn't, and they're not saying that at all, that we're going to hurt your privacy. In fact, they're saying 180-degree the opposite. Here's what they say, if someone uploads a photo of your face to Facebook, the company usually knows that it's you, thanks to facial recognition technology. Facebook will now alert people that a friend or a friend of a friend, whoever uploaded a photo of them, even they haven't been tagged in the picture.

This is what Facebook says, "We're doing this to prevent from people from impersonating others on Facebook." Facebook says it has no plans to use facial recognition to enhance ads targeting. That's the first thing I thought of, that this has something to do with advertising. Like, sharing you more news feed post from friends who post and tag photos of you, or as related to locations where you appear in untagged photos.

For example, if you're in somebody's profile photo, which is always public, you'll always be notified. For other photos, though, you'll only get notified if you're in the audience for that photo so as to protect the uploader's privacy, and not alert you about photos you're not allowed to see. Facebook says, the feature is designed to give people more control and make them feel safer because that's the ultimate goal in this society that they're, at least, that everybody feels safe.

MCDOWELL: Well, impersonation is a huge problem on Facebook. And I had -- somebody came -- was on air with us years ago and literally took, I'm not joking, more than 30 photos in the building of themselves, and they tagged me in every single photo and I wasn't in one of them. And it was like the most bizarre thing. And so, why would you do that? This is way -- this is another step in preventing some kind of nonsense like that.

WILLIS: If you're not convinced to this? You can have it undone of your Facebook. There's a way to delete it so that you don't have to be part of this if you don't want to. But I see what you're saying and makes a lot of sense for people who are worried about impersonation.

GABRIELLE: In fact, delete it from people who are trying to impersonate people. In others words --

WILLIS: It will just alert. It will tell you that somebody -- so, Dagen who've known.

GABRIELLE: What I mean is that there's a way in your security options or something to prevent it from being in effect? So, for somebody who wants to try to impersonate somebody else --

WILLIS: Go find those people.

GABRIELLE: They can figure it out.

MCDOWELL: We will know that something is not right if something's up if you start like, if I have a pimple on my face and I start getting ads -- no, I start getting ads for Clear Fill.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: It's a proactive face watch. And I'm like, wait a minute.

GABRIELLE: Dagen, never gets a pimple.

MCDOWELL: Oh, that's not true.

KELLY: I think this highlight, though, the omnipotent power of Facebook, whether you recognize it or not. Because they know you're in the photo. So, you know, whether you're tagged it's you -- they know who are, and that's how they track.

WILLIS: I gave up with privacy a long time ago.

KELLY: You are the product. That's what it is.

GABRIELLE: Not just that but it's a --

FORBES: In a way.

MCDOWELL: In a way. We'll leave it. Gerri, thank you. Gerri Willis. Still ahead, cellphone use, a public health issue. It's what health officials in California are warning. The details are coming up on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

I already explained most of the problems with this version of the law in this post[1]. For now, I'll just say that I hope the bill supporters are right and that the law actually helps sex trafficking victims as they anticipated. Eventually Ihope toexplainwhat I think went wrongso we can better prepare for the onslaught ofproposed Section 230 amendments that are coming. A short linkwrap: * TechFreedom[2]:Senate Passes Hybrid SESTA Bill, Despite Constitutional ...ckfiring Concerns: 'This is a new low for CongressThe process that led to this point was appalling' * Open Technology Institute[3]:Congress Erred in Passage of FOSTA, Threatening the Internet and Trafficking Victims: 'Though Congress' intentions are good, its methods are harmful' * NPR All Things Considered[4]:Section 230: A Key Legal Shield For Facebook, Google Is About To Change * Mike Godwin[5]:The Roots of Section 230 Show Why We Shouldn't Abandon Intermediary Liability Protection * AEIdeas[6]:Should Big Tech be held more liable for the content on their platforms?

An AEIdeas online symposium * Congressional Research Service[7]: Ex Post Facto Implications of the Allow States and Victims to Fight Online Sex Trafficking Act of 2017 (H.R. 1865). We may have more to say about this. For now, note thatTechFreedom disagrees[8]. My apologies, I cannot bring myself to link to the gloating posts from the people who hate Google/Facebook, Section 230, or the Internet generally. It's open season on Section 230, and every victim's advocacy group is gearing up. Section 230had a good run while it lasted. Apr 08, 2019( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/ Delivered by Newstex) Another Senate hearing probing into the treatment of free speech at social media companies is scheduled to happen on April 10.The hearing, 'Stifling Free Speech: Technological Censorship and the Public Discourse,' will be headed by subcommittee chair Senator Ted Cruz (R-Texas). Representatives from Facebook, Twitter, and Google have been asked to testify in front of the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on the Constitution.

Senate sources say all three representatives will be attending, but only Facebook confirmed its response to CNET.Facebook's public policy director, Neil Potts, will be representing the company in the hearing. Its testimony comes in the face of CEO Mark Zuckerberg calling for more regulation. But after the heavy-handed regulations proposed by the U.K. in an attempt to rid the internet of 'harm,' one wonders how much more regulation Facebook is willing to take.Senator Cruz has been outspoken in his criticism of big tech companies, telling MRC's President Brent Bozell that 'There is no greater threat today, in the United States of America or globally, than big tech.' He also said that he would be 'leading the charge in the Senate' against the 'naked ideological censorship.'Some tech media outlets are skeptical of this endeavor. Engadget wrote that 'this will be another case of "Tech Companies Go to Congress," in which Congress attempts to shed light on an issue, and instead, we learn very little.'The hearing will take place at 2:30 pm, at the Dirksen Senate Office Building.
