urn:contentItem:5T9H-TH61-DXH2-62NH-00000-00Senate Republicans Deliver Testimony Ultimatum To Kavanaugh Accuser Christine Blasey Ford; Shinzo Abe Re-Elected Prime Minister After Landslide Victory In Japan; Azar on Florence Response; Sky to be Auctioned Off; SnackNation Secures $12M2018-09-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:47ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTMike Murphy, Steve Forbes, Herman Cain, Sandy Cockrell, Alex Azar, Sean KellyNEWSFinancial092003cb.231Senate Republicans Deliver Testimony Ultimatum To Kavanaugh Accuser Christine Blasey Ford; Shinzo Abe Re-Elected Prime Minister After Landslide Victory In Japan; Azar on Florence Response; Sky to be Auctioned Off; SnackNation Secures $12MDagen McDowell, Blake Burman, Marie Harf, Cheryl Casone, Connell McShane, Stuart Varney

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Thursday, September 20th. Your top stories at 8:00 a.m. Eastern. Supreme Court showdown. Republicans warn that time is running out for Nominee Brett Kavanaugh's accuser to testify. President Trump defending his pick to the Supreme Court and hopeful that Christine Blasey Ford will testify.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I really want to see her, I really would want to see what she has to say. But I want to give it all the time they need if she shows up that would be wonderful. If she doesn't show up, that would be unfortunate.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We have the latest coming up. And we are watching these markets because the Dow and the S&P 500 are oh, so close to new all-time highs. On the Dow, all the futures are up 94-point gain on the Dow futures at the moment. 26,616 and change is the old record set for the blue chips January 26th of this year. We will be watching that. This after a bit of a mixed session yesterday, the Dow and S&P moving to plus side.

The NASDAQ composite dipping lower. Tech stocks taken a bit of a bruising there. Checking the global market action over in Europe, we have buying across the board in England, France, and Germany and every market in Asia overnight up except the Shanghai down just fractionally.

Florence fallout. Devastating flooding in the Carolinas could wreak havoc on the region for years. And the concerns go well beyond infrastructure. We take a closer look at the health hazards with Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar later this hour.

Alibaba backtracks. Jack Ma, the founder says his company is pledged to create one million jobs in America is off the table. He's blaming the trade dispute that the U.S. is having with China, the fallout ahead.

On the block, the battle for Sky News will go to auction. We have the details on how this deal's fate could be sealed. All that and so much more coming up this morning, former state department spokesman, host of "BENSON & HARF" on Fox News Radio, Maria Harf. Rosecliff CEO and Managing Partner Mike Murphy and Forbes Media Chairman and former Republican presidential candidate, Steve Forbes.

It's been a pleasure so far to spend this morning with you. , it has been a pleasure so far, to spend this morning with you. And just real quick, Steve, because I know you love talking taxes, the corporate tax cut is paying for itself, how about that.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: And Steve Moore had an article on that just a few hours ago, 24 hours ago. Yes. When you get off of people's tax, the economy prospers. And the assets of the nation go up as well as the incomes. And, so for the first time in a long time not only do we have job shortages but also companies are getting in the business that the government can never do, job training.

That's the best, Corporate America is the best job trainer, you're starting to see that kick in, and so it's nice to have the problem, labor shortages, wow.

MCDOWELL: So I love to see you smile. That's why I asked you that question, Steve. We've got a lot --

FORBES: Thank you. I always smile.

MCDOWELL: No. Thank you. Steve Forbes also, the first thing you always ask about my dogs, so thank you for that. To our top story this hour, President Trump hitting the campaign trail. The President will hold a rally in Las Vegas tonight as the midterm elections loom. The GOP pushes ahead -- full steam ahead on confirming Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court. Blake Burman is joining us with the very latest from the White House. Good morning, Blake.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: Hi there, Dagen. Good morning to you as well. Republicans who control the Senate Judiciary Committee have given Christine Blasey Ford an ultimatum. Let us know by tomorrow morning at 10:00 a.m. Friday at 10:00 a.m. if you will testify before that committee on Monday, or not. Chuck Grassley, the top Republican who runs that committee says he is giving Ford four different options on how to make that possible.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. CHUCK GRASSLEY (R-IA), CHAIRMAN, SENATE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE: Where I'm focused right now is doing everything that we can to make Dr. Ford comfortable with coming before our committee either in an open session or closed session or a public or a private interviews.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: The Supreme Court Nominee Brett Kavanaugh who Ford says sexually assaulted her at a party during their high school years denies that allegation and says he is ready to head back to the Hill Monday. But Ford's attorney said last night in a statement that timeline is hurried, "the committee stated plans to move forward with a hearing that has only two witnesses is not a fair or good faith investigation."

They go on to write, the rush to a hearing is unnecessary and contrary to the committee discovering the truth. Ford's attorneys have also called for law enforcement investigation before she would testify, a position that Democrats support as well.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. KIRSTEN GILLIBRAND (R), NEW YORK: I think staying there testify on Monday, or not be heard I think it is fairly outrageous. And what's really shocking to me that is that there is a normal process for a Supreme Court justice nomination, and it starts with an FBI background check.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Dagen, President Trump continues to stand by his FBI -- his Supreme Court nominee rather. The President said yesterday that if Ford were to testify up the Hill, that would be "wonderful." If not, he described that as "unfortunate." As for the President know official public events on his schedule today, he will thought head later today to Las Vegas for a campaign rally there tonight. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Thank you. Blake Burman at the White House for us. And let's turner to the political impact of this and those midterm elections. 47 days away in an increasingly partisan season. My next guest is launching a super PAC to support President Trump's agenda in the face of escalating liberal backlash. Here with us now is former presidential candidate Herman Cain. Tell us about the initiative in terms of the President's agenda.

Steve Forbes was talking about some of the results that this country is already seen, good morning.

HERMAN CAIN, FORMER PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Good morning, Dagen. And that's what people should focus on. And that's what we are going to be focusing on with the super PAC called America Fighting Back. And people can help and we need their help at americafighting backpack.com or AFB.com. Here is why we started this. The liberal media and you know who they are, they basically report 90 percent negative about this president.

And about the results that we are getting similar to the ones that Steve just alluded to. 90 percent negative. This is -- our objective is simple. Number one, help maintain control of the United States House and the United States Senate and to support the President's agenda through 2020. And I have often said, you don't have to love the tree to love the fruit. The fruit is great.

But all the liberal media and the Democrats want to focus on, they want to focus on bringing down the tree. And so this super PAC America Fighting Back, is going to fight back against the negativity.

MCDOWELL: Well, Steve have said this, I will debate policy all day long, personality not. What do you have to say to Herman?

FORBES: Well Herman, the Republicans won going to have an agenda, positive agenda, not just saying the economy is good but how they're going to make it better. And, two, the President looks like he is now going to be focusing on the economy at a great tweet this morning. The key thing is set the agenda and not get sidetracked. The Republicans going to do it and finally, Herman, persuade the Republicans and get a real tax cut proposal out there.

So people have a Christmas present to look forward to if they win.

CAIN: I agree with you one hundred percent, Steve. And the thing is yes, this Super PAC along with a lot of other organizations and PACs that are out there, they are doing a good job of trying to get a positive message out about the results that this president and this administration that they are producing. However, the message is sometimes overwhelmed, and what sets us apart is that we will have a voice, this voice and a face, this face to the T.V. ad campaign that we're going to be running.

And you're right, it's difficult at times to get all of the Republicans to get on the same page. We also hope that this would be a vehicle for them to help get on the same page and deliver that messages as well as that Christmas present you talked about which we know is working out fantastic and they now have momentum behind them as well as actual results based on what you mentioned that Steve Forbes heard about yesterday.

(CROSSTALK)

FORBES: -- in blue states there are about 20 Republicans -- representatives in blue states that are vulnerable, they're all getting hit on assault thing losing to local deductions. How are you going to counter that to save these 20 Republicans?

CAIN: Our second tactic is a targeted campaign in those very vulnerable states. Remember the Super PAC we're not going to coordinate with them but we know where these races are close. And we have technology that will allow us to target these races so we can then go in and target the voters in those states to tell them the truth. All we have to do is tell people the truth, they will make the right decisions.

So we are targeting those races in order to try to help out.

MCDOWELL: Marie has a question for you, Herman.

MARIE HARF, FOX NEWS POLITICAL COMMENTATOR: Herman, Marie Harf here, there is a lot of evidence in polls and anecdotally that the Republican voters are not that fired up this November. Democrats are really enthusiastic, their base is ready to go vote and a lot of stories about Republicans not believing that they might lose the House, there is a lot of apathy. It seems like upon Republicans voters. How are you going to help tackle that issue?

CAIN: The thing that I talked about on my show yesterday that's posted at my Web site, Hermancain.com, Republicans and Conservatives don't stay home. Don't believe that it's a slam dunk. This is how we're going to counter it by encouraging people through the various platforms that we participate with to tell people you can't -- you can't take it for granted. Don't assume just because the fruit meaning the results of this administration of this President are so good, that it is impossible for people to vote for Democrats, no. The --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: No. I was just --

CAIN: They are using nefarious deceptive rhetoric in order to try to get people's vote for Democrats which is a bad idea as you know and this is what we are fighting with our messages.

MCDOWELL: Well, Marie is kind of a big old Democrat because she actually worked in the State Department Undersecretary State John Kerry, worked in the Obama administration, so you're kind of -- but this is an issue and I want to get to there is one other thing about Alibaba, Chairman Jack Ma walk -- has walked back promise to create one million jobs in the United States.

Saying that the trade dispute is to blame the Chinese tech billionaire who made this promise in 2017 while speaking with then-President Elect Trump, said his commitment contingent on good relations between the U.S. and China, and these retaliatory tariffs are specifically targeted whether you're talking about China or even what Europe has done at red districts and Republican districts. So it's political. What this retaliation from these nations, Herman.

CAIN: You're absolutely right. First, Marie not all Democrats, we can only save the savable, OK? Now, to your point, Dagen, this is the points that I want to make, if it's a good business decision for Alibaba they will eventually come back with that offer, that's what's going to drive it. Secondly, I understand why he may have retracted it because maybe he didn't want to ruffle feathers of the Chinese government at that particular time.

But ultimately, if this is a goods business decision and these negotiations and this tension is reduced, it could be something that he would readdress, simply because he is motivated by making a good business decision but he has to put up a smiley face right now to say that he is on the side of the Chinese government.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Well said, Herman. Thank you so much for being here. Herman Cain. Pleasure always, sir.

CAIN: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Coming up. Health hazards after Hurricane Florence standing water in overflow of farm waste causing a public health emergency in the Carolinas. Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar joins us this hour with how the administration is helping those affected by this disaster. Plus the battle for Sky TV heads to the auction block. The latest on the bidding war between Comcast and the parent company of this network, 21st Century Fox, next.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back to MORNINGS WITH MARIA. I'm Cheryl Casone with some of your headlines. A suspect arrested after the murder of a jogger in the nation's capital. Police in Washington arrested a man last night after a FEMA jogger was stabbed multiple times and killed in a residential neighborhood. Police are expected to hold a news conference to give us more details on the case at 10:30 a.m. Eastern time this morning.

After being attacked Tuesday night, 35-year-old Wendy Martinez who has newly engaged stumbled into a takeout restaurant for help. She later died at a hospital. Police believe she was likely a random target.

Well, breaking news this morning. Shares of Under Armour, they're actually rallying in premarket up more than three percent right now. The company says it is going to cut about 474 jobs as part of a restructuring plan. That works out to three percent of its global workforce. Under Armour also raising its profit outlook for 2018. Under Armour also releasing its new rock sneakers today as in, yes, the rock. There you go.

Well, Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has been reelected head of the ruling liberal Democratic Party third term. Abe is on course to become Japan's longest serving prime minister in August of 2021. He finishes out his term of course. Abe won the election on a landslide receiving 70 percent of the votes.

And there is this. Some main lobsters are getting baked before getting boiled. Let me explain. The restaurant Charlotte's Legendary Lobster Pound which is in Seawall is getting some its lobsters high on pot. They blow the smoke into their tank before they cook them. The owner, Charlotte Gill is a registered medical marijuana caregiver and she says doing this seems bit more humane.

Earlier researches found lobsters have an advanced nervous system and may feel pain. Gill says a lobster she experimented on is much calmer afterwards. And then she released it back to the ocean. She's only going to use this method if a customer requests it. All right. Coming up, optimism waning. The risks and worries, some top executives have about why this economic sweet spot won't last much longer.

Plus, move over pizza rat. A New York rodent also discovered in a New York City subway. It's taking the internet by storm. You don't want to miss that one. Stay with us.

MCDOWELL: Welcome Back. How long can the economic boon last? A new Deloitte survey finds less than half of chief financial officers expect better economic conditions in a year and that's the lowest recorded in eight quarters. Joining us with much more on these findings. A first on Fox Business interview. Deloitte's Global CFO program leader Sandy Cockrell. Sandy, good to see you.

SANDY COCKRELL, GLOBAL LEADER OF THE CFO PROGRAM, DELOITTE TOUCHE TOHMATSU LIMITED: Dagen, great to see you.

MCDOWELL: How do you read and let's start with that statistic. How do you read into that? What does that tell you about the road ahead?

COCKRELL: Well, first of all, it's really important. The second quarter has some of the highest survey recordings, you know, we have ever seen. So we're coming down some very high metrics. And if you look at the U.S. economy, the North American company, nine out of 10 CFOs still say at least good. So that's positive. One of the statistics that just jumped out of us is definitely -- think actually positive again, dividend growth.

7.4 percent forecasted dividend growth over next year. That is a survey record just off the charts. So especially in retail wholesale and energy and resources stocks. So those investors are sitting pretty good right now.

MIKE MURPHY, CEO AND MANAGING PARTNER, ROSECLIFF CAPITAL: So, Sandy, two things, one, are these public companies? The CFOs of --

(CROSSTALK)

COCKRELL: Yes. 130 some CFOs participated this quarter. We've done this for eight years and most all of these are from public multinational companies with billion dollars of sales.

MURPHY: And just historically, are they a good indicator or, you know, because sometimes they'll see people -- results like this come in as contrarian indicators. They're historically been good at predicting.

COCKRELL: Yes. All the metrics, we follow a number of metrics. Revenue growth, earnings growth, capital expenditures are in growth and those metrics really do kind of follow other economic indices in pretty good way. Yes.

FORBES: Are these companies have large international component? Do they make a distinction between what they see in Europe and Asia versus the U.S.?

COCKRELL: Yes.

FORBES: And do they see the U.S. as being good and the rest of the world being bad or to think U.S. is in trouble?

COCKRELL: Steve, what we saw this quarter is still huge amount of optimism for the North American economy. For the Chinese economy and the European economy they slid. If you look at China, so only 32 percent of the CFOs said the Chinese economy is good today, 55 percent last quarter. So, huge dramatic shift. You got to wonder if CFOs are worried about the trade wards and tariffs --

(CROSSTALK)

FORBES: How much damage let's say, worst happens, 25 percent tariffs the end of the year, sales taxes on 207 billion or whatever number of imports. What do you think that's going to do, the U.S. economy into the global economy. How much damage? Right now people sort of pooh-pooh it but --

(CROSSTALK)

COCKRELL: Well, we're starting to see -- you know, it's interesting if you think where we are in calendar year. Most calendar companies are just starting their planning processes for 2019. If you're a multinationalist pushing a lot of goods or global supply chain, you really just scratching your head as to what to do your pricing, what does that do to margins and all those things. And that got reflected in company --

(CROSSTALK)

FORBES: So is this uncertainty affecting investment decisions?

COCKRELL: Yes, yes. In other -- and just to that point, there is a huge bias this quarter to invest organically as opposed to inorganically through M&A, partly due to uncertainty. Secondly, 71 percent of the CFOs said that U.S. equity markets were overvalued. Now that was basically a month ago, S&P 500 has moved up three percent since then.

MCDOWELL: So if you think the market is overvalued, would that impact share buybacks, would you take that money and invest it in a different way?

COCKRELL: Well, you know, that's the interesting thing with the 7.4 percent forecasted dividend growth, that really comes from a few things. Number one, obviously company performance has been very strong. You know, forecasting 8.1 percent basically earnings growth over the next 12 months. So a lot of cash accumulation from that second tax reform in two elements. Number one, lower rate and number two for multinationals having the ability to repatriate cash in effective way.

And number three, companies and CFOs are a lot more sensitive today about their capital allocation methodologies because of activism. You have to be. And so that's really fueling dividend growth over the next year.

FORBES: Activism.

MCDOWELL: Well, I want to --

FORBES: Can you spell that out?

MCDOWELL: Yes. Well --

MURPHY: It's fine. Go ahead, Steve.

MCDOWELL: OK. He said activism spell that out.

COCKRELL: Yes. So shareholder activism and basically investors expecting a lot more in terms of overall returns. We see this in the news every day, you really got to stay on toes to be able to not be a target of activist. And a company that has a lot of cash sitting on balance sheet that doesn't explain what they're going to do with it, they become a target.

MCDOWELL: Mike, real quick.

MURPHY: So just real quick. So ultimately, the results of this study are that the economy is good but they don't see it being great for that long.

COCKRELL: Yes. The North American economy is very strong. When we ask what does it looked like a year from now, less than half the CFOs said the U.S. economy will be better one year from now.

MCDOWELL: But there's kind of the paid worry warts, aren't they, Steve? They're the ones who are paid to worry while the CEOs think kind of big picture 10 years down the road.

COCKRELL: Yes. Well, I get to a spend a lot of time with CFOs, I think they're pretty good people.

MCDOWELL: I didn't say worry warts were bad people. Why do you think I bite my fingernails? Sandy, thank you.

COCKRELL: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Thank so much. Great insight in the survey.

COCKRELL: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Sandy Cockrell from Delloite. Coming up. The battle for Sky TV. The latest on the bidding war between Comcast and the parent company of this network, 21st Century Fox later this hour. And a cryptic countdown. We revel the secret behind Olive Garden's mysterious countdown clock ahead.

MCDOWELL: Welcome back everybody I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Thursday, September 20th. And we've got breaking news right here right now.

Jobless claims coming in for the most recent week, look at that coming in well below expectations which is good, 201,000. The lower the number on your weekly jobless claims, the better that is as a sign of a very healthy labor market. These are people filing first time claims for unemployment benefits.

We're also getting a reading on the Philadelphia Fed Index and that came in above expectations, 22.9 in the month of September versus an estimate of 17 points. We got Mike Murphy standing by. But look at these markets go, Dow Jones Futures are up 114 points at the moment. So we've got a rally across the board.

This is a critical day for the market because we could, we could hit a new all-time high, all-time closing high. The Blue Chips, the Dow is two -- about 211 points away from its all-time closing high hit earlier this year in January.

Let's talk about this Mike Murphy, what do you make of these numbers? Like when you get the jobless claims number close to 200,000 and came in 201,000, that just tells you how healthy this job market --

MURPHY: News flash, the economy is doing great and I think of the -- to the people watching at home, big mistake people make I think is saying this can't continue.

But it can continue, there's no rule or law that says that this has to stop. Right now the economy is hitting on all cylinders, we're doing great. People have jobs, people have money to spend, that's a good thing, it's a great time to be in the United States, it's a great time to be investing. Don't think the market is too high, you can still invest in the market at these levels because of the economy.

MCDOWELL: What did President Trump tweet earlier Steve? He's like, "Eh, if they don't" -- I'm paraphrasing but, "If you don't like your job and they're not treating you right, go get another one because the job market is great." I just think that that's kind of the optimism that --

FORBES: It would be a good thing to see what it does to the housing market if this thing last for a couple of years which it should. People become mobile again, that's going to be good for housing, housing market.

MCDOWELL: Yes, absolutely. And when people buy homes that -- particularly new homes, that really spreads to mini corners of the economy in terms the building and --

FORBES: And the very fact that people are still caution is good for the stock market.

MURPHY: Exactly.

FORBES: for people to get optimistic you got to get pessimistic.

MURPHY: Yes.

FORBES: IF it feels good, stay out. If feels bad or cautious, get in.

MURPHY: Yes. And on housing, you know, mortgage rates up at seven years highs right now. So that's one thing to keep an eye on.

If anyone's looking to buy homes, probably a great time because as the economy improves, would expect rates (INAUDIBLE)

FORBES: Would you do floating rates or fixed rate if you're building the house.

MURPHY: I would do fixed rate for certain.

MCDOWELL: Yes. At this point with the -- I mean, you're going to put your hands in the -- in the put your money in the hands of the Federal Reserve or you're buying a house, I don't know, not right now.

Thank you gentlemen. But we want to move on to Florence's fallout, now causing a public health hazard. Massive flooding slamming North Carolina's hog farm. This is the largest concentration of hog farms in the country.

More than 5,000 of the state's hogs and pigs, dad waste lagoons, dozens of waste lagoons overflowing causing a health hazard.

Joining me with more to discuss this and many other topic, Health and Human Services Secretary, former Elli Lilly Executive, Alex Azar. Mr. Secretary, what is HHS doing to address what is clearly a health emergency?

ALEX AZAR: We;; the president's been showing personal leadership throughout this. He was just down in the Carolinas yesterday and we've been at HHS have been working under his direction.

We pre-deployed hundreds of people into there and we're going to be there as long as it takes to get the job done to help those in Carolina in the situation, I'm glad to report that the hospitals are up and running, they're on their power. We've got most -- nursing homes are back up and occupied and we've actually gotten every dialysis patient and the Carolina is accounted for.

So we've got a long road to go, it's going to be a significant recovery effort ,we'll be in for the long haul but progress is being made that's quite good so far.

MCDOWELL: What kind of monitoring is HHS going to do with this? And I bring up the dozen -- the several dozen ways lagoons from these farms that have overflowed because this was a really serious problem in the Carolinas.

I believe it was -- it was almost 20 years ago after Hurricane Floyd in 1999. And what -- how do you monitor the impacts of these kind of environmental problems.

AZAR: So you're right to raise that after a significant flooding event like this. You've got affluent runoff coming from various hog, chicken farms that can b an issue. You have to be checking well water as well as public water supplies.

We have going got a significant team of an environmental response team from the Center of Disease Control as well as the Food and Drug Administration that is ready to deploy. Now, the state and local governments take the lead here but we're on standby ready to deploy and be active to a system and anything that they need.

But we'll take our cues from the -- from the leadership in North Carolina and South Carolina here but we've got the resources and we're ready and you're right, it's significant and important issue of public health.

MCDOWELL: Are they communicating with you enough at this point?

AZAR: Oh, very much so. Very much so. I cannot have been more impressed by the leadership in South Carolina and North Carolina and our connectivity. We've got our teams, they're deployed with their emergency teams.

Of course, FEMA is providing overall federal direction, we're tightly aligned working with the president directly on this. So no, I think everything is work as it ought to be working in a situation like this as catastrophic as the circumstances happen to be.

MCDOWELL: Speaking of the catastrophic circumstances, what is HHS doing about the mental health issue for all of these residents of the Carolinas? Because, again, it becomes a -- not just a physical health problem but a mental health problem as well when people see everything that they have ever -- that they own essentially destroyed?

AZAR: Well you're absolutely right. The mental health issues are ones that we'll be dealing with in the weeks and months and even years ahead. And that's a -- we provide significant support to the state and local authorities there and public health providers for mental health.

That's our substance abuse mental health services agency. We provide significant grants and expertise to them to assist and providing mental healthcare services and, of course, deploy our professional -- our healthcare professionals with our -- with the FEMA emergency response teams that are there on the ground, at the shelters, able to provide care and counseling as we speak.

MCDOWELL: Zack Rosenberg, the Chief of the charity organization SBPUSA.org was on earlier and he said that he is sensing working with organizations like FEMA and HUD, Housing in Urban Development, that there is a real openness to true public private partnerships to make sure that A, gets to people quickly, that the rebuilding happens quickly.

Can you speak to that within Health and Human Services particularly given the fact that you came from the private sector.

AZAR: Oh sure. We -- it's vital that we be open to working with a private sector, to provide resources. That's one of the gray aspects of how we work here in America and the American governmental system that we never try to carry the burden alone from the government side but rather working in public/private partnership and taking advantage of the tremendous goodwill and charity of the American people who see catastrophic situation like this.

Their heart goes out to their fellow citizens and they want to be of assistance not just individual people but companies and organizations and we work to facilitate that, that's one of the important missions on in our public health service core.

MCDOWELL: I want to turn the opioid crisis, the Wall Street Journal has an article titled, "Opioid Crisis Emerges as Dominant Campaign Theme." The Department of Health and Human services granting $1 billion this week to fight this opioid crisis. Can you tell us where that money is going, how it's being spend?

AZAR: You bet. So the president's been providing decisive leadership here, highlighting and really making this a central issue or the country, the opioid epidemic that is devastating so many families, so many communities across every generation.

And just yesterday we released a $1 billion of A, the state and local government that help provide resources for prevention, for treatment, for recovery. This is going to help people get into medication-assisted treatment so they can break the cycle of addiction that's going to help states in controlling the flow of legal and illegal opioid. So this is vital relief around the country for all those suffering from this massive epidemic.

MCDOWELL: And I think that you'll agree with this Mr. Secretary, if a doctor tries to prescribe you opioids for the first time, you need to push back on that. It really starts with the individual in this country.

AZAR: It's really important that everybody have a very detailed discussion with their doctor about what they're being prescribed and why they're being prescribed. And you know, we're seeing really positive signs although we have a long way to go.

We've seen a reduction in the prescribing rates for legal opioids, we've seen a 264 percent increase since the president took office of Naloxone prescriptions which are those drugs, the overdose reversing drugs and we've seen from 2016 to 2017a 50 percent reduction in heroine use in this country.

So we've got a long way to go, we didn't get in this overnight but we're making progress all working together across our communities.

MCDOWELL: Mr. Secretary, Secretary of Health and Human Services Alex Azar, thank you so much for being here.

AZAR: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, Amazon Go growing, Stuart Varney, he loves to talk about Amazon and he will do that. What's next for the e-commerce giant?

Plus, fighting the flood, more video of this little rodent taking on a torrential downpour inside a New York City subway. He's just like the rest of us who live here, we'll be right back.

MCDOWELL: The battle for sky will be settled by auction this weekend. Connell McShane on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with more. Hey Connell.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hey, hello there Dagen. You know, it's interesting, this has been going on for close to two years, 21 months to be exact between the FOX Business Network parent company, 21st Century Fox and Comcast over who would end up with the British broadcasters giant.

But as regulators come out and said, "Yes, we're going to have an auction," kind of unusual. But that what they're going to do starting tomorrow ending on Saturday. Max three rounds of biding and we'll see who comes away with Sky. Market cap's $35 billion, so certainly the final number you think would be higher than that.

Now, before I go back to you, I also want to mention earnings today briefly, garden restaurants of Olive Garden chain and also a number of other restaurant chains, Longhorn Steak House, the Capital Grill and others, $0.10 better than expected this morning. In its most recent quarter, $1.34 versus $1.24, stocks been red hot. Looks like it will continue possibly up again an all-time high this morning.

It's a 40 plus percent over the last 52 weeks and I know, I think you guys have been following, speaking of Olive Garden Dagen, this story where they say they're going to have a huge reveal, mysterious countdown clock that emerge at Olive Garden, we know what it was about, it turns out Olive Garden is issuing 10 more of its annual pasta passes in some sort of a digital scavenger hunt. So strong sales and bad, so the world's a better place, I believe.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much Connell. Good to see you. Connell McShane at the New York Stock Exchange.

Amazon now considering opening as many as 3,000 cashierless, that's cashier free stores by 2021 according to a recent report. Joining us now, the Host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney. You love talking about Amazon.

STEWART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I do. It's a brilliant company with extraordinary power and global reach and the guy who found it, it is now by far in a way the richest man in the world.

But what they're doing with these cashierless stores is really very advanced. As I understand it, now I've not been to one, they have experiment (INAUDIBLE) you walk in the store, you put your phone against some kind of scanner, walk around the store, takes stuff off the shelves which you want and walk out.

Everything's scanned and looked at electronically and you get the bill on your phone a little later. I don't think any other retailer has anything close to that and that may well be the way of the future. But Dagen, I draw your attention to a New York Times Op-Ed piece which reads as follows, "Why Jeff Bezos should push for nobody to get as rich as Jeff Bezos?"

The Times is behind the lefties move to reign big tech in especially Jeff Bezos and especially Amazon. They're under attack but what happens if the attacker succeed and reign in Amazon? Do we still get this kind of cashierless stores innovation? My answer is no.

We've got a problem with the concentration of wealth and power that the technology economy gives to us but we don't have an answer as to what to do with it.

MCDOWELL: I don't know, as long as -- as long as they keep innovating I don't see a problem with it. And I've got an entire lexicon of hand gestures that I would gladly teach to those tech billionaires if they would like to communicate with the New York Times in a nonverbal way.

VARNEY: I thought you're having a go at me there because I tend to use my hands a little do I not?

MCDOWELL: No, no, no. I do too. I think that we are from the same stock if you will.

VARNEY: Well the bottom line is that the attack is gathering steam and it's an attack on America's technology leaders and I don't know where it's going and I hope it fails.

MCDOWELL: Me too. Agreement. Stuart, thank you. We will see you in 11 minutes time, almost. Stuart & -- Stuart Varney, "VARNEY & COMPANY." Brett Bear is coming up with Stuart, you don't want to miss Brett with Mr. Varney, 9:00 a.m. Monday through Friday. Three hours of Stuart straight ahead.

But for -- up here first, talk about a tech crunch, how this snack delivery services making a big splash in Silicon Valley, next.

MCDOWELL: Snacking made simple. The tech savvy delivery service called Snack Nation securing $12 million in Siri (INAUDIBLE) funding. The company founded on the idea of making healthy food more convenient than junkfood.

Joining us now the company's Co-Founder and CEO Sean Kelly. Sean, SnackNation, we attacked these boxes of SnackNation. So while we eat, please speak.

SEAN KELLY, CO-FOUNDER & CEO, SNACKNATION: Absolutely. You want to know a little bit about SnackNation?

MCDOWELL: Yes. Please sir.

KELLY: All right. We are the authority when it comes to discovering emerging an innovative snack food brands. And what we mean more specifically is that we're a tech enabled snack delivery service that delivers creations like these to thousands of companies and homes across the country.

MARIE HARF, FOX NEWS RADIO HOST: Sean, you're telling me you can make something that taste like Cheetos but it's healthier for me, right?

KELLY: We don't necessarily make them but --

HARF: Or deliver it, not make.

KELLY: Absolutely, deliver. We're go and find the best emerging and innovative brands that's also better for you and clean delicious and bring them direct to people. So you can feel a little bit less bad of having the snacks you want.

HARF: Great.

MURPHY: Sean, good to see you. We are in full disclosure, Rosecliff Ventures are proud investors in SnackNation, in Sean's business. One thing we look forward Dagen when we're investing in a company's strong innovative leaders and Sean fits that bill, he's an awesome guy.

But what we love about this is they're delivering their snacks to you at your business. You know, we spend -- people are spending over eight hours a day at work and employers want to make sure that their employees have an opportunity to eat healthy while they're at work.

But one thing we love that I love to hear Sean speak about is the data that they're able to collect. When they send this box to you at work, what you're getting out of that Sean?

KELLY: Yes. In today's world it's so important to be able to continually iterate and innovate, right, especially if you're a big CPG company. So what we do is we go direct to the consumer, have a direct relationship with them at their most engage moments.

We collect consumer insights and data that we see back o the brands so they can better understand their customer and therefore improve their products. We also use all that data to determine what emerging brands are going to win tomorrow. So we have a little bit of a predictive analytics engine that gives us a leg up in this business.

MCDOWELL: Do you sell that -- the new -- do you take that new data and sell it?

KELLY: We do. We sell that actually back to brands and there's also different ways for us to work with industry leaders and big CPGs to deliver some of that information to them.

MCDOWELL: So are you growing -- so this is direct to individuals but also companies.

KELLY: Absolutely. So we started on the enterprise, the reason that we started, we don't really look at B2B and B2C as being different. It's all about just where the consumer is and today's business --

MCDOWELL: Business-to-business and business-to-consumer.

KELLY: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: That's from -- that's from the first.com bubble by the way.

KELLY: Yes. Yes. Well that's the -- we like -- we like afternoons. But for us it's like, "Why did you -- why did start at the office? It's because it's where the younger generation spends the most time.

HARF: Yes.

KELLY: And so for us there's not that much difference. But being able to collect these insights and (INAUDIBLE) will have a forward-looking view in terms of what's going to work and what's not is really important.

MCDOWELL: But I attack this box like I hadn't eaten for the last five weeks and there -- we're immediately plant-base options in these boxes, not --

KELLY: Well based on a plan that's not going away

MCDOWELL: It's not -- you know, I don't eat any animal products at all. But it is -- but it goes to also.

If you're dealing with corporate customers, if they're trying to make their entire workforce healthy and keep their healthcare cost down, that's a huge selling point.

FORBES: It's nice with chocolate chip cookies that are healthy and taste like chocolate chip cookie.

HARF: We also have pizza too.

MURPHY: To wash down the pizza.

KELLY: Absolutely. Lenny & Larry's pack of protein, Steve, those are good for the guns, good for the biceps.

FORBES: I'm getting ready for the Olympics.

MURPHY: Sean, real quick, is there -- so with this platform, is there anything after snacks that could next for SnackNation?

KELLY: Yes. So we're actually setting this up as a platform where we can really deliver any consumer products through this. So even though our focus is on snacks, is in -- by the way, snacks can be anything.

Seventy percent Americans say that anything can be a snack as long as it's in a convenient format. And so we're already starting to plug health and beauty items and other items to our consumer insights final.

MCDOWELL: Here's a -- here's a tip --

FORBES: Wow. Sounds like a mini Amazon.

MCDOWELL: Right.

KELLY: Well.

MCDOWELL: Here's a -- here's a tip, cauliflower and cassava flour crackers, there you go, they're delicious.

KELLY: Love -- I love casara -- cassava, it's great for anti-inflammatory.

MCDOWELL: Yes, exactly. And Sean Kelly, great of you to be here. Please come back sir.

KELLY: Thanks so much, appreciate it.

MCDOWELL: Nice to see you.

KELLY: Thanks for having me.

MCDOWELL: The flood rat next.

MCDOWELL: I'd say thank you and so long to Marie, Mike, and the fabulous Steve Forbes and we hope that flood rat's OK. Stuart, take it away. It's all yours my friend.

VARNEY: Yes. Good morning flood rat, Dagen and all, good morning everyone. We are really close to yet another record high for the Dow Industrials.

Senate Republicans Participated In Faith And Freedom Coalition Capitol Hill Town Hall

June 27, 2019 11:30 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

SEN. MITCH MCCONNELL (R-KY.), MAJORITY LEADER

SEN. MIKE LEE (R-UTAH)

SEN. MARSHA BLACKBURN (R-TENN.)

SEN. JAMES LANKFORD (R-OKLA.)

SEN. JOSH HAWLEY (R-MO.)

FAITH AND FREEDOM COALITION DIRECTOR OF LEGISLATIVE AFFAIRS PATRICK PURTILL

FAITH AND FREEDOM COALITION EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR TIM HEAD

REP. MARK MEADOWS (R-N.C.)

FAITH AND FREEDOM COALITION CHAIRMAN RALPH REED

[*]BLACKBURN: Well, greetings, and how wonderful to see you all here instead of off campuses, as we say, which is where you usually are when I have joined you. And as I do each year, I want to first of all, say thank you to you for your interest and for your willingness to pay your own way here and attend a conference that is really going to shore you up and give you the information you need to talk to your friends and neighbors.

I was just talking to a reporter outside the room and he said, "Why is a conference like this important?" I said, "Let me tell you why. Fewer and fewer people believe what they hear on the evening news and they listen to it with skepticism and doubt. But you know who they do believe? They believe their neighbors and friends." And I bet if I asked for a show of hands, how many of you every day get an email, hear from a friend, go to church and somebody says, "Look at this that I read on the Internet. Is this true? What do you know about this?"

The most important name in news now is not ABC, which I still call them the All 'Bout Clinton News Network--

(LAUGHTER)

--or NBC, or CBS, or CNN, it is the Y-O-U, it is you and your circle of friends. That is who you're listening to. That is who they are listening to. They're listening to you. So I applaud you for being here. I thank you so much for your heartfelt interest. And I encourage you in getting the education that you need to help individuals know what is a constitutional, truthful vote, what is a constitutional, truthful position. And having them understand that, indeed, elections have consequences and who is in charge matters and who you're listening to makes a difference. I say Tommy Waller, if I want to know something about Israel I know who to call. And these are people that you rely on, because they are your friends. So thank you for that.

Now, what I thought I would do today, a little bit different from what I've talked with you about in past years, coming to the Senate, and you're going to get to hear from some of the senior senators who've been plowing away on issues here in the Senate, I thought I would recap for you what I think are the top 10 most important items that I have worked on since coming to the Senate, then I'm going to yield the floor to some of these other guys. But, you know, it's always good to hear from a good, solid, conservative woman first, right?

(APPLAUSE)

I tell my family all the time, "I'm the Chief Mama in Charge and what I say goes." So there you go.

The way I'm spending my time, the Title 10 Abortion Provider Prohibition Act, when I chaired the Select investigative panel, looking into what was happening with Planned Parenthood. One of the--you know, in the videos, and then we came up, figured out they were selling baby body parts, what we did was to put in place legislation that backs up what the President has done by executive order. It simply says this, "Title 10 funding will go to its stated statutory all purpose, which is to clinics that provide women's health care, and if you provide abortion services, you're not going to get that." So--

(APPLAUSE)

But the Title 10 Prohibition and the Protecting Life and Taxpayers Act, these two pieces of legislation, two of the first things that I did in coming to the Senate, because stating that we are, indeed, here to protect life and Liberty. Oh, yeah. What was that, the first thing? Life. So those are our first two--two things that we have worked on. Third, last month, I found the Campus Free Speech Resolution of 2019. This is--

(APPLAUSE)

--this is--you are so welcome. And I've talked with a lot of college students. You know, it's inconceivable to us that in this day and age that having diversity of thought would be considered to be harmful, and that students and professors are arguing about encouraging people to hear different points of view. So we have this, and it backs up many of our conservative--conservative groups.

The fourth thing, in Judiciary Committee we are doing hearings in addressing social media bias. And I am going to chair a working group in the Senate Judiciary Committee that will look at the issues of privacy, data security, antitrust, and online censorship. We think this--

(APPLAUSE)

It's important that we hold these online platforms accountable, and that they move away from subjectively manipulating those algorithms that boot out--that boot out conservative speech.

Number five, judicial confirmations. How do you like these new federal judges?

(APPLAUSE)

Isn't that great? So far, we have confirmed 123 federal judges, and in Judiciary Committee today, we moved for more out to go to the floor. So President Trump has set quite a record on this and we really--we really do support what he's doing.

Number six, defending Israel.

(APPLAUSE)

This is Senate Bill 1, passed early this year and item number seven on my list, fighting BDS.

(APPLAUSE)

And Senate Resolution 120.

Number eight, defending Christians in Sri Lanka, important that we weighed in on that.

(APPLAUSE)

Number nine is something we're continuing to work on even today, keeping maximum pressure on Iran--

(APPLAUSE)

--and making certain that we support the President when he put the sanctions in place. Iran's economy is beginning to crumble. And don't let anybody tell you this is a new problem; this has been going on since the 70s. And we know that Iran is the largest state sponsor of terrorism. And I thought it was interesting, The Washington Post even reported that Hezbollah was complaining that Iran had cut off some of their money flow, so Hezbollah couldn't carry out their bad deeds. So we're going to keep the pressure on.

And number 10 is one that we have just done today, the National Defense Authorization Act, making certain that our men and women in uniform have what they need to carry out the job that they're supposed to do.

Thank you all so much for letting me be with you.

(APPLAUSE)

PURTILL: Hello, everyone. I'm Patrick Purtill. I'm Director of Legislative Affairs for the Faith and Freedom Coalition and it is my distinct pleasure to introduce your next speaker. I think probably all of you will know him already, but let me say a few words.

U.S. Senator Mike Lee was first elected to the Senate in 2010, since then, he has been as he was before coming to the Senate, he's been a leader on all of the issues that we care about. He is a--he was an--an accomplished attorney in private practice, a Supreme Court litigator before he came here, so it's no surprise that he landed on the Senate Judiciary Committee, where you have probably seen him in some made for TV specials, like the Gorsuch hearings and the Kavanaugh hearings, which were all great sport.

He has been a leader on a number of issues here. He's a leader on pro-life issues. He's a leader on religious liberty issues here in the Senate. We have worked and have been particularly excited to work with him on a lot of criminal justice issues, which President Trump spoke about yesterday, and Matthew Charles, also spoke to you a little bit about the first step act and what--what that has accomplished. None of that, that act would not have been possible without Senator Lee's leadership on the committee, both his commitment to the issue and to fixing where their disproportionalities in the system, in the criminal justice system, the prison system, his commitment to that has been steadfast since he's been elected. But it was really not just his commitment to it, but his really smart approach to it, he made sure that it was a bipartisan bill, that it was able to come out of the Judiciary Committee, head to the--to the Senate floor, and ultimately, to President Trump's desk. So please--please join me in welcoming Senator Mike Lee.

(APPLAUSE)

LEE: Thank you. I never ever get people standing for me when I enter a room in this town. So this is unusual for me.

(LAUGHTER)

When that happens, I look around And I think they must be applauding for someone else. It's so great to be back with you. I love this organization. I love each of you. I love what you do. I love even the name of the organization, the Faith and Freedom Coalition. These are two concepts that define America. And they're two things that cannot exist one without the other, you can't truly be free without faith, and you cannot truly exercise faith without freedom.

(APPLAUSE)

So in that respect, your organization does exactly what we as Americans do so well, balancing faith with freedom, making sure that they both exist, so that either can exist and when either can exist, so can the other. These are things that are easy to take for granted and sometimes people do take them for granted. But we have to remember, that for most of human history, prior to America's founding, a free conscience was not seen as a fundamental, unmitigated good, it was seen, rather, as a threat.

From ancient tribes, to modern empires, governments saw fit to subject the City of God to the City of Man. This state decided, in most instances, what consisted of acceptable religion and it punished whatever was not dissenters were punished and so we're worshippers of just about every stripe. Fortunately, our founders saw a better way. Fortunately, our--our founders envisioned America, the kind of America that we would later become, the kind of America that we still are, then that I hope we always will be. That is, as Americans we're great, not because of who we are, but because of what we do. You see, both faith and freedom are the consequence of a choice. We must choose every day of our lives to be free, we must choose every day of our lives to have faith.

(APPLAUSE)

So our founding fathers set up a system that would protect both. It was one of the things that they did that was so bold, and so brave, nearly two and a half centuries ago. I've talked for a long time and written extensively about our Constitution and recently, I came to believe that there's another document that's sometimes not appreciated as much as it should be, the Declaration of Independence. It's often been said--

(APPLAUSE)

Yes, I thank you. I'm glad there's some-- It sometimes has been said that the Constitution provides the frame for our freedom, the frame as in around a picture, the structure. But the picture itself is painted by the Declaration of Independence. It's one of the reasons why I recently wrote a book about the Declaration of Independence. It's called Our Lost Declaration. All 12 people who have read Our Lost Declaration have absolutely loved it.

(LAUGHTER)

I encourage you to become the 13th today.

But what they did when they sent their name to that document was, in fact, treason. It was an act of open resistance against not only their own king, their own country, but what was then the world's last standing and greatest superpower. They truly pledged their lives, their fortunes, and their sacred honor. We have to ask ourselves from time to time, why did they do it? Was it worth it? They did it, of course, because of their love of their fellow beings. They recognized what I hope each and every one of us will always be willing to recognize, that is the eternal worth and immortal, immeasurable import of every human soul, that having been created in the image of God, we are entitled to be treated with respect and dignity, and we must treat each other that way every day.

(APPLAUSE)

One of my favorite Frenchman of all times, Alexis de Tocqueville, understood that our religion, our belief in the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, even the Lord God, Jesus Christ, was the source of our strength. As he toured America and tried to explain why it is that the revolution had stuck here, why it is that it worked here, that why it was that we were allowed and able to be free and equally treated under a fair, just system of laws. He explained as follows, "Freedom regards religion as the companion in all its battles and all its triumphs as the very cradle of its infancy and the source of all its claims, because religion alone is the safeguard of morality and morality is the best ensures pledge for the survival of freedom."

(APPLAUSE)

We managed as a country to hold on to these emblems, these remembrances, these reminders of the fact that what makes us great is the choice we make every day to follow our God. It's been said, I believe by Winston Churchill, that, "We shape our buildings and then our buildings shape us."

As I take the time to give constituents from my state or around the country tours of this great building, I'm often drawn to a couple of pieces of artwork that often go unnoticed. Both were made by an Italian born immigrants to the United States who were hired on as artists for the decoration of the capital. One was by Enrico Causici, who made this great sculpture that often goes unnoticed. It currently stands in Statuary Hall, also known as the former House Chamber.

Liberty in the Eagle consists of a figure, I believe, representing liberty, with her right arm outstretched holding a scroll, most likely representing the Constitution. To her right is an eagle, representing farseeing vision and--and strength. To her left is a fasces, a bundle of sticks representing E Pluribus Unum, representing the fact that we're greater we're stronger than the sum of our parts. Normally, a fasces is held together by leather straps, by ropes, or by cords of some sort. In this instance, the fasces is held together by a snake.

I was alarmed by the sculpture when I first got here, I didn't know what to make of it, until someone explained to me a hypothesis that perhaps, maybe just maybe, this is channeling the words of Jesus from Matthew Chapter 10, verse 16, admonishing Jesus's followers to be wise as serpents, but harmless as doves. You see, we have to trust and love your neighbor, but also cut the cards. Could it have been that the founders of our great country, including those who adorned its public buildings in the early part of our Republic, understood this great truth, that the Republican form of government, any form of government that recognizes is freedom, and protects and professes the right to believe in Almighty God as each person deems appropriate, is itself wonderful and very fragile, is at once the source of our strength, and our biggest potential vulnerability?

Another one of these sculptures represented the same thing can be found at the opposite end of the building, I'm a senate wing in something called the Brumidi Corridor. The artists there, Constantino Brumidi, displays a cherub surrounded on one side by a snake, and the other side by a dove. We have to remember the important choice to be wise as serpents, but harmless as doves every single day.

(APPLAUSE)

And so I hope we can choose every day to maintain the strength of our Republic, to do so by choosing virtue, by making the choice between right and wrong and choosing to interact with each other in a way that properly reflects all of Jesus' teachings, including those to love one another.

(APPLAUSE)

I bear testimony that God lives, that He is aware of and loves each and every one of us, that Jesus is the Christ, that He, in fact, died for us, that He paid the price for our sins, that He suffered for all humanity so that we might be free and we might return to live with him once again. I bear that testimony in the name of Jesus Christ. Amen.

(APPLAUSE)

HEAD: So we'll let--another day we'll have Senator Lee, the constitutional expert explain why someone like that is legally allowed to say something like that in a building like this.

(LAUGHTER)

So this--hopefully, this is--this is encouraging to you. It's informational. It's--its current, I mean, literally off of the senate floor.

(APPLAUSE)

The--you know, like--like Senator Blackburn alluded to earlier, we do it in a hotel, large crowd, big stage and stuff, but we--we really--I really love having this--this element, because I--I think that it--not only does it allow us to be able to come into our capital, but honestly, it allows elected officials, like you just heard, to kind of lay it out right here in--in front of--of everybody, that this is--this is who we are, this is what we believe, this is what we stand for and--and we're not checking--checking that at the door, right.

(APPLAUSE)

So speaking of not checking anything at the door, any Oklahomans, family--family, friends of Oklahomans? We got an Oklahoman on the front row over here. So that--that is God's country. And this is hard--hard as a--as a native Texan for me to--to say this, but God's country, but it's easier for me to say because he's married to a former Baylor Bear.

And as you heard earlier, when I talked about Dr. Paul, the--the--I think one of the Clarion voices in American politics on these issues is our next speaker, background as a minister that I--I think I'll tell you a little bit about, but he has influenced, truly influenced the lives of an entire generation of Oklahomans, really, throughout the Midwest for that matter. But--but he was a--he worked in youth ministry for years and years. And--and after interacting, literally, with hundreds of thousands over the years of high school and college students, Senator Lankford realized that the--that the time is now, and the calling is here to--to come to Washington.

Several years ago, as a member of the United States House of Representatives, James Lankford moved in and became a staunch and reliable voice on these issues and the last couple of years, he's taken that voice across Capitol Hill into the Senate. So would you join me in welcoming our friend, Senator James Lankford, from Oklahoma?

(APPLAUSE)

LANKFORD: Well, see. No need to stand and clap and just unless you need to stand in stretch.

(LAUGHTER)

Be able to go.

\So let--me let me clarify something on this God's Country issue. In Oklahoma, we have more barbecue restaurants in Oklahoma than any other state in America per capita.

(APPLAUSE)

Okay, so I--I--I--lots of other folks say they have great barbecue and I--I--I'm, "Okay, fine. Come eat ours and you'll know the difference." But I--I--I joke with folks all the time that as--as you read through the Old Testament, it always talks about the sweet aroma of the sacrifice coming up. And I always say that even God likes the smell of barbecue.

(LAUGHTER)

So it is--it is--it is one of those things that is always special for--

My--my background is as he was mentioning, it was in ministry. I was 22 years in ministry, and served in youth ministry, and depending on your background with your own personal youth minister, to know that a youth pastor is a senator either encourages you or terrifies you, probably--

(LAUGHTER)

--Depending on your own personal relationship with your youth pastor.

I never expected to be in Congress. This was not in our life plan. This is what my wife calls life's greatest interruption. But in 2008, my wife and I, separately, since God calling us to be able to run for Congress, and we spent about seven months telling God what a really insane idea that was. And saying over and over again, "That's not rational. That's not possible," Because I was a voter, I was engaged in the issues, I was passionate about what was happening in our country, but I spent all my time working with students.

I directed what--some of you may have heard of the False Creek Youth Camp, I was the director of the False Creek Youth Camp. It's the largest Christian camp in America. We have 5,000 students a week there. It is a very unique place to be able to do ministry. And if you're in youth ministry and you have the opportunity to be able to work with 51,000 students a summer you take that. And that's my joy to be able to do that.

(APPLAUSE)

But in 2008, and 09, God was very clear with us to say, "I want you to do something different." And honestly, when we started bragging about it, I really thought this was going to be an--an Isaac/Abraham kind of moment, that God was going to say, "Be faithful and pray about it, go up to Mount Moriah, but at the end, there's the ram, you don't have to kill your career."

(LAUGHTER)

But we got to Mount Moriah and he said, "No kill it. We're going to do something different." And at the end of that, we finally had to get to the point to say, "I'm going to be an old man one day telling my grandchildren about the time I didn't follow God. This is what God is calling us to do and I don't know why, but we're going to go do it."

Now, I tell you that story because it's not about us, it's about what God has done. But I'm also convinced that I meet people all the time, that they say, "My family doesn't have any background in politics. I don't have any background in politics. I don't have any money, like all these other folks do. There's no way that I can ever get involved in that, but God."

AUDIENCE: But God.

(APPLAUSE)

LANKFORD: So my simple statement to some of you, some of you are here because you're grassroots activists, and you're excited about helping someone else and what you're really doing is disobeying God, because he's telling you not to help someone else, he's telling you to do it, and you're short circuiting what he's calling you to do. Complete what he's calling you to do. Now, I can't call you, that's not my responsibility. But some of you are not supposed to be helping, you're supposed to be doing, you're supposed to be on the school board, you're supposed to be on the city council--

(APPLAUSE)

--you're supposed to be engaged in these issues. I don't know what that is for you. But I would encourage you to not be afraid to follow where God leads you.

(APPLAUSE)

Don't be afraid to go there.

I have folks all the time that say, "I'm grateful that there are good people that are in Washington, DC, because they'll change the country." I will typically smile at them and say politely, "Washington doesn't change the country, the country changes Washington. That's how it works."

(APPLAUSE)

So the grassroots activists, the people that are engaged in the issues that are actually changing the culture, and that's the family, and the church, and the communities, and the nonprofits that are actually changing culture and engaging, that moves slowly to DC, and it moves slowly out of DC. So the transitions that we need to see in DC 10 years from now will happen because churches, and communities, and families are engaging in their local communities now and that will slowly make it. What's happening in DC right now, culturally, is a result of what happened in our country 10 years ago. What would you like to see DC like 10 years from now? Transition your communities, engages the church, activate and real dialogue and conversation, and that's what DC will be like 10 years from now. It takes some time. But that's actually the way that it actually moves.

Now, there are a lot of critical issues we're working on right now that are exceptionally important to us, those of us who believe in basic freedom, and not everyone up here does. One of my colleagues just two weeks ago made a public statement to say people that are pro-life are like racist and anti-Semites, there's no place for them in America.

AUDIENCE: Wow.

LANKFORD: And when she made a statement that pro-life individuals, that there is no place for them in America because they're like racists and anti-Semites, she laid down a gauntlet to say, "This is what we believe. We're going to do whatever we can do to silence those of you that believe in the value of children. We will make sure that your voice does not get out there." Because I can't imagine anything worse in America than racism, antisemitism, and children, can you? It's a really odd list to be in, isn't it? For those of you that love the life of a child, to be considered as the group that there is no place for them anymore in America. The way that turns around is not a vote, that's heart issue and that's the engagement that well have to do culturally in conversations.

Right now on--on university campuses, and all this fall, there will be students standing and screaming in the face of people that they disagree with because they disagree with them and they're going to work to silence their voice to make sure they cannot speak. It's a cultural issue. That's an engagement about what is right and what's wrong and what we value. We turn that around, not with a vote, we turn that around with individual engagement. Now, there are things like judges that we can work on here. We've got to be able to get good judges in place, people that actually read the law, and crazy enough, follow the law. I know that's a radical concept to some.

We've got to get great judges in place and we're working on that. In fact, the Senate reached a point just a few months ago, that we reached the boiling point to say, "We're going to actually change the rules of the Senate," and I had the joy of leading the effort to be able to shift the rules in the Senate because my Democratic colleagues were blocking every good judge that was coming through and so we shifted the rules of the Senate to say, "It doesn't matter who this judge is, if they are qualified we need to be able to move them through." And we have doubled the number of judges that we're doing now in this basis now, to be able to accelerate that.

(APPLAUSE)

That is exceptionally important for us to be able to do, because we're not looking for judges with a certain opinion, other than their opinion is the law, follow that. We're not looking for certain bias, we're not looking for certain preference towards our point of view, just follow the law and we'll try to do the same. It's the most basic aspect that we can do in culture. Now, there's lots of things that we can work on, they provide religious liberty, and they provide engagement, our community, but there is no substitute for us engaging with our neighbors.

So let me just say this thing to you, thank you for coming here and for encouraging members of Congress and our staff in the test that we're doing, because seeing you is an encouragement to us to be able to keep going, to be able to know there's people in my state in Oklahoma, God's country, as you've already heard--

(LAUGHTER)

--that are passionate about trying to do the right thing the right way. But it's good to know there's folks from all over the country that are also doing that. But again, there is no substitute for just having that dialogue at home, with family, with friends, with neighbors, and not having an expectation that if I elect somebody, they'll go do my job. I have a job, so do you. Let's go follow God together, and to see how we can serve our country and our neighbors, and to see where this takes us in the days ahead. Is that I can deal with you? Let's go do it together. Thanks for engaging.

(APPLAUSE)

REED: Now, if--if you ever, for even a second, think that what you do, to pray and work, to see God glorified in the Civic arena, if you think it doesn't make a difference, I want you to think about what you just heard. It makes a difference. I can tell you, when I came here to Washington and worked in the Senate, I'm not going to say how many years ago it was, 37--

(LAUGHTER)

--there wasn't anybody in the Senate like him. And now I think it would be fair to say there are a good number.

LANKFORD: There are several, yeah.

REED: And we are--we are fortunate to have a man like this in the U.S. Senate fighting for us every single day.

(APPLAUSE)

And it is--it is a bit of a cliche to say doing the Lord's work in the Devil City, but in this case, it applies.

LANKFORD: It is true, yeah.

REED: And he has generously agreed to stay and take a few questions. So anybody have a question for Senator Lankford? I think we're getting handheld mics right here. Patrick, we have one right here.

LANKFORD: This is my moment as a pastor, I get to say, yes, I see that hand. I see that hand.

(LAUGHTER)

Yes, yes, yes, I see that hand.

QUESTION: Yeah. Thank you so much Senator Lankford. Roman Buhler with Madison Coalition.

President Trump talked in his inaugural address about taking power out of Washington and giving it back to the people. What are some of your ideas about how we can take power out of Washington permanently and give it back to the States and the people?

LANKFORD: So it is a great challenge, because the Executive Branch, over the decades, has been given authority by Congress and the Executive Branch only gives that authority up if the Executive Branch chooses to. Because once the Executive Branch has the power, you have to have a vote of the House, Senate, and the signature of a president to take it away. That's the catch. It's a easy to give power away, it is very difficult to be able to take it back.

So here's what President Trump is actively doing right now, he's working on the regulatory side, he made a commitment to say for every one new regulation that goes in, two are going to come out. Why is that significant? He's not trying to create chaos in the country, he's trying to say we're over managed as a country, where there's a federal bureaucrat trying to look over our shoulder on everything.
