I--you know I kept saying that the president can't back up. He's got to do this and I'm just hitting it very hard and I--I get in the car we go.

My wife had been waiting in the car and we go and we're starting to get back to our apartment, which is about 25 minutes away from the White House. And my phone rings and it's Reince Priebus and he says, "Mark where are you mark where you?" And I said, "Well I'm--I'm actually almost back to the apartment." He says, "Can you turn around and come tell the president what you touch told us?"

Now, my first thought is you work for the president. You tell him because I had been a little passionate and I said, "Sure." So, I--I--I wasn't quite there yet. So, I stop the car and I asked my wife, my godly wife of almost 40 years if she would take a taxi to get back to the rest of the house.

(LAUGHTER)

She did. Well, I won't go any further. She did, she took a taxi. I turned around and I came back as we--we go in--I come in and I go into the Oval Office and I know this may come as a surprise to many of you, it was the first time I had ever been invited to the Oval Office because I had only been in Congress six years that Obama didn't invite me a whole lot.

(LAUGHTER)

I know that is a shock to many of you, but I--I went in and actually the President wasn't there. He was actually in a little side office that was off of the Oval Office. Where he was doing some reading and--and he said, "Mark my favorite Congressman. Come in." I was not his favorite congressman, but he was making me feel like I was his favorite Congressman. Come on in.

I come in and I start advocating and I'm passionate and I'm talking to the President and saying you know you need to do this, and you need to do that. But he kept noticing I kept getting distracted. I kept looking down. There was about a 12-inch block of wood right in front of the president that had a red button in the middle of it. So, I would talk to him and I would look down at this red button.

(LAUGHTER)

I'd talked to him a little bit more and I looked down at the red button. Finally, he goes it makes you nervous doesn't it?

(LAUGHTER)

I said, "Oh no, it doesn't make me nervous at all." And so, you know I'm passionate and I keep on and I'm going on a little bit. And so finally, he hits the red button. Well, my eyes get as big as silver dollars.

(LAUGHTER)

I'm looking from it--for incoming from anywhere you know and--and sure enough out of this door to my right, comes this Marine in full uniform and he sets a Diet Coke right there in front of the President of the United States.

(LAUGHTER)

(APPLAUSE)

True story. He said--I said, "Man, that's pretty neat." And he said, "Do you want to see it again to Mark" Swish. Boom. There was one for me.

(LAUGHTER)

(APPLAUSE)

So--so I'm there and--and I'm getting--and--and it dawns on me that here I am, this nobody from North Carolina, who never wanted to run for Congress, who felt the call from the Lord to run for the office, and who was obedient.

(APPLAUSE)

I hated speaking. I didn't want to speak. In fact, when I found that I was--I told my wife--I called my wife and I said I'm going to run for office. I feel like the Lord is telling me to do that. I got physically ill, had to pull over on the side of the road and throw up. That's how bad I didn't want it, and yet God will use each one of you if you'll just listen to that still small voice that is saying. "Will you engage"

And for all of you, You've--you've decided to engage, and I just went to applaud you. Do not grow weary in well doing, as I said before, because you are making a difference. Not just here in your states, not in the--not in the nation's capital, not in the United States, but you're making a difference in the world. And I share the rest of the story, as Paul Harvey used to say, "And the rest of the story." Now don't nod because if you nod, you're too old. Okay. You don't know what I'm talking about. You're going to go back in Google, right? You're going to Google it. All right.

But the rest of the story is this. I was there that particular day advocating with the President of the United States that what he should do is keep his promise to the American people and move the embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem and this president did exactly that.

(APPLAUSE)

He exactly that.

(APPLAUSE)

He is a promise keeping President.

(APPLAUSE)

And he deserves your applause and your prayers.

(APPLAUSE)

And your prayers.

(APPLAUSE)

So--so, I share that story to encourage you, just a little bit, because in the next room was a whiteboard with every single campaign promise he had made, when he had made it, and he was going down, checking off every one of those campaign promises. This President is a pro-life, promise keeping president and we need to be on our knees before our heavenly father praying for him each and every day.

(APPLAUSE)

Each and every day.

(APPLAUSE)

So, I will--I will close with this. Debbie and I need your prayers. I mean just bluntly that the battle is ongoing in each and every day. The enemy makes himself very know. You can maybe even feel it, sometimes in the city. The oppression that is really there. You can--you know you can cut it like a knife and yet we know--we know the Savior who has the power and the victory over death and the power and the victory over this city and I will tell you this, our God still reigns over the affairs of nations and we will never forget it.

(APPLAUSE)

God bless you.

(APPLAUSE)

Thank you, so much. I love you guys.

(APPLAUSE)

Thank you for loving me appreciate it.

(APPLAUSE)

God bless you, appreciate it. Thank you.

(APPLAUSE)

Up there in the cheap seats, thank you too, alright. God bless you.

(APPLAUSE)

HEAD: You can see why that energy translates to TV. Can't you?

(LAUGHTER)

So--so, yeah. There--there you have it. Day two, in the--in the books. Except we--I--we're actually working on a little--in case you haven't heard there are debates that are happening. A little bit last night, a little bit tonight.

And we're actually working on trying to finalize a room that anybody--everybody is more than--more than welcome to do your own thing, but--but later on in the night, tonight. We might actually have a little contingency unofficial things that if you want to watch you know a--a debates night with 1000 of your favorite friends--faith and--Faith and Freedom family friends, how are we going to--we'll--we'll send you an email.

Hopefully in like the next hour or so. It'll be over at the Omni Shoreham and--and--and I think--I think it's going to be in a room called the Empire Room. The debate I think starts tonight at like nine. So--so, we'll--we'll probably have to wrap it up a little bit before they finish because we ourselves have our own work to be done tomorrow morning.

But listen, thank you so much for being here this afternoon. Thank you for staying engaged. So, impressed. Had over 600 people, I think that came to this--this part of the program, after almost 1000 this morning. Over 1000 yesterday. Tomorrow--

AUDIENCE: Repeat that.

HEAD: Which part? For tonight?

AUDIENCE: Yes, repeat that.

HEAD: To--tonight if--if you're interested, we're going to try to get a--a--a little watch party for the debate at--at the Omni Shoreham probably in the Empire Room. The Empire Room. So, like maybe ask the concierge it's hard for me to describe without pointing to the map or whatever, but Empire Room is probably where we're going to be for--and we'll send an email sometime in the next you know probably hour and a half or so, at 9 PM.

And speaking of nine, tomorrow morning is when we'll officially get--get ready--ramped--ramped up again and we're going to have another great--tomorrow morning we're actually going to have several Members of the Cabinet. Four different Cabinet Officials are going to come and visit with us and--and then a couple of other members of Congress.

I would be remiss, our--one of our speaker's tomorrow morning is a--a Congressman by the name of Barry Loudermilk.

(APPLAUSE)

In order to have this room. This physical room. A Congressman and--and their staff actually have to--to physically--to like to facilitate that, and Rob Atkinson, who is of the Chief of Staff for Congressman Barry Loudermilk. He drew the short straw so to speak. No, I'm kidding. He--he--they actually help in many, many ways legislatively, but--but Rob is just a great friend to Faith and Freedom Coalition and--and so is Congressman Loudermilk.

And so, thank you, Rob Atkinson and thank you, Congressman Loudermilk's office, for helping to facilitate this great space.

(APPLAUSE)

And so, we--we have buses. The same five buses that--that will be going back to--to the--to the-- the hotels. So, if you can head back up where you came in. We have those five buses, otherwise you know if you can grab an Uber or we've got restaurants around here that you are welcome to help yourselves. Have a wonderful night, the rest of tonight and we'll look forward to either seeing you tonight unofficially or tomorrow morning at 9 o'clock at the Omni Shoreham. Thanks. Be blessed.

urn:contentItem:6059-SF01-JBCN-44N8-00000-00Senate Republicans propose Big Tech regulation overhaul2020-06-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:47ZLexisNexisPOLITICSSenate Republicans propose Big Tech regulation overhaulRyan Lovelace

Senate Republicans seek to strip protections shielding Big Tech companies from lawsuits unless the companies change their terms of service to agree to operate in good faith and to pay a $5,000 fine if they fail to live up to the agreement.

Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act has long afforded Big Tech companies shelter from legal liability from material posted by users on their platform.

The Limiting Section 230 Immunity to Good Samaritans Immunity Act was introduced by Sen. Josh Hawley, Missouri Republican, on Wednesday and had three GOP cosponsors: Sens. Mike Braun of Indiana, Tom Cotton of Arkansas, and Marco Rubio of Florida.

"For too long, Big Tech companies like Twitter, Google, and Facebook have used their power to silence political speech from conservatives without any recourse for users," Mr. Hawley said in a statement. "Section 230 has been stretched and rewritten by courts to give these companies outlandish power over speech without accountability. Congress should act to ensure bad actors are not given a free pass to censor and silence their opponents."

The proposal does not eliminate Section 230 protections completely, which some Big Tech allies have feared may still happen. Mr. Rubio said in a statement that he thinks Section 230 still serves an important purpose, but it should not be weaponized as a tool of political censorship and activism.

The Justice Department is also preparing to release a proposal of how it wants to limit Section 230. The department is looking to roll back civil immunity to tech companies across several different circumstances, including those that host third-party content involving online scammers and trafficking in illicit drugs, the Wall Street Journal reported.

The competing visions of Big Tech regulation have emerged in response to President Trump's recent social media executive order. Mr. Trump's order directed the Federal Communications Commission to draft regulation that could scrap legal liability protections for Big Tech companies if they censor or edit content online.

Mr. Trump's order also took aim at Section 230, which the president said was necessary to restore fairness online.

urn:contentItem:5VVM-85Y1-JB4M-V29B-00000-00Senate Republicans renew their claims that Facebook, Google and Twitter censor conservatives2019-04-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:47ZLexisNexisSenate Republicans renew their claims that Facebook, Google and Twitter censor conservativesTony Romm

Republicans led by Sen. Ted Cruz on Wednesday pilloried Facebook, Google and Twitter over allegations they censor conservative users and content online, threatening federal regulation in response to claims that Democrats long have described as a hoax and a distraction.

The tensions played out over more than three hours at a Senate hearing where Cruz, the leader of the Judiciary Committee's constitution-focused panel, pointed to reports that he said showed a "consistent pattern of political bias and censorship on the part of big tech."

"Not only does big tech have the power to silence voices with which they disagree, but big tech likewise has the power to collate a person's feed so they only receive the news that comports with their own political agenda," Cruz said.

But Democrats sharply rebuked Cruz and his GOP allies for convening the hearing in the first place. "For decades, Republicans have bashed the supposedly liberal mainstream media in an effort to work the refs," said Sen. Mazie Hirono (Hawaii). "Now that two-thirds of Americans get their news from social media, Republicans have a new boogeyman to target - big tech."

Hirono and her Democratic peers chided Republicans for ignoring the real ills of social media - including the rise of hate speech and disinformation online. And one of the witnesses Wednesday raised concerns that Facebook and Google hadn't been aggressive enough in the ways they police their platforms. Robbie Parker, a parent of a child killed during the 2012 shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School, said Facebook and Google-owned YouTube long had failed to stop conspiracy theorists and others from attacking him and his family.

"They systematically failed to protect us from harassment and threats," Parker told lawmakers, later adding: "Only when they realized it would tarnish their brand and affect them financially did they finally respond appropriately."

Conservatives long have claimed that major social-media sites exhibit political bias, pointing to Silicon Valley's liberal leanings and regular contributions to Democrats. Beyond that, however, experts have said there is no evidence that Facebook, Google and Twitter have deliberately sought to limit the reach of Republicans, a message that tech giants in attendance on Wednesday emphasized.

"The notion that we would silence any political perspective is antithetical to our commitment to free expression," said Carlos Monje, Jr., the director of Public Policy and Philanthropy for the U.S. and Canada at Twitter.

But tech executives' continued pledges to treat all political content equally have failed to sway the country's most prominent Republicans, including President Trump, who repeatedly has claimed that Facebook, Google and Twitter are biased against the party. In March, Trump accused the industry of harboring "hatred" for a "certain group of people that happen to be in power, that happen to have won the election."

As an example, Trump has pointed to his follower count on Twitter, which he said tends to fluctuate - a fact Twitter long has attributed to its efforts to shut down spam accounts on the platform. Still, Trump last month reiterated his threat for further scrutiny, telling reporters the government has to "do something about it."

Opening the Wednesday hearing, Cruz on detailed a series of potential regulatory steps Congress could consider, including rethinking a longstanding federal law that spares companies from being held liable for content posted by their users. Cruz said lawmakers didn't seek to serve as "government speech police," but he raised the potential for further antitrust scrutiny of the tech industry.

"By almost any measure the giant tech companies today are larger, and more powerful, than Standard Oil was when it was broken up," Cruz said. "And if we have tech companies using the powers of monopoly to censor political speech, I think that raises real antitrust issues."

Cruz and his peers pointed to instances in which Facebook and Twitter erroneously applied its policies to conservative content, resulting in pro-life ads or tweets being removed from those social-media sites. One of the tweets Cruz displayed and claimed had been "blocked" - from the president of Susan B. Anthony List - claimed that abortion is "profoundly anti-women," accompanied by a quotation from Mother Theresa. But a tweet from 2017 containing the same text and image still appeared on Twitter after a search Wednesday. A spokesman for Cruz did not immediately respond to request for comment about the tweet.

In another example, GOP Sen. Marsha Blackburn (Tenn.) highlighted a 2017 controversy in which one of her campaign ads had been briefly barred by Twitter. The company later said it had been a mistake - and repeated its apology Wednesday.

In doing so, Facebook and Twitter emphasized they had taken action in response to controversial content posted by Democrats and Republicans alike. "I can tell you we have actioned accounts on both sides of this debate," Monje said.

Absent from the Wednesday hearing was Google. The search giant, which owns YouTube, had been invited to testify, but Cruz rejected the company's witness. The GOP senator said he plans to hold a hearing, specifically focused on Google, in the coming weeks.

urn:contentItem:5YBS-NMW1-JC11-14VF-00000-00Senate Scheduled 18 Committee Hearings for March 42020-03-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:47ZLexisNexisSenate Scheduled 18 Committee Hearings for March 4Targeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The U.S. Senate scheduled 18 committee hearings for March 4, 2020.

Committee on Appropriations: Subcommittee on Department of Defense, to hold hearings to examine proposed budget estimates and justification for fiscal year 2021 for the National Guard and Reserve, 10 a.m., SD-138.

Subcommittee on Department of the Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies, to hold hearings to examine proposed budget estimates and justification for fiscal year 2021 for the Department of the Interior, 10 a.m., SD-124.

Subcommittee on Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, and Related Agencies, to hold hearings to examine proposed budget estimates and justification for fiscal year 2021 for the Department of Transportation, 10 a.m., SD-192.

Subcommittee on Energy and Water Development, to hold hearings to examine proposed budget estimates and justification for fiscal year 2021 for the Department of Energy, 2:30 p.m., SD-138.

Committee on Armed Services: Subcommittee on Emerging Threats and Capabilities, to hold open and closed hearings to examine the Department of Defense review of vetting policies for international military students following the attack on Naval Air Station Pensacola, 10 a.m., SR-232A.

Subcommittee on SeaPower, to hold hearings to examine Navy shipbuilding programs in review of the Defense Authorization Request for fiscal year 2021 and the Future Years Defense Program, 10 a.m., SR-222.

Full Committee, to hold hearings to examine the Department of Defense budget posture in review of the Defense Authorization Request for fiscal year 2021 and the Future Years Defense Program, 2:30 p.m., SH-216.

Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation: to hold hearings to examine 5G supply chain security, focusing on threats and solutions, 10 a.m., SR-253.

Subcommittee on Aviation and Space, to hold hearings to examine the role of global aviation in containing the spread of infectious disease, focusing on coronavirus, 2:30 p.m., SR-253.

Committee on Energy and Natural Resources: Subcommittee on Water and Power, to hold hearings to examine the impact of invasive species on Bureau of Reclamation facilities and management of water resources in the West, 10:30 a.m., SD-366.

Subcommittee on National Parks, to hold hearings to examine S. 1863, to require the Secretary of the Interior to conduct a special resource study of the sites associated with the life and legacy of the noted American philanthropist and business executive Julius Rosenwald, with a special focus on the Rosenwald Schools, S. 1910, to rename the Homestead National Monument of America near Beatrice, Nebraska, as the Homestead National Historical Park, S. 1969, to authorize the Fallen Journalists Memorial Foundation to establish a commemorative work in the District of Columbia and its environs, S. 2206, to express the sense of Congress regarding restoration and maintenance of the Mardasson Memorial in Bastogne, Belgium, S. 2340, to establish the Cahokia Mounds Mississippian Culture National Historical Park in the States of Illinois and Missouri, S. 2827, to amend title 54, United States Code, to establish within the National Park Service the U.S. African-American Burial Grounds Network, S. 2924, to establish the Bandelier National Park and Preserve in the State of New Mexico, S. 3098, to redesignate the Jimmy Carter National Historic Site as the "Jimmy Carter National Historical Park", S. 3119, to modify the boundary of the Casa Grande Ruins National Monument, S. 3121, to establish the Chiricahua National Park in the State of Arizona as a unit of the National Park System, S. 3265, to redesignate the Weir Farm National Historic Site in the State of Connecticut as the ``Weir Farm National Historical Park", S. 3331, to modify the boundary of the Rocky Mountain National Park, H.R. 182, to extend the authorization for the Cape Cod National Seashore Advisory Commission, and H.R. 1472, to rename the Homestead National Monument of America near Beatrice, Nebraska, as the Homestead National Historical Park, 2 p.m., SD-366.

Committee on Environment and Public Works: to hold an oversight hearing to examine the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, 10 a.m., SD-406.

Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs: to hold hearings to examine resources and authorities needed to protect and secure the homeland, 2:30 p.m., SD-342.

Committee on Indian Affairs: to hold hearings to examine S. 2610, to reauthorize certain programs under the Office of Indian Energy Policy and Programs of the Department of Energy, and S. 2891, to require the Secretary of the Interior to establish Tribal Wildlife Corridors, 2:30 p.m., SD-628.

Committee on the Judiciary: to hold hearings to examine the nominations of John Peter Cronan, to be United States District Judge for the Southern District of New York, Thomas T. Cullen, to be United States District Judge for the Western District of Virginia, and Jennifer P. Togliatti, to be United States District Judge for the District of Nevada, 10 a.m., SD-226.

Subcommittee on Crime and Terrorism, to hold hearings to examine big tech and Beijing, 2 p.m., SD-226.

Committee on Veterans' Affairs: to hold a joint hearing with the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs to examine the legislative presentation of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, 10 a.m., SD-G50.

Select Committee on Intelligence: to hold closed hearings to examine certain intelligence matters, 2 p.m., SH-219.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Senate scheduled five committee hearings for Nov. 5:

Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation: Subcommittee on Aviation and Space, to hold hearings to examine building NASA's workforce of the future, focusing on STEM engagement for a 21st century education, 2:30 p.m., SD-562.

Committee on Energy and Natural Resources: to hold hearings to examine the nominations of James P. Danly, of Tennessee, to be a Member of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, and Katharine MacGregor, of Pennsylvania, to be Deputy Secretary of the Interior, 10 a.m., SD-366.

Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs: to hold hearings to examine threats to the homeland, 2:30 p.m., SH-216.

Committee on Judiciary: Subcommittee on Crime and Terrorism, to hold hearings to examine how corporations and Big Tech leave our data exposed to criminals, China, and other bad actors, 2:30 p.m., SD-226.

Select Committee on Intelligence: to receive a closed briefing on certain intelligence matters, 2:30 p.m., SH-219.

urn:contentItem:5TVP-8M01-JCMN-Y1JX-00000-00Senate Subcommittee Evaluates Expansion Of The FTC's Data And Privacy Authority2018-11-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:47ZLexisNexisSenate Subcommittee Evaluates Expansion Of The FTC's Data And Privacy AuthorityCozen OConnor

Nov 30, 2018( JD Supra: http://www.jdsupra.com Delivered by Newstex) On November 27, 2018, the U.S. Senate Subcommittee on Consumer Protection, Product Safety, Insurance, and Data Security held a hearing titled 'Oversight of the Federal Trade Commission,' which included testimony from Chairman Joseph Simons and Commissioners Rohit Chopra, Noah Phillips, Rebecca Slaughter, and Christine Wilson. The hearing examined a range of topics within the purview of the FTC, but of particular importance to privacy professionals was the discussion of whether the FTC should have expanded authority over privacy and data security.

The hearing followed two Subcommittee hearings on the creation of a federal privacy law, which Senator Moran (R-KS) noted was necessary in the wake of several large-scale data incidents and in light of the 'implementation of the General Data Protection Regulation ('GDPR') in Europe, and the recent passage of the California Consumer Privacy Act [('CCPA')].' Senator Blumenthal (D-CT), echoing the need for a federal privacy law, stated that '[the U.S.] need[s] to do it not only because Europe has done it, not only because California has done it, but [because] these rules are long overdue' and that congress must '[p]rovide the FTC with the resources[,] expertise and structure to enforce the rules [and] establish meaningful penalties on first offenses to pose a credible deterrent . . . .' In working toward a bipartisan federal privacy law, the Subcommittee was specifically interested in input from the Commissioners on what should be included in the law as well as any additional tools the FTC would need to enforce it. Although little testimony was given on specific aspects of what should be included in the law, there appeared to be a consensus among the Commissioners that the FTC needs (1) direct authority to asses civil penalties, (2) authority over non-profits and common carriers for which there is currently an exemption, and (3) rulemaking authority under the Administrative Procedure Act. In predicting what may be to come from the FTC in light of growing privacy concerns, Chairman Simons indicated that the FTC may use its Section 6(b) power under the FTC Act—which empowers the FTC to require an entity to file 'annual or special . . . reports or answers in writing to specific questions'—to investigate big tech companies such as Amazon, Apple, Facebook, and Google regarding what consumer information is being collected and how that information used, shared, and sold. Privacy professionals should continue to monitor the development of a federal U.S. privacy law and should keep an eye on potential FTC investigation efforts into big tech as the discussion develops and continues.

Tech Copyright Reforms; Facebook Removes Fake Accounts; U.S.-China Trade; Federal Reserve Rate Hikes; May Faces New Pressure2019-03-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:47ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTJon Steinberg, Kyle Bailey, Daniel Ives, Michael SonnenfeldtNEWSFinancial032701cb.231Senate Subcommittee Holding Hearing On Aviation Safety This Afternoon; Strong Demand For Lyft IPO; Green New Deal Procedural Vote Fails In Senate; AppleQualcomm Legal Battle; E.U. Tech Copyright Reforms; Facebook Removes Fake Accounts; U.S.-China Trade; Federal Reserve Rate Hikes; May Faces New PressureDagen McDowell, Maria Bartiromo, Richard Fowler, Lauren Simonetti, Ashley Webster

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Thank you -- thank you so much. Good morning, everyone. I'm Maria Bartiromo, happy Wednesday. It is Wednesday, March 27th, your top stories right now 6:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast. Safety in the sky, this morning, the Senate is holding a hearing today following the two deadly Boeing crashes, what to expect from that transportation hearing, as the 737 Max makes an emergency landing in Florida.

Racing toward an IPO, Lyft reportedly seeing strong demand this morning as well. The price shares above the range last night, the details ahead of Friday's opening trade. And Green No Deal, the controversy plan -- controversial plan from Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez failed in the Senate yesterday. One Senator going viral for the posters that he used to slam that deal. Plus, $750 million up for grabs tonight, that's the big Powerful drawing. MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And Futures are searching for direction this morning, we are looking at a lower opening for the broader averages, but fractionally. Dow Industrials down about 45 points right now, S&P 500 down two, and the NASDAQ down one.

Our top story this morning, lawmakers are focusing on aircraft safety this afternoon with a Senate Commerce subcommittee on aviation and space. That hearing is following the deadly crashes of the Boeing 737 Max 8 jet. This, as the same model aircraft made an emergency landing in Florida yesterday after a reported engine problem. Joining me right now is former FAA safety team representative and pilot, Kyle Bailey, is here. Kyle, great to have you on the program.

KYLE BAILEY, SAFETY TEAM REPRESENTATIVE, FAA: Good morning, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. Tell us what you think is most important in the hearing today in terms of looking at this 737 jet?

BAILEY: You know, I think as far as the FAA goes and with Boeing with the certification process, it really should be scrutinizing relationship they have, the two of them, if they're a little bit complacent, because Boeing really does a good job at the certification process. And it will be interesting to see when they investigate, you know, how the two are working together, and are they a little bit too complacent?

BARTIROMO: I see. Because Boeing unveiled a software update today to fix this problem, and I guess it's the automated system, it was thought to have caused the 737's nose to tilt down in last October's Lion Air crash. Can you explain a little about that and what the issue is?

BAILEY: So, the system -- the software update, what that -- what that will do is there's an angle of attack indicator on the airplane. One sensor was feeding into that, or one, you know, of the actual -- on the exterior of the airplane. Now, two of those are going to feed into that sensor. So, if one malfunctions, there will still be another one that is giving input. So, there will be two in place of one. Also, as far as that nose, the system pushing the nose down to make the airplane descend in a potential stall situation, the system will only do that a couple of times. So, it will not be like the pilot will be struggling over and over and over again like, you know, what might have been the case previously.

BARTIROMO: How significant is this for Boeing? I mean, obviously, you're going to talk about major lawsuits coming at the company. But do you think that this is a major problem for the business and for how it may have to redirect itself?

BAILEY: Well, you know, keep in mind, Boeing isn't just in airplanes, they're also in the defense business, but as far as the airplane business goes, I mean, I think --

BARTIROMO: It's an important product.

BAILEY: Yes. And the passengers, in general, are you know, typically fearful of flying for the most part. You know, they really have to build, you know, passenger confidence. And it'll be very interesting to see how they do that.

BARTIROMO: How can they do it?

BAILEY: You know, it's hard. I mean, they really just have to tell everybody what they're doing and prove everything. And, you know, test this airplane, test the new software to make sure everything is doing what it should be doing. So, now, you know, we've had two crashes already. I mean -- so, they're going to do the software fix. I mean, they really have to, you know, go out of their way to prove this to the general flying public that this stuff really does work.

BARTIROMO: To really communicate that they are on the -- on the issue. I'm worried about the FAA. I mean, does it surprise you that the U.S. was really the last of -- you know, in the globe in terms of grounding this jet?

BAILEY: Well, the FAA is very bureaucratic, but I have to say they do a fine job at what they do. And they typically work on the facts and statistics, so they really don't care about media pressure, they don't care about pressure from the public. I think this -- you know, incident might have changed things, but in general, they're pretty much facts and data- driven when they make decisions. So -- but this would be the exception, though.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will leave it there. Kyle, it's great to have you, thanks so much.

BAILEY: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thanks for your insights on that. Kyle Bailey there. Meanwhile, IPOs are in focus, big year, Lyft reportedly will price its stock above the range, ahead of its IPO. Dagen McDowell with more on that. Good morning, Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. Lyft- off, let's call it. So, Lyft is on its IPO road show at the moment, marketing the shares to potential investors, and it's been standing-room- only crowds, according to The Wall Street Journal. The targeted range previously talked about was between $62.00 and $68.00 a share, and now it is expected to price above that level. The Wall Street Journal says it's unlikely to be as high as $80, more likely to be in the low 70s. Nevertheless, Lyft will be valued at more than $23 billion on a fully- diluted basis when it goes public.

Here's one of the interesting things, so most of the big private companies have large shareholders, mutual fund companies that already owned shares privately. Lyft, not so much, with the exception of Fidelity Investments. So, there's a lot of demand there from mutual fund companies, potentially for this IPO because they don't have a stake in the company before it goes public. One concern is its profitability. You're looking at some of the major IPOs to watch.

This is a good sign for, say, Pinterest, Uber that will follow Lyft. And investors have told The Wall Street Journal, their concern is profitability, the path to profitability. Lyft last year lost $911 million. That was one of -- it was the biggest of any U.S. start-up in the 12 months preceding its IPO, the biggest lost there. But nevertheless, people are interested in this company, Maria.

And by the way, we talked about LEVI, LEVI is still trading. It went public, it was priced at $17.00 a share, it's trading at 22 bucks, that's a gain of 29 percent.

BARTIROMO: Yes, just in a couple of days, that was real successful. And how about Uber, what is its valuation? $120 billion or something on Uber.

MCDOWELL: A lot of upside here because Lyft is going to -- is promising that it's going to reduce its costs dramatically, reducing its insurance costs as it builds scale, so that's what they're telling investors about the path to profitability.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll keep talking about that. See you in a bit, Dagen, thank you. Meanwhile, prosecutors are facing backlash this morning after dropping all charges against actor Jussie Smollett. Lauren Simonetti with those details now and headlines. Lauren, what a story.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Maria, wow! Chicago's mayor and police chief both raising questions about why Smollett was not held accountable for allegedly faking a racist, anti-gay attack on himself to gain attention for his acting career. Prosecutors say they dropped the charges after Smollett agreed to let the city keep its $10,000 in bail and to perform community service. But Smollett may not be out of the woods just yet. An investigation into a death threat letter the actor supposedly received prior to the alleged attack has been handed over to the FBI.

Take a look at this, shares of FiatChrysler trading sharply higher, up 3- 1/2 percent in the premarket. London's Financial Times is reporting that the company could be a takeover target once Renault restarts merger talks with Nissan, that in the coming months. The newspaper says the move is a new strategy following the arrest of former Renault CEO and former Nissan Chairman Carlos Ghosn on financial misconduct charges. Ghosn, of course, has denied any wrongdoing.

And it might be your lucky day, your chance to turn two bucks into 750 million. Tonight's Powerball jackpot, the fourth largest in history if someone picks the lucky numbers. They'll get a lump sum of $466 million before taxes. We always like to let you know your odds, your odds of winning, 1 in 292 million. There is a chance, Maria.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Lauren. All right, quick break. And then, coming up, Green No Deal, Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's controversial Green New Deal fails test vote in the Senate yesterday as one Senator's poster against it goes viral. We'll tell you about that one. And then, battle of the drones, UPS is rolling out the first revenue-generating drone deliveries, beating out competition from Amazon and FedEx, much more on that when we come right back. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Big program this morning, coming up. Georgia Senator, member of the Senate Budget Banking, and Armed Services, and Agricultural Committees, David Perdue is with us this morning. Tennessee Senator and a member of the subcommittee on Aviation and Space, Marsha Blackburn is here, she's going to be at that transportation hearing today. Former adviser to President George W. Bush, Fox News Contributor Karl Rove joining us. Along with the author of "The Coming Collapse of China," author Gordon Chang is with us, as U.S. officials head to Beijing -- oh, they are in Beijing already for another round of trade talks. And Fox News Senior Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. Family Medicine doctor, Mikhail Varshavski, "Dr. Mike" is here. Breakout of measles to talk about with Mike. You don't miss a moment of it.

Meanwhile, the Green New Deal was denied yesterday. The Senate voted 57-0 against a procedural motion to take up the resolution. Most Democrats voted present to protest the GOP's action. A fiery response by freshman Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez to push back from Congressman Sean Duffy. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. SEAN DUFFY (R), WISCONSIN: The Green New Deal is one that if you're a rich liberal from maybe New York or California, it sounds great because you can afford to retrofit your home or build a new home that has zero emissions, that's energy efficient, affordable and safe.

REP. ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ (D), NEW YORK: You want to tell people that their concern and their desire for clean air and clean water is elitists? Tell that to the kids in the South Bronx which are suffering from the highest rates of childhood asthma in the country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining the conversation this morning, the founder and CEO of Cheddar, Jon Steinberg is here, along with New Leaders Senior Fellow, Fox News Contributor, Richard Fowler. Dagen McDowell, that was some hearing yesterday on the Green New Deal, it looked like theatrics more than anything else. How did you see them?

MCDOWELL: I will not throw shade at a lady who can rock a red lip and uses her hands like that.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: I kid. This is interesting. And my takeaway from just that comment from Congresswoman Ocasio-Cortez when she was talking about -- she was talking about the dirty -- the water problems in Flint, Michigan and the South Bronx. She is not pointing to something that the Green New Deal would necessarily fix. She's pointing to problems that occur, say, in the South Bronx, this is one of the most socialist cities in the nation, where you have great government control and extremely high taxes, and you still have appalling conditions that people are living in. With the Flint water crisis, again, this is something that the government did not prevent and did not stop. So if she thinks that government is the solution, she just gave two examples of the government being the problem.

BARTIROMO: Yes. What do you think, Richard?

RICHARD FOWLER, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Listen, I think the Green New Deal was a -- is a framework, right? Like I said, I don't think it's the perfect solution but here lies the problem. So we saw -- and I'm pretty sure we'll show the clip later of Utah Senator Mike Lee showing all these pictures of -- I think Ronald Reagan sitting on top of --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Let's take a look at this because that was Senator Mike Lee yesterday and it went viral. His posters which slammed the Green New Deal. Here is one example.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. MIKE LEE (R), UTAH: I rise today to consider the Green New Deal with the seriousness it deserves. This is a picture of Aquaman, a superhero from the undersea kingdom of Atlantis. I draw your attention, Mr. President, to the 20-foot impressive seahorse he's riding. Under the Green New Deal, this is probably Hawaii's best bet.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: It is pretty funny.

FOWLER: It is funny and I'm pretty sure the Kinkos stocks should be going through the roof right now because he made a lot of -- he spent a lot in printing. But here is the truth is that both the United Nations, the Congressional report, the fact is that climate change is a real thing, right? And I think what we have on one side is the Green New Deal, I'm not saying it's the best solution but on the other side you have folks likes Senator Mike Lee saying that climate change, nothing to see here, nothing is happening and I think that is part of the problem.

MCDOWELL: Mitch McConnell didn't know. Mitch McConnell actually is now on the record as saying I'm talking about climate change.

(CROSSTALK)

FOWLER: They haven't given any solutions and I think the solution exist sometimes in the middle when Democrats, Republican, businesses come together and say, OK, we have a problem here and that's actually trying to figure out some real solutions because the real problems like Super Storm Sandy flooding.

BARTIROMO: It's a nice thing to say that this is just a framework but it actually -- it is legislation that she would like to bring to the -- that she would like to see materialize, so it's not just a framework.

JON STEINBERG, CEO & FOUNDER, CHEDDAR: But to your point, Maria, it's basically nonexistent on facts right now.

BARTIROMO: Right.

STEINBERG: No one actually knows what's in the Green New Deal, the world is ending in 10 years, apparently it's causing asthma in New York City. But what we've seen here is the politicians level of marketing skill has completely evolve. I think largely as a result of President Trump, we have people now that know how to message, know how to use gimmicks, you've got presentations skills from somebody like AOC that are spectacular.

The way she presents, the way she speaks and we're entering sort of an area where this is what's going to define, you know, the movements that happened in this country. This socialism thing is unbelievably dangerous whether it's the Green New Deal or the pied-a-terre tax or the -- under the real estate kill tax basically in New York City. This kind of stuff is going to make things happen.

MCDOWELL: The Green New Deal proposes explicitly retrofitting every house in America. This is the Wall Street Journal's editorial today. And eliminating fossil fuels within a decade. That is higher energy cost, it will hurt lower-income Americans more than anyone else and our standard of living as a nation will suffer and they have to answer to that. Instead all of these yesterday, Democratic presidential candidates voted present. The Journal is calling it profiles and present which is hilarious.

BARTIROMO: So, it's -- that's the thing, I mean, you could say, yes, climate change is an issue, she could have just said that but to come up with this whole plan that is specific in terms of getting rid of fossil fuels in the next 10 years doesn't make any sense and that's why they're --

(CROSSTALK)

FOWLER: Yes. I mean, I think the -- but the truth of the matter here is that her plan sits on one side and on the opposite side of the aisle there is nothing, there is no plan, there is zero, there is an empty box, right? And I think if you look at -- if you look at recent polls you will see millennials in the Republican side are saying climate change is real and their party doesn't have an answer to that.

MCDOWELL: Well, the answer will be is that a carbon-free future is one -- is it creates a nation that you don't want to live in.

FOWLER: But that's not coming from the President or the party.

MCDOWELL: But you -- and also well, they -- we talk about it endlessly on this program and it is private industry that has not only lowered our emissions --

STEINBERG: Absolutely, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: -- with the use of natural gas, it is private industry and getting out of the way of using and developing and discovering in a new way those very fossil fuels that are plentiful in this country that keep people's energy costs down.

BARTIROMO: So there is a plan and Corporate America has been executing that plant --

(CROSSTALK)

STEINBERG: Look at the electric car move, you know, we can -- you know, we all, you know, punch at Elon Musk for his craziness all day long. He's done more to affect, you know, hybrid and electric vehicles in this country than any amount of legislation, any amount of tax credits. He just --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: I forgot throw punches at Elon Musk although I think he's been a jerk in the past, I think that this is -- he ultimately by creating a cool car, he will get more people behind the wheel of the electric vehicle without AOC and her cronies telling us what kind of car to buy.

(CROSSTALK)

STEINBERG: I tried to do solar, you can't get it done on your house.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: And you can't get it done on your car because the sun is now always shining. We'll take a quick break. When we come back. The Federal Reserve is in focus. President Trump's expected nominee Stephen Moore reportedly in favor of the Central Bank cutting rates at this point. We're going to get into that. And then time for a change. Colorado's governor unveiling a new state logo. But it's his look that's gone viral. We'll be right back with that.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Headlines across America this morning. The Las Vegas review Journal says that giving Nevada a raise, minimum wage of $12 is possible by 2024. Proposed legislation raising minimum that wage to $12 an hour for workers not offered health insurance, $11 for those who are. The increase would be gradual, 75 cents a year beginning in 2020. Did you know Empire reporting an Alaska moose hunter can rev up his hovercraft according to the U.S. Supreme Court.

Justices reeling at the National Park Service was wrong to ban John Sturgeon from using his hovercraft on a river running through a national preserve. The panel decided the agency does not have the jurisdiction over that stretch of land. The Denver post this morning writing, Governor Jarid Polis unveils new Colorado logo with a tree and a sea from the state flag. He says the new look better reflects Colorado and will not cause taxpayers any more money.

The Governor wearing a winter hat featuring the colorful logo during his presentation and that hack up plenty of comments on social media. Colorado's new logo.

FOWLER: I like it.

STEINBERG: He was my classmate at Princeton. He was my classmate.

BARTIROMO: Is that right?

STEINBERG: Yes. He was always doing like start-ups and all sort of stuff.

MCDOWELL: That's awesome.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: I think Colorado is the coolest -- one of the coolest states in the country. I lived there for a couple of years and it's -- I think it -- the people in Colorado are also the thinnest in the nation because they're so --

(CROSSTALK)

STEINBERG: I want to ask you about the moose thing, OK?

(CROSSTALK)

STEINBERG: -- because you know -- because you've mentioned some of the outdoor stuff to me before in the green room. Like isn't hunting a moose in a hovercraft won't actually the moose off?

MCDOWELL: Is he hunting it?

STEINBERG: He was hunting moose in the hovercraft, right?

BARTIROMO: I don't know that he was hunting, no.

STEINBERG: Oh, he was just chasing those.

MCDOWELL: No. I think it was stretch of water.

BARTIROMO: It's a stretch of water.

MCDOWELL: It went through -- I don't know, I have to go read the story but I don't -- yes. But it depends on how loud his hovercraft is. I like how you turn to me from moose.

BARTIROMO: The moose story.

STEINBERG: I will -- I will - you can keep both of those. I'll stay right here in New York.

MCDOWELL: Here's my line of the day, don't hunt these majestic animals.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

STIREWALT: I'm -- I concur.

BARTIROMO: Actually, look, you know what I want to talk about with you later on in the show, this idea about socialism and you said it was dangerous some of these plans.

STEINBERG: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Why do you think it's so dangerous because people don't understand these are Federal programs and socialist program.
