Tech Copyright Reforms; Facebook Removes Fake Accounts; U.S.-China Trade; Federal Reserve Rate Hikes; May Faces New Pressure2019-03-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:47ZLexisNexisSenate Subcommittee Holding Hearing On Aviation Safety This Afternoon; Strong Demand For Lyft IPO; Green New Deal Procedural Vote Fails In Senate; AppleQualcomm Legal Battle; E.U. Tech Copyright Reforms; Facebook Removes Fake Accounts; U.S.-China Trade; Federal Reserve Rate Hikes; May Faces New PressureLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Thank you -- thank you so much. Good morning, everyone. I'm Maria Bartiromo, happy Wednesday. It is Wednesday, March 27th, your top stories right now 6:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast. Safety in the sky, this morning, the Senate is holding a hearing today following the two deadly Boeing crashes, what to expect from that transportation hearing, as the 737 Max makes an emergency landing in Florida.

Racing toward an IPO, Lyft reportedly seeing strong demand this morning as well. The price shares above the range last night, the details ahead of Friday's opening trade. And Green No Deal, the controversy plan -- controversial plan from Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez failed in the Senate yesterday. One Senator going viral for the posters that he used to slam that deal. Plus, $750 million up for grabs tonight, that's the big Powerful drawing. MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And Futures are searching for direction this morning, we are looking at a lower opening for the broader averages, but fractionally. Dow Industrials down about 45 points right now, S&P 500 down two, and the NASDAQ down one.

Our top story this morning, lawmakers are focusing on aircraft safety this afternoon with a Senate Commerce subcommittee on aviation and space. That hearing is following the deadly crashes of the Boeing 737 Max 8 jet. This, as the same model aircraft made an emergency landing in Florida yesterday after a reported engine problem. Joining me right now is former FAA safety team representative and pilot, Kyle Bailey, is here. Kyle, great to have you on the program.

KYLE BAILEY, SAFETY TEAM REPRESENTATIVE, FAA: Good morning, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. Tell us what you think is most important in the hearing today in terms of looking at this 737 jet?

BAILEY: You know, I think as far as the FAA goes and with Boeing with the certification process, it really should be scrutinizing relationship they have, the two of them, if they're a little bit complacent, because Boeing really does a good job at the certification process. And it will be interesting to see when they investigate, you know, how the two are working together, and are they a little bit too complacent?

BARTIROMO: I see. Because Boeing unveiled a software update today to fix this problem, and I guess it's the automated system, it was thought to have caused the 737's nose to tilt down in last October's Lion Air crash. Can you explain a little about that and what the issue is?

BAILEY: So, the system -- the software update, what that -- what that will do is there's an angle of attack indicator on the airplane. One sensor was feeding into that, or one, you know, of the actual -- on the exterior of the airplane. Now, two of those are going to feed into that sensor. So, if one malfunctions, there will still be another one that is giving input. So, there will be two in place of one. Also, as far as that nose, the system pushing the nose down to make the airplane descend in a potential stall situation, the system will only do that a couple of times. So, it will not be like the pilot will be struggling over and over and over again like, you know, what might have been the case previously.

BARTIROMO: How significant is this for Boeing? I mean, obviously, you're going to talk about major lawsuits coming at the company. But do you think that this is a major problem for the business and for how it may have to redirect itself?

BAILEY: Well, you know, keep in mind, Boeing isn't just in airplanes, they're also in the defense business, but as far as the airplane business goes, I mean, I think --

BARTIROMO: It's an important product.

BAILEY: Yes. And the passengers, in general, are you know, typically fearful of flying for the most part. You know, they really have to build, you know, passenger confidence. And it'll be very interesting to see how they do that.

BARTIROMO: How can they do it?

BAILEY: You know, it's hard. I mean, they really just have to tell everybody what they're doing and prove everything. And, you know, test this airplane, test the new software to make sure everything is doing what it should be doing. So, now, you know, we've had two crashes already. I mean -- so, they're going to do the software fix. I mean, they really have to, you know, go out of their way to prove this to the general flying public that this stuff really does work.

BARTIROMO: To really communicate that they are on the -- on the issue. I'm worried about the FAA. I mean, does it surprise you that the U.S. was really the last of -- you know, in the globe in terms of grounding this jet?

BAILEY: Well, the FAA is very bureaucratic, but I have to say they do a fine job at what they do. And they typically work on the facts and statistics, so they really don't care about media pressure, they don't care about pressure from the public. I think this -- you know, incident might have changed things, but in general, they're pretty much facts and data-driven when they make decisions. So -- but this would be the exception, though.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will leave it there. Kyle, it's great to have you, thanks so much.

BAILEY: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thanks for your insights on that. Kyle Bailey there. Meanwhile, IPOs are in focus, big year, Lyft reportedly will price its stock above the range, ahead of its IPO. Dagen McDowell with more on that. Good morning, Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. Lyft-off, let's call it. So, Lyft is on its IPO road show at the moment, marketing the shares to potential investors, and it's been standing-room-only crowds, according to The Wall Street Journal. The targeted range previously talked about was between $62.00 and $68.00 a share, and now it is expected to price above that level. The Wall Street Journal says it's unlikely to be as high as $80, more likely to be in the low 70s. Nevertheless, Lyft will be valued at more than $23 billion on a fully-diluted basis when it goes public.

Here's one of the interesting things, so most of the big private companies have large shareholders, mutual fund companies that already owned shares privately. Lyft, not so much, with the exception of Fidelity Investments. So, there's a lot of demand there from mutual fund companies, potentially for this IPO because they don't have a stake in the company before it goes public. One concern is its profitability. You're looking at some of the major IPOs to watch.

This is a good sign for, say, Pinterest, Uber that will follow Lyft. And investors have told The Wall Street Journal, their concern is profitability, the path to profitability. Lyft last year lost $911 million. That was one of -- it was the biggest of any U.S. start-up in the 12 months preceding its IPO, the biggest lost there. But nevertheless, people are interested in this company, Maria.

And by the way, we talked about LEVI, LEVI is still trading. It went public, it was priced at $17.00 a share, it's trading at 22 bucks, that's a gain of 29 percent.

BARTIROMO: Yes, just in a couple of days, that was real successful. And how about Uber, what is its valuation? $120 billion or something on Uber.

MCDOWELL: A lot of upside here because Lyft is going to -- is promising that it's going to reduce its costs dramatically, reducing its insurance costs as it builds scale, so that's what they're telling investors about the path to profitability.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll keep talking about that. See you in a bit, Dagen, thank you. Meanwhile, prosecutors are facing backlash this morning after dropping all charges against actor Jussie Smollett. Lauren Simonetti with those details now and headlines. Lauren, what a story.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Maria, wow! Chicago's mayor and police chief both raising questions about why Smollett was not held accountable for allegedly faking a racist, anti-gay attack on himself to gain attention for his acting career. Prosecutors say they dropped the charges after Smollett agreed to let the city keep its $10,000 in bail and to perform community service. But Smollett may not be out of the woods just yet. An investigation into a death threat letter the actor supposedly received prior to the alleged attack has been handed over to the FBI.

Take a look at this, shares of FiatChrysler trading sharply higher, up 3-1/2 percent in the premarket. London's Financial Times is reporting that the company could be a takeover target once Renault restarts merger talks with Nissan, that in the coming months. The newspaper says the move is a new strategy following the arrest of former Renault CEO and former Nissan Chairman Carlos Ghosn on financial misconduct charges. Ghosn, of course, has denied any wrongdoing.

And it might be your lucky day, your chance to turn two bucks into 750 million. Tonight's Powerball jackpot, the fourth largest in history if someone picks the lucky numbers. They'll get a lump sum of $466 million before taxes. We always like to let you know your odds, your odds of winning, 1 in 292 million. There is a chance, Maria.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Lauren. All right, quick break. And then, coming up, Green No Deal, Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's controversial Green New Deal fails test vote in the Senate yesterday as one Senator's poster against it goes viral. We'll tell you about that one. And then, battle of the drones, UPS is rolling out the first revenue-generating drone deliveries, beating out competition from Amazon and FedEx, much more on that when we come right back. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Big program this morning, coming up. Georgia Senator, member of the Senate Budget Banking, and Armed Services, and Agricultural Committees, David Perdue is with us this morning. Tennessee Senator and a member of the subcommittee on Aviation and Space, Marsha Blackburn is here, she's going to be at that transportation hearing today. Former adviser to President George W. Bush, Fox News Contributor Karl Rove joining us. Along with the author of "The Coming Collapse of China," author Gordon Chang is with us, as U.S. officials head to Beijing -- oh, they are in Beijing already for another round of trade talks. And Fox News Senior Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. Family Medicine doctor, Mikhail Varshavski, "Dr. Mike" is here. Breakout of measles to talk about with Mike. You don't miss a moment of it.

Meanwhile, the Green New Deal was denied yesterday. The Senate voted 57-0 against a procedural motion to take up the resolution. Most Democrats voted present to protest the GOP's action. A fiery response by freshman Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez to push back from Congressman Sean Duffy. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. SEAN DUFFY (R), WISCONSIN: The Green New Deal is one that if you're a rich liberal from maybe New York or California, it sounds great because you can afford to retrofit your home or build a new home that has zero emissions, that's energy efficient, affordable and safe.

REP. ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ (D), NEW YORK: You want to tell people that their concern and their desire for clean air and clean water is elitists? Tell that to the kids in the South Bronx which are suffering from the highest rates of childhood asthma in the country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining the conversation this morning, the founder and CEO of Cheddar, Jon Steinberg is here, along with New Leaders Senior Fellow, Fox News Contributor, Richard Fowler. Dagen McDowell, that was some hearing yesterday on the Green New Deal, it looked like theatrics more than anything else. How did you see them?

MCDOWELL: I will not throw shade at a lady who can rock a red lip and uses her hands like that.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: I kid. This is interesting. And my takeaway from just that comment from Congresswoman Ocasio-Cortez when she was talking about -- she was talking about the dirty -- the water problems in Flint, Michigan and the South Bronx. She is not pointing to something that the Green New Deal would necessarily fix. She's pointing to problems that occur, say, in the South Bronx, this is one of the most socialist cities in the nation, where you have great government control and extremely high taxes, and you still have appalling conditions that people are living in. With the Flint water crisis, again, this is something that the government did not prevent and did not stop. So if she thinks that government is the solution, she just gave two examples of the government being the problem.

BARTIROMO: Yes. What do you think, Richard?

RICHARD FOWLER, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Listen, I think the Green New Deal was a -- is a framework, right? Like I said, I don't think it's the perfect solution but here lies the problem. So we saw -- and I'm pretty sure we'll show the clip later of Utah Senator Mike Lee showing all these pictures of -- I think Ronald Reagan sitting on top of --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Let's take a look at this because that was Senator Mike Lee yesterday and it went viral. His posters which slammed the Green New Deal. Here is one example.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. MIKE LEE (R), UTAH: I rise today to consider the Green New Deal with the seriousness it deserves. This is a picture of Aquaman, a superhero from the undersea kingdom of Atlantis. I draw your attention, Mr. President, to the 20-foot impressive seahorse he's riding. Under the Green New Deal, this is probably Hawaii's best bet.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: It is pretty funny.

FOWLER: It is funny and I'm pretty sure the Kinkos stocks should be going through the roof right now because he made a lot of -- he spent a lot in printing. But here is the truth is that both the United Nations, the Congressional report, the fact is that climate change is a real thing, right? And I think what we have on one side is the Green New Deal, I'm not saying it's the best solution but on the other side you have folks likes Senator Mike Lee saying that climate change, nothing to see here, nothing is happening and I think that is part of the problem.

MCDOWELL: Mitch McConnell didn't know. Mitch McConnell actually is now on the record as saying I'm talking about climate change.

(CROSSTALK)

FOWLER: They haven't given any solutions and I think the solution exist sometimes in the middle when Democrats, Republican, businesses come together and say, OK, we have a problem here and that's actually trying to figure out some real solutions because the real problems like Super Storm Sandy flooding.

BARTIROMO: It's a nice thing to say that this is just a framework but it actually -- it is legislation that she would like to bring to the -- that she would like to see materialize, so it's not just a framework.

JON STEINBERG, CEO & FOUNDER, CHEDDAR: But to your point, Maria, it's basically nonexistent on facts right now.

BARTIROMO: Right.

STEINBERG: No one actually knows what's in the Green New Deal, the world is ending in 10 years, apparently it's causing asthma in New York City. But what we've seen here is the politicians level of marketing skill has completely evolve. I think largely as a result of President Trump, we have people now that know how to message, know how to use gimmicks, you've got presentations skills from somebody like AOC that are spectacular.

The way she presents, the way she speaks and we're entering sort of an area where this is what's going to define, you know, the movements that happened in this country. This socialism thing is unbelievably dangerous whether it's the Green New Deal or the pied-a-terre tax or the -- under the real estate kill tax basically in New York City. This kind of stuff is going to make things happen.

MCDOWELL: The Green New Deal proposes explicitly retrofitting every house in America. This is the Wall Street Journal's editorial today. And eliminating fossil fuels within a decade. That is higher energy cost, it will hurt lower-income Americans more than anyone else and our standard of living as a nation will suffer and they have to answer to that. Instead all of these yesterday, Democratic presidential candidates voted present. The Journal is calling it profiles and present which is hilarious.

BARTIROMO: So, it's -- that's the thing, I mean, you could say, yes, climate change is an issue, she could have just said that but to come up with this whole plan that is specific in terms of getting rid of fossil fuels in the next 10 years doesn't make any sense and that's why they're --

(CROSSTALK)

FOWLER: Yes. I mean, I think the -- but the truth of the matter here is that her plan sits on one side and on the opposite side of the aisle there is nothing, there is no plan, there is zero, there is an empty box, right? And I think if you look at -- if you look at recent polls you will see millennials in the Republican side are saying climate change is real and their party doesn't have an answer to that.

MCDOWELL: Well, the answer will be is that a carbon-free future is one -- is it creates a nation that you don't want to live in.

FOWLER: But that's not coming from the President or the party.

MCDOWELL: But you -- and also well, they -- we talk about it endlessly on this program and it is private industry that has not only lowered our emissions --

STEINBERG: Absolutely, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: -- with the use of natural gas, it is private industry and getting out of the way of using and developing and discovering in a new way those very fossil fuels that are plentiful in this country that keep people's energy costs down.

BARTIROMO: So there is a plan and Corporate America has been executing that plant --

(CROSSTALK)

STEINBERG: Look at the electric car move, you know, we can -- you know, we all, you know, punch at Elon Musk for his craziness all day long. He's done more to affect, you know, hybrid and electric vehicles in this country than any amount of legislation, any amount of tax credits. He just --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: I forgot throw punches at Elon Musk although I think he's been a jerk in the past, I think that this is -- he ultimately by creating a cool car, he will get more people behind the wheel of the electric vehicle without AOC and her cronies telling us what kind of car to buy.

(CROSSTALK)

STEINBERG: I tried to do solar, you can't get it done on your house.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: And you can't get it done on your car because the sun is now always shining. We'll take a quick break. When we come back. The Federal Reserve is in focus. President Trump's expected nominee Stephen Moore reportedly in favor of the Central Bank cutting rates at this point. We're going to get into that. And then time for a change. Colorado's governor unveiling a new state logo. But it's his look that's gone viral. We'll be right back with that.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Headlines across America this morning. The Las Vegas review Journal says that giving Nevada a raise, minimum wage of $12 is possible by 2024. Proposed legislation raising minimum that wage to $12 an hour for workers not offered health insurance, $11 for those who are. The increase would be gradual, 75 cents a year beginning in 2020. Did you know Empire reporting an Alaska moose hunter can rev up his hovercraft according to the U.S. Supreme Court.

Justices reeling at the National Park Service was wrong to ban John Sturgeon from using his hovercraft on a river running through a national preserve. The panel decided the agency does not have the jurisdiction over that stretch of land. The Denver post this morning writing, Governor Jarid Polis unveils new Colorado logo with a tree and a sea from the state flag. He says the new look better reflects Colorado and will not cause taxpayers any more money.

The Governor wearing a winter hat featuring the colorful logo during his presentation and that hack up plenty of comments on social media. Colorado's new logo.

FOWLER: I like it.

STEINBERG: He was my classmate at Princeton. He was my classmate.

BARTIROMO: Is that right?

STEINBERG: Yes. He was always doing like start-ups and all sort of stuff.

MCDOWELL: That's awesome.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: I think Colorado is the coolest -- one of the coolest states in the country. I lived there for a couple of years and it's -- I think it -- the people in Colorado are also the thinnest in the nation because they're so --

(CROSSTALK)

STEINBERG: I want to ask you about the moose thing, OK?

(CROSSTALK)

STEINBERG: -- because you know -- because you've mentioned some of the outdoor stuff to me before in the green room. Like isn't hunting a moose in a hovercraft won't actually the moose off?

MCDOWELL: Is he hunting it?

STEINBERG: He was hunting moose in the hovercraft, right?

BARTIROMO: I don't know that he was hunting, no.

STEINBERG: Oh, he was just chasing those.

MCDOWELL: No. I think it was stretch of water.

BARTIROMO: It's a stretch of water.

MCDOWELL: It went through -- I don't know, I have to go read the story but I don't -- yes. But it depends on how loud his hovercraft is. I like how you turn to me from moose.

BARTIROMO: The moose story.

STEINBERG: I will -- I will - you can keep both of those. I'll stay right here in New York.

MCDOWELL: Here's my line of the day, don't hunt these majestic animals.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

STIREWALT: I'm -- I concur.

BARTIROMO: Actually, look, you know what I want to talk about with you later on in the show, this idea about socialism and you said it was dangerous some of these plans.

STEINBERG: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Why do you think it's so dangerous because people don't understand these are Federal programs and socialist program.

STEINBERG: Because I think you have an entire generation of young people that don't know that socialism is breadlines basically that are having it sold by them and not another generation, not a counter kind of marketing message of how great capitalism. I mean, Ken Langone's book, you know, I love capitalism, it was great, we need an AOC version of capitalism basically in terms of pitch.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll take a short break. When we come back. The technology battle. Apple is facing iPhone sales bans in the United States after Qualcomm's patent ruling. And then a special delivery. UPS beats out Amazon and FedEx to roll out successful revenue generating drone deliveries. We'll show you more when we come back. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, good Wednesday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Wednesday, March 27th, your top stories right now, 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast.

Futures are indicating a decline at the start of trading this morning. Take a look, the Dow Industrials Futures down 50 points right now, a quarter of a percent, the S&P 500 down 3 points, and the NASDAQ lower by 1 and three quarters, stock finished positive yesterday.

The Dow added nearly 141 points on the session. It was one-half of a percent higher at the close. The S&P was up 20 points, three quarters of a percent, as well as the NASDAQ, 53 points higher yesterday, at the close.

Global markets this morning, under some selling pressure, European Indices are down across the board, as you can see, FT-100 down 23, CAC Quarante down 20, and the DAX Index down 28.

Shares were mixed in Asia overnight, Japan was down two-tenths of a percent, as you see there, a quarter of a percent, but the biggest mover was China, Shanghai Composite up almost one percent.

In favor of cutting interest rates, Stephen Moore, President Trump's pick for the Federal Reserve board, reportedly says that rates should be cut immediately by half of a percentage point.

May's tough decision, meanwhile, British lawmakers are looking for a new strategy this morning, for the country to exit the E.U., with Prime Minister Theresa May facing pressure, now to step down.

Special delivery now, by drone, UPS beats out Amazon and FedEx with drone deliveries of medical supplies, we'll show you how it works.

And then, smart glasses, Huawei unveils glasses that are all about sound, yes, Huawei, coming out with those glasses.

Our top story this half an hour, right now, Apple and Qualcomm's legal back and forth, a U.S. trade judge, ruling that the technology giant violated a Qualcomm patent in the manufacturing of certain older model iPhones and recommended an import ban on some iPhones.

At the same time, the U.S. International Trade Commission ruled in favor of Apple and invalidated a Qualcomm patent on battery-saving technology. The two companies have been in a two-year long legal battle. Qualcomm says that Apple owes billions of dollars in loyalties over technology used, in their iPhones.

Joining us now is Wedbush Securities Managing Director, Daniel Ives, Dan, good to see you this morning, thanks so much for joining us. First, give us your reaction to this Qualcomm-Apple fight which keeps going on?

DANIEL IVES, MANAGING DIRECTOR, WEDBUSH SECURITIES: Yes, it's just another round in this 12-round heavyweight battle, I mean, there's (INAUDIBLE) Qualcomm feels like they have Apple against the ropes, in terms of some of the rulings they've gotten especially overseas.

You know, I think this was a bit of a gut punch to Qualcomm in terms of -- on the ITC ruling. And I think, right now, this continues to be overhang on Apple because they continue to come out at the wrong time, given iPhone sales a phone off a cliff.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We want to talk more about regulation and the potential of it. Europe is obviously ahead of the U.S. The E.U. continues to take on big tech, the European Union, backing copyright reforms targeting Facebook and Google. They would require the companies to pay licensing fee to publishers for content posted on their platforms.

These new reforms also targeted copyrighted material by installing filters on the platforms, but, Dan, this is all on top of what we know to be hefty fines against Google, against other tech companies in Europe, much more aggressive in Europe than the U.S., will the U.S. follow suit at some point, do you think, and get a bigger government hand on tech?

IVES: This is another anti-big tech measure. I could tell you I talked to executives last night, a bunch from the valley, and these are nightmare who are ruling because from a copyright perspective, it's more lawyer-driven right around Brussels, but really anti-big tech.

We continue to think from GDPR to moves like the copyright, Europe continues to be much further ahead, regulatory wise, from the U.S., but look, with Warren and some others talking about breaking up big U.S. tech, that's something that investors are getting a little more worried about especially since we go into next election cycle.

STEINBERG: Dan, let's go back to Apple for a second. Investors have been talking about it nonstop since the media announcements this past week. It seems to me that Qualcomm is not the overhang, is that ultimately, it was a whole home event, a lot of celebrities, very light on details.

And ultimately, if you look at five-day chart on the stock, the service's revenue is supposed to be to solve for the flattening of device sales, but people seem to think it's not going to happen now, agree or disagree on that?

IVES: Oh, definitely, the battleground areas and services, we continue to look, 400, 450 billion of the valuation of services. And when I look at the announcement this week, I viewed it as a step in the right direction, ultimately they are keeping the play book close to vest.

There's a lot of competition of Netflix and Disney, but otherwise, we continue to do see Apple does make a large content acquisition, that's going to be significant not just from a distribution platform but from original content. That's the key right now for Cook and Cupertino with their back against the wall.

MCDOWELL: Dan, it's Dagen McDowell, and I put out this crock pot theory, I think it was yesterday, that if investors become concerned about the growing competition from Apple and other content providers, that drives down Netflix stock.

That makes Netflix attractive potentially to Apple, sweeping them and buying them. Do you think Apple ultimately tries to buy Netflix?

IVES: Look, we have said the biggest strategic mistake that Apple and Cook have ever made, was not acquiring Netflix. I think it's becoming clearer and clearer, it's around services and content. That's why we believe that's still potential on the table.

But we view as CBS, Viacom, and A24 Lionsgate, as more likely in terms of the content acquisitions for Apple, even though they've never done historic M&A. Right now, we believe the clock struck 12:00.

BARTIROMO: Well, yes, I mean, you know, content is king right now. Look at the billions being paid for original content. What about the privacy issues around at Facebook? I mean, this morning, the company is announcing it is cracking down on fake news, announcing it has removed more than 2,600 pages that are linked to fake accounts, the majority were tied to Russia and Iran.

But look, when you talk about fixes for the company's privacy issues, what does that mean? I mean, this is their business model, right? I mean, they sell data to advertisers, so can you really get out of what the issues are, without completely changing the business model?

IVES: Well, look, and that's why Cox and the other executives have been revolving door and leaving, because as you play nice in the sand box to the bell weight in Brussels, you ruin your business model. And I think that's the worry right here, is that, as you get more to privacy, it comes down to that's the worry for investors, that's why there's been the overhang here.

And I think there -- it's a fork in the road situation, they're going to have to kind of balance this because ultimately, especially when you look at what happened in Instagram and the messaging platform, that's going to be the key for Facebook, that's why in fang names, right now, you know, some queer overhangs, especially on the social media names, with Facebook front and center and a target on its back.

FOWLER: So, Dan, I mean, I think -- to add on to Maria's questions, so, I mean, how does Facebook deal with that, right? The fact that they have to police the site, they have to get all these sort of fake accounts off the site.

They have to get these people buying fake sites off the site. And at the same time, they have to make money off of ads. I mean, how do they balance those two for the marketplace?

IVES: Yes. We believe it's content-driven and fundamentally, Facebook right now, they're going to have to draw more and more content on the platform, focus more and more on user engagement. They're going to have to do these privacy issues, but it gets back to that is their core business model from an advertising perspective, that's what investors care about.

And that's also why even internally, at Facebook, that's what they care about. And that's why Zuckerberg right now, there's a battle going on internally, where they have to continue to stick to their core knitting, otherwise, even there could be, you know, some nightmares days ahead.

BARTIROMO: All right.

MCDOWELL: No, I was just going to say, oh, so they are media companies, but they can't be sued for defamation under federal law?

And again, I brought this up, Devin Nunes' lawsuit against Twitter, it's pushing the legal boundaries of what is going on, because mid-'90s law, you cannot sue internet service providers and other companies because they don't technically create the content and aren't media companies, but they are.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but they are.

STEINBERG: On Dan's last point, they don't want to stick to their knitting anymore. Zuckerberg has come out and said now it's all going to be about private messaging. This is his big of a shift, as post IPO, when they had to make the pivot to mobile. And now, you're going to have to bet on a whole new company. They're exiting this public arena.

MCDOWELL: It's not a whole new company, though, they are reckless with people's private information and I think that that's what investors know, and I think that's what the public knows, is you're saying it's private, but you can still see all of these messages and all of these communication.

And what are Zuckerberg and Sheryl Sandberg going to actually do with that, do we trust them? Somebody told me, doing business with them, like you cannot trust what they tell you.

BARTIROMO: And you mentioned Dan -- and you mentioned Devin Nunes and his lawsuit against Twitter, more are coming, I understand (INAUDIBLE) as well as the Daily Beast, he's going to be suing others, and he'll be joining us this week, by the way, to talk about it. Dan Ives, it's good to see you this morning, thank you.

IVES: Thanks.

BARTIROMO: We'll keep watching. Meanwhile, a date has been set for Elon Musk and the Securities and Exchange Commission to square off in court. Lauren Simonetti on that story in headlines this morning, Lauren.

SIMONETTI: We have the date, Maria, Elon Musk's contempt of court case, set for April 4th. A federal judge in New York, hearing arguments on the SEC's claim the tweet, Musk, posted in February, violated terms of his fraud settlement, because Musk didn't get approval from Tesla.

UPS is making history today. The company is testing drone deliveries of medical supplies to a hospital in North Carolina. The flight marks the first commercial drone deliveries approved by FAA. Drones will transport lab samples from hospitals to doctors' offices and so forth, getting them to their destinations much quicker than ground deliveries, essentially from 30 minutes to 3 minutes.

Huawei is teaming up with Gentle Monster, that's a Korean fashion brand. They are set to release their first smart glasses. You're looking at them. If you buy a pair, you'll be able to listen to music and take phone calls simply by tapping the temple of the glasses, so you won't have to wear ear buds.

The glasses can be charged wirelessly, they go on sale in July. We don't know how much they are going to cost. Glasses -- smart glasses have struggled from other companies, we'll see if this one will work.

BARTIROMO: Is it spying on all your data and what comes up there, I mean, Huawei has its own issues, we know that, and the U.S. government is trying to ban Huawei telecom and technology from the U.S.

SIMONETTI: And if you're wearing something, is it, you know, spying on all the people around you.

BARTIROMO: Right.

SIMONETTI: What is it doing with that?

BARTIROMO: Yes. We'll have to look at that. Coming up, thank you, Lauren, eye on China trade, top U.S. officials back at the table this week, another round of talks with China, what can get done, we're going to get into it when we come back, and then tough decisions in the U.K. this morning, British Prime Minister Theresa May faces increasing pressure to step down, lawmakers there, looking for another strategy to exit the European Union, all ahead right here, back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We are watching negotiations between the U.S. and China. Big week. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin in Beijing this morning ahead of high-level talks tomorrows. Joining us right now to talk about what it means for markets and investing Tiger 21 Chairman, Michael Sonnenfeldt. It is good to see you this morning, Michael.

MICHAEL SONNENFELDT, CHAIRMAN, TIGER 21: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much for joining us. What are your members doing in terms of allocating capital, how important is a China deal to them in terms of putting money to work in markets?

SONNENFELDT: Well, first of all, our members have been shying away from China for all of the problems, rule of law being one of them but as far as the negotiations when our members think about their businesses, they've been getting stolen intellectual property. It's hard to develop a product when fake product is in China within 24 hours. So, on the intellectual property, that's got to have some progress and then you have tariffs and quotas, and we want to tamp it down because we know bad things happen when that gets out of control. So, members who are running small businesses, they know that these are the two factors that they're looking at.

BARTIROMO: Yes. So, we want to talk China this morning, we also going to talk rates. Dagen, look at this 10-year yield which has happened in the last half an hour. The yield has dropped below 2.4 percent, this is a big move here, down four basis points, what do you make of it?

MCDOWELL: And I think some of this is a reaction to the comments of Steve Moore, who is the nominee to be on Federal Reserve Board by president. Yes, to President Trump. I almost said Obama. President Trump trading in fed fund futures indicates a 70 percent -- 75 percent probability for a rate cut by the end of the year based on Steve Moore is saying that the Fed should cut rates. So, this is very often when you see the yield curve invert where shorter term rates are higher. This is telling you that the Fed will be cutting rates.

BARTIROMO: So, is this a positive or a negative? I mean, look, rates being lowered is a good thing usually but if it's indicating things are a lot slower than anybody thought, do investors react negatively to that story?

SONNENFELDT: Look, for my member's point of view, I was in a meeting yesterday where people are trying to make sense of this. Most recessions are indicated by an inverted yield curves, not all inverted yield curves mean we have recession. But it's a warning signal, it's one of those red flags. So, clearly people are concerned about the Fed, but generally, the Fed has been high marks when you think about the changes at the Fed over the last year. I think people are pleasantly surprised.

STEINBERG: Michael, that's my question to you, which is usually, the inverted yield curve means a recession but we've never seen this level of whipsawing in interest rates and kind of reversal that's being messaged now. Can we say the economy is fundamentally strong, that the removal of any chance of impeachment removes kind of the, the domestic overhang that could rattle the market and then ultimately, this is just a readjustment with the new Fed chairman?

SONNENFELDT: So, for business people, not economists trying to run small businesses, that is what our members are about. They balance what you just said with the trillion-dollar deficit. We've never had a trillion-dollar deficit. So, it's like when you're pulling a rope. Now, we have one in one direction and one in the other and nobody knows which part of that is going to win. You can have the kind of trillion-dollar deficit even though the signals are pretty good right now. The members in our group were saying it's kind of like being on thin ice: we're still skating, but it feels like the ice is getting thinner and thinner.

FOWLER: So, Michael, the question around this China trade thing that Maria brought up at the top of this segment, right, so I think the two issues you brought up both tariffs as well as intellectual property, seemed to be sticking point for China, right? Because what China wants is immediate relief of the tariffs, but they don't really want to give up intellectual property which is why this negotiation have sort of hung on for so long. So, how does the folks in your group see this, right, and what is the best outcome for them?

SONNENFELDT: I would say of all of the policy areas that are going on, the one where our members, which are businessmen, left, right, conservative, liberal, the ones that they concentrate on is the intellectual property. If we don't break the back of this kind of activity, every time you invest, I have a company in Germany that we create little computers in the solar business. Within 24 hours of a new product, a fake product is on the web in China. You can't afford to make investments if every time you make an investment, it's stolen. So, this is an absolute bedrock issue for any kind of basic business.

BARTIROMO: And I think the Trump administration knows that, but the question is: are they going to be able to put in some kind of an enforcement mechanism where they could just, you know, snap back tariffs or do something should China not follow through on its promises to stop stealing.

SONNENFELDT: Well, certainly, our negotiator, Lighthizer, is one of the tough negotiators. You got to give the administration credit for putting somebody in who has a spine.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right, we'll leave it there. Michael, it's great to see you.

SONNENFELDT: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much. Michael Sonnenfeldt there. Coming up, the search for more options: British Prime Minister Theresa May told to set a date for her departure as lawmakers consider alternative plans to leave the E.U. That's next. Back in a minute right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. British lawmakers are voting on other option this is morning for the country's exit from the E.U. Prime Minister Theresa May is now facing pressure to step down. Ashley Webster with all the details right now. Ashley.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Yes. Hey, Maria, listen, she's been under pressure for a long time, Theresa May. She will step down. It's a matter of whether she can get her deal across the line, which she has not been able to do. In fact, humiliating defeats twice now. And if she can get it across the line, she will resign at that point too. So, her future, we know, is outside of number 10 Downing Street. The bigger issue, though, is how the heck they're going to break this deadlock in parliament. They're going to be voting on 16 different options being proposed today, house speaker -- House of Commons Speaker, John Bercow, the guy that shouts order, order. He'll decide which ones will be --

BARTIROMO: You sound like him.

WEBSTER: Thank you very much. He will decide which ones will be debated, he'll probably whittle it down to half a dozen. But let's point this out, none of what happens today, the debate and the votes mean anything. They are non-binding and Theresa May can completely ignore what they do today; it's just parliament saying, we've told you what we want to vote for but now, today, we're going to show you what we will vote for. If there's a massive majority in parliament for one particular option that will put a lot of political pressure on Theresa May and she may be impossible for her to ignore. But bottom line here is, you know, this is crunch time and she still doesn't have enough votes for her plans.

FOWLER: So, Ashley, will her deal get a third vote? So, I mean, the speaker has already ruled that her deal wouldn't get up their vote like a couple -- a week or two ago. Will her deal get a third vote now?

WEBSTER: Yes, it will because the E.U. has now put stipulations on it. So, you could argue it's now in the different form. There are reports that maybe a third time will happen this Friday symbolically because it's March 29th, the day that the U.K. was supposed to leave the E.U. If not, sometime next week. But by the way, these votes taking place today, these indicative votes will get whittled down and we could see another round of this next Monday, April Fool's Day, make of that what you will. Bottom line is, this is going to be -- there's still a no-deal option on the table as far as Johnson said today.

STEINBERG: Ashley, that's my question to you. So, when I can't get over something, and I'm not doing something, my dad says: John, move on, move on, right?

WEBSTER: Right.

STEINBERG: It's over. They're Brexiting, move on. Why can they not just get --

WEBSTER: Because Theresa May's greatest quality is her persistence. Her biggest problem is her persistence and her stubbornness. She's kind of said, it's my way, these are my red lines, nothing changes. Parliament has said, that's not good enough and that's where we're at this point.

BARTIROMO: All right. Wow, what a story. Ashley, thank you.

WEBSTER: Yes. My pleasure.

BARTIROMO: We'll take a break. When we come back, coffee with the side of playtime. We'll take you to unique coffee where you can cuddle with corgi. Next hour right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Wednesday, March 27th. Your top stories right now, 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast. A timetable for the release, a new report says that the public could see a version of the Mueller report within weeks.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It could not have been better --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

Tech Copyright Reforms; Facebook Removes Fake Accounts; U.S.-China Trade; Federal Reserve Rate Hikes; May Faces New Pressure2019-03-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:47ZLexisNexisSenate Subcommittee Holding Hearing On Aviation Safety This Afternoon; Strong Demand For Lyft IPO; Green New Deal Procedural Vote Fails In Senate; AppleQualcomm Legal Battle; E.U. Tech Copyright Reforms; Facebook Removes Fake Accounts; U.S.-China Trade; Federal Reserve Rate Hikes; May Faces New PressureLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Thank you -- thank you so much. Good morning, everyone. I'm Maria Bartiromo, happy Wednesday. It is Wednesday, March 27th, your top stories right now 6:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast. Safety in the sky, this morning, the Senate is holding a hearing today following the two deadly Boeing crashes, what to expect from that transportation hearing, as the 737 Max makes an emergency landing in Florida.

Racing toward an IPO, Lyft reportedly seeing strong demand this morning as well. The price shares above the range last night, the details ahead of Friday's opening trade. And Green No Deal, the controversy plan -- controversial plan from Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez failed in the Senate yesterday. One Senator going viral for the posters that he used to slam that deal. Plus, $750 million up for grabs tonight, that's the big Powerful drawing. MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And Futures are searching for direction this morning, we are looking at a lower opening for the broader averages, but fractionally. Dow Industrials down about 45 points right now, S&P 500 down two, and the NASDAQ down one.

Our top story this morning, lawmakers are focusing on aircraft safety this afternoon with a Senate Commerce subcommittee on aviation and space. That hearing is following the deadly crashes of the Boeing 737 Max 8 jet. This, as the same model aircraft made an emergency landing in Florida yesterday after a reported engine problem. Joining me right now is former FAA safety team representative and pilot, Kyle Bailey, is here. Kyle, great to have you on the program.

KYLE BAILEY, SAFETY TEAM REPRESENTATIVE, FAA: Good morning, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. Tell us what you think is most important in the hearing today in terms of looking at this 737 jet?

BAILEY: You know, I think as far as the FAA goes and with Boeing with the certification process, it really should be scrutinizing relationship they have, the two of them, if they're a little bit complacent, because Boeing really does a good job at the certification process. And it will be interesting to see when they investigate, you know, how the two are working together, and are they a little bit too complacent?

BARTIROMO: I see. Because Boeing unveiled a software update today to fix this problem, and I guess it's the automated system, it was thought to have caused the 737's nose to tilt down in last October's Lion Air crash. Can you explain a little about that and what the issue is?

BAILEY: So, the system -- the software update, what that -- what that will do is there's an angle of attack indicator on the airplane. One sensor was feeding into that, or one, you know, of the actual -- on the exterior of the airplane. Now, two of those are going to feed into that sensor. So, if one malfunctions, there will still be another one that is giving input. So, there will be two in place of one. Also, as far as that nose, the system pushing the nose down to make the airplane descend in a potential stall situation, the system will only do that a couple of times. So, it will not be like the pilot will be struggling over and over and over again like, you know, what might have been the case previously.

BARTIROMO: How significant is this for Boeing? I mean, obviously, you're going to talk about major lawsuits coming at the company. But do you think that this is a major problem for the business and for how it may have to redirect itself?

So, on the intellectual property, that's got to have some progress and then you have tariffs and quotas, and we want to tamp it down because we know bad things happen when that gets out of control. So, members who are running small businesses, they know that these are the two factors that they're looking at.

BARTIROMO: Yes. So, we want to talk China this morning, we also going to talk rates. Dagen, look at this 10-year yield which has happened in the last half an hour. The yield has dropped below 2.4 percent, this is a big move here, down four basis points, what do you make of it?

MCDOWELL: And I think some of this is a reaction to the comments of Steve Moore, who is the nominee to be on Federal Reserve Board by president. Yes, to President Trump. I almost said Obama. President Trump trading in fed fund futures indicates a 70 percent -- 75 percent probability for a rate cut by the end of the year based on Steve Moore is saying that the Fed should cut rates. So, this is very often when you see the yield curve invert where shorter term rates are higher. This is telling you that the Fed will be cutting rates.

BARTIROMO: So, is this a positive or a negative? I mean, look, rates being lowered is a good thing usually but if it's indicating things are a lot slower than anybody thought, do investors react negatively to that story?

SONNENFELDT: Look, for my member's point of view, I was in a meeting yesterday where people are trying to make sense of this. Most recessions are indicated by an inverted yield curves, not all inverted yield curves mean we have recession. But it's a warning signal, it's one of those red flags. So, clearly people are concerned about the Fed, but generally, the Fed has been high marks when you think about the changes at the Fed over the last year. I think people are pleasantly surprised.

STEINBERG: Michael, that's my question to you, which is usually, the inverted yield curve means a recession but we've never seen this level of whipsawing in interest rates and kind of reversal that's being messaged now. Can we say the economy is fundamentally strong, that the removal of any chance of impeachment removes kind of the, the domestic overhang that could rattle the market and then ultimately, this is just a readjustment with the new Fed chairman?

SONNENFELDT: So, for business people, not economists trying to run small businesses, that is what our members are about. They balance what you just said with the trillion-dollar deficit. We've never had a trillion-dollar deficit. So, it's like when you're pulling a rope. Now, we have one in one direction and one in the other and nobody knows which part of that is going to win. You can have the kind of trillion-dollar deficit even though the signals are pretty good right now. The members in our group were saying it's kind of like being on thin ice: we're still skating, but it feels like the ice is getting thinner and thinner.

FOWLER: So, Michael, the question around this China trade thing that Maria brought up at the top of this segment, right, so I think the two issues you brought up both tariffs as well as intellectual property, seemed to be sticking point for China, right? Because what China wants is immediate relief of the tariffs, but they don't really want to give up intellectual property which is why this negotiation have sort of hung on for so long. So, how does the folks in your group see this, right, and what is the best outcome for them?

SONNENFELDT: I would say of all of the policy areas that are going on, the one where our members, which are businessmen, left, right, conservative, liberal, the ones that they concentrate on is the intellectual property. If we don't break the back of this kind of activity, every time you invest, I have a company in Germany that we create little computers in the solar business. Within 24 hours of a new product, a fake product is on the web in China. You can't afford to make investments if every time you make an investment, it's stolen. So, this is an absolute bedrock issue for any kind of basic business.

BARTIROMO: And I think the Trump administration knows that, but the question is: are they going to be able to put in some kind of an enforcement mechanism where they could just, you know, snap back tariffs or do something should China not follow through on its promises to stop stealing.

SONNENFELDT: Well, certainly, our negotiator, Lighthizer, is one of the tough negotiators. You got to give the administration credit for putting somebody in who has a spine.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right, we'll leave it there. Michael, it's great to see you.

SONNENFELDT: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much. Michael Sonnenfeldt there. Coming up, the search for more options: British Prime Minister Theresa May told to set a date for her departure as lawmakers consider alternative plans to leave the E.U. That's next. Back in a minute right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. British lawmakers are voting on other option this is morning for the country's exit from the E.U. Prime Minister Theresa May is now facing pressure to step down. Ashley Webster with all the details right now. Ashley.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Yes. Hey, Maria, listen, she's been under pressure for a long time, Theresa May. She will step down. It's a matter of whether she can get her deal across the line, which she has not been able to do. In fact, humiliating defeats twice now. And if she can get it across the line, she will resign at that point too. So, her future, we know, is outside of number 10 Downing Street. The bigger issue, though, is how the heck they're going to break this deadlock in parliament. They're going to be voting on 16 different options being proposed today, house speaker -- House of Commons Speaker, John Bercow, the guy that shouts order, order. He'll decide which ones will be --

BARTIROMO: You sound like him.

WEBSTER: Thank you very much. He will decide which ones will be debated, he'll probably whittle it down to half a dozen. But let's point this out, none of what happens today, the debate and the votes mean anything. They are non-binding and Theresa May can completely ignore what they do today; it's just parliament saying, we've told you what we want to vote for but now, today, we're going to show you what we will vote for. If there's a massive majority in parliament for one particular option that will put a lot of political pressure on Theresa May and she may be impossible for her to ignore. But bottom line here is, you know, this is crunch time and she still doesn't have enough votes for her plans.

FOWLER: So, Ashley, will her deal get a third vote? So, I mean, the speaker has already ruled that her deal wouldn't get up their vote like a couple -- a week or two ago. Will her deal get a third vote now?

WEBSTER: Yes, it will because the E.U. has now put stipulations on it. So, you could argue it's now in the different form. There are reports that maybe a third time will happen this Friday symbolically because it's March 29th, the day that the U.K. was supposed to leave the E.U. If not, sometime next week. But by the way, these votes taking place today, these indicative votes will get whittled down and we could see another round of this next Monday, April Fool's Day, make of that what you will. Bottom line is, this is going to be -- there's still a no-deal option on the table as far as Johnson said today.

STEINBERG: Ashley, that's my question to you. So, when I can't get over something, and I'm not doing something, my dad says: John, move on, move on, right?

WEBSTER: Right.

STEINBERG: It's over. They're Brexiting, move on. Why can they not just get --

WEBSTER: Because Theresa May's greatest quality is her persistence. Her biggest problem is her persistence and her stubbornness. She's kind of said, it's my way, these are my red lines, nothing changes. Parliament has said, that's not good enough and that's where we're at this point.

BARTIROMO: All right. Wow, what a story. Ashley, thank you.

WEBSTER: Yes. My pleasure.

BARTIROMO: We'll take a break. When we come back, coffee with the side of playtime. We'll take you to unique coffee where you can cuddle with corgi. Next hour right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Wednesday, March 27th. Your top stories right now, 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast. A timetable for the release, a new report says that the public could see a version of the Mueller report within weeks.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It could not have been better --

Tech Copyright Reforms; Facebook Removes Fake Accounts; U.S.-China Trade; Federal Reserve Rate Hikes; May Faces New Pressure2019-03-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:47ZLexisNexisSenate Subcommittee Holding Hearing On Aviation Safety This Afternoon; Strong Demand For Lyft IPO; Green New Deal Procedural Vote Fails In Senate; AppleQualcomm Legal Battle; E.U. Tech Copyright Reforms; Facebook Removes Fake Accounts; U.S.-China Trade; Federal Reserve Rate Hikes; May Faces New PressureLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Thank you -- thank you so much. Good morning, everyone. I'm Maria Bartiromo, happy Wednesday. It is Wednesday, March 27th, your top stories right now 6:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast. Safety in the sky, this morning, the Senate is holding a hearing today following the two deadly Boeing crashes, what to expect from that transportation hearing, as the 737 Max makes an emergency landing in Florida.

Racing toward an IPO, Lyft reportedly seeing strong demand this morning as well. The price shares above the range last night, the details ahead of Friday's opening trade. And Green No Deal, the controversy plan -- controversial plan from Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez failed in the Senate yesterday. One Senator going viral for the posters that he used to slam that deal. Plus, $750 million up for grabs tonight, that's the big Powerful drawing. MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And Futures are searching for direction this morning, we are looking at a lower opening for the broader averages, but fractionally. Dow Industrials down about 45 points right now, S&P 500 down two, and the NASDAQ down one.

Our top story this morning, lawmakers are focusing on aircraft safety this afternoon with a Senate Commerce subcommittee on aviation and space. That hearing is following the deadly crashes of the Boeing 737 Max 8 jet. This, as the same model aircraft made an emergency landing in Florida yesterday after a reported engine problem. Joining me right now is former FAA safety team representative and pilot, Kyle Bailey, is here. Kyle, great to have you on the program.

KYLE BAILEY, SAFETY TEAM REPRESENTATIVE, FAA: Good morning, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. Tell us what you think is most important in the hearing today in terms of looking at this 737 jet?

BAILEY: You know, I think as far as the FAA goes and with Boeing with the certification process, it really should be scrutinizing relationship they have, the two of them, if they're a little bit complacent, because Boeing really does a good job at the certification process. And it will be interesting to see when they investigate, you know, how the two are working together, and are they a little bit too complacent?

BARTIROMO: I see. Because Boeing unveiled a software update today to fix this problem, and I guess it's the automated system, it was thought to have caused the 737's nose to tilt down in last October's Lion Air crash. Can you explain a little about that and what the issue is?

BAILEY: So, the system -- the software update, what that -- what that will do is there's an angle of attack indicator on the airplane. One sensor was feeding into that, or one, you know, of the actual -- on the exterior of the airplane. Now, two of those are going to feed into that sensor. So, if one malfunctions, there will still be another one that is giving input. So, there will be two in place of one. Also, as far as that nose, the system pushing the nose down to make the airplane descend in a potential stall situation, the system will only do that a couple of times. So, it will not be like the pilot will be struggling over and over and over again like, you know, what might have been the case previously.

BARTIROMO: How significant is this for Boeing? I mean, obviously, you're going to talk about major lawsuits coming at the company. But do you think that this is a major problem for the business and for how it may have to redirect itself?

BAILEY: Well, you know, keep in mind, Boeing isn't just in airplanes, they're also in the defense business, but as far as the airplane business goes, I mean, I think --

BARTIROMO: It's an important product.

BAILEY: Yes. And the passengers, in general, are you know, typically fearful of flying for the most part. You know, they really have to build, you know, passenger confidence. And it'll be very interesting to see how they do that.

BARTIROMO: How can they do it?

BAILEY: You know, it's hard. I mean, they really just have to tell everybody what they're doing and prove everything. And, you know, test this airplane, test the new software to make sure everything is doing what it should be doing. So, now, you know, we've had two crashes already. I mean -- so, they're going to do the software fix. I mean, they really have to, you know, go out of their way to prove this to the general flying public that this stuff really does work.

BARTIROMO: To really communicate that they are on the -- on the issue. I'm worried about the FAA. I mean, does it surprise you that the U.S. was really the last of -- you know, in the globe in terms of grounding this jet?

BAILEY: Well, the FAA is very bureaucratic, but I have to say they do a fine job at what they do. And they typically work on the facts and statistics, so they really don't care about media pressure, they don't care about pressure from the public. I think this -- you know, incident might have changed things, but in general, they're pretty much facts and data-driven when they make decisions. So -- but this would be the exception, though.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will leave it there. Kyle, it's great to have you, thanks so much.

BAILEY: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thanks for your insights on that. Kyle Bailey there. Meanwhile, IPOs are in focus, big year, Lyft reportedly will price its stock above the range, ahead of its IPO. Dagen McDowell with more on that. Good morning, Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. Lyft-off, let's call it. So, Lyft is on its IPO road show at the moment, marketing the shares to potential investors, and it's been standing-room-only crowds, according to The Wall Street Journal. The targeted range previously talked about was between $62.00 and $68.00 a share, and now it is expected to price above that level. The Wall Street Journal says it's unlikely to be as high as $80, more likely to be in the low 70s. Nevertheless, Lyft will be valued at more than $23 billion on a fully-diluted basis when it goes public.

Here's one of the interesting things, so most of the big private companies have large shareholders, mutual fund companies that already owned shares privately. Lyft, not so much, with the exception of Fidelity Investments. So, there's a lot of demand there from mutual fund companies, potentially for this IPO because they don't have a stake in the company before it goes public. One concern is its profitability. You're looking at some of the major IPOs to watch.

This is a good sign for, say, Pinterest, Uber that will follow Lyft. And investors have told The Wall Street Journal, their concern is profitability, the path to profitability. Lyft last year lost $911 million. That was one of -- it was the biggest of any U.S. start-up in the 12 months preceding its IPO, the biggest lost there. But nevertheless, people are interested in this company, Maria.

And by the way, we talked about LEVI, LEVI is still trading. It went public, it was priced at $17.00 a share, it's trading at 22 bucks, that's a gain of 29 percent.

BARTIROMO: Yes, just in a couple of days, that was real successful. And how about Uber, what is its valuation? $120 billion or something on Uber.

MCDOWELL: A lot of upside here because Lyft is going to -- is promising that it's going to reduce its costs dramatically, reducing its insurance costs as it builds scale, so that's what they're telling investors about the path to profitability.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll keep talking about that. See you in a bit, Dagen, thank you. Meanwhile, prosecutors are facing backlash this morning after dropping all charges against actor Jussie Smollett. Lauren Simonetti with those details now and headlines. Lauren, what a story.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Maria, wow! Chicago's mayor and police chief both raising questions about why Smollett was not held accountable for allegedly faking a racist, anti-gay attack on himself to gain attention for his acting career. Prosecutors say they dropped the charges after Smollett agreed to let the city keep its $10,000 in bail and to perform community service. But Smollett may not be out of the woods just yet. An investigation into a death threat letter the actor supposedly received prior to the alleged attack has been handed over to the FBI.

Take a look at this, shares of FiatChrysler trading sharply higher, up 3-1/2 percent in the premarket. London's Financial Times is reporting that the company could be a takeover target once Renault restarts merger talks with Nissan, that in the coming months. The newspaper says the move is a new strategy following the arrest of former Renault CEO and former Nissan Chairman Carlos Ghosn on financial misconduct charges. Ghosn, of course, has denied any wrongdoing.

And it might be your lucky day, your chance to turn two bucks into 750 million. Tonight's Powerball jackpot, the fourth largest in history if someone picks the lucky numbers. They'll get a lump sum of $466 million before taxes. We always like to let you know your odds, your odds of winning, 1 in 292 million. There is a chance, Maria.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Lauren. All right, quick break. And then, coming up, Green No Deal, Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's controversial Green New Deal fails test vote in the Senate yesterday as one Senator's poster against it goes viral. We'll tell you about that one. And then, battle of the drones, UPS is rolling out the first revenue-generating drone deliveries, beating out competition from Amazon and FedEx, much more on that when we come right back. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Big program this morning, coming up. Georgia Senator, member of the Senate Budget Banking, and Armed Services, and Agricultural Committees, David Perdue is with us this morning. Tennessee Senator and a member of the subcommittee on Aviation and Space, Marsha Blackburn is here, she's going to be at that transportation hearing today. Former adviser to President George W. Bush, Fox News Contributor Karl Rove joining us. Along with the author of "The Coming Collapse of China," author Gordon Chang is with us, as U.S. officials head to Beijing -- oh, they are in Beijing already for another round of trade talks. And Fox News Senior Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. Family Medicine doctor, Mikhail Varshavski, "Dr. Mike" is here. Breakout of measles to talk about with Mike. You don't miss a moment of it.

Meanwhile, the Green New Deal was denied yesterday. The Senate voted 57-0 against a procedural motion to take up the resolution. Most Democrats voted present to protest the GOP's action. A fiery response by freshman Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez to push back from Congressman Sean Duffy. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. SEAN DUFFY (R), WISCONSIN: The Green New Deal is one that if you're a rich liberal from maybe New York or California, it sounds great because you can afford to retrofit your home or build a new home that has zero emissions, that's energy efficient, affordable and safe.

REP. ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ (D), NEW YORK: You want to tell people that their concern and their desire for clean air and clean water is elitists? Tell that to the kids in the South Bronx which are suffering from the highest rates of childhood asthma in the country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining the conversation this morning, the founder and CEO of Cheddar, Jon Steinberg is here, along with New Leaders Senior Fellow, Fox News Contributor, Richard Fowler. Dagen McDowell, that was some hearing yesterday on the Green New Deal, it looked like theatrics more than anything else. How did you see them?

MCDOWELL: I will not throw shade at a lady who can rock a red lip and uses her hands like that.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: I kid. This is interesting. And my takeaway from just that comment from Congresswoman Ocasio-Cortez when she was talking about -- she was talking about the dirty -- the water problems in Flint, Michigan and the South Bronx. She is not pointing to something that the Green New Deal would necessarily fix. She's pointing to problems that occur, say, in the South Bronx, this is one of the most socialist cities in the nation, where you have great government control and extremely high taxes, and you still have appalling conditions that people are living in. With the Flint water crisis, again, this is something that the government did not prevent and did not stop.
