Tech Copyright Reforms; Facebook Removes Fake Accounts; U.S.-China Trade; Federal Reserve Rate Hikes; May Faces New Pressure2019-03-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:47ZLexisNexisSenate Subcommittee Holding Hearing On Aviation Safety This Afternoon; Strong Demand For Lyft IPO; Green New Deal Procedural Vote Fails In Senate; AppleQualcomm Legal Battle; E.U. Tech Copyright Reforms; Facebook Removes Fake Accounts; U.S.-China Trade; Federal Reserve Rate Hikes; May Faces New PressureLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Thank you -- thank you so much. Good morning, everyone. I'm Maria Bartiromo, happy Wednesday. It is Wednesday, March 27th, your top stories right now 6:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast. Safety in the sky, this morning, the Senate is holding a hearing today following the two deadly Boeing crashes, what to expect from that transportation hearing, as the 737 Max makes an emergency landing in Florida.

Racing toward an IPO, Lyft reportedly seeing strong demand this morning as well. The price shares above the range last night, the details ahead of Friday's opening trade. And Green No Deal, the controversy plan -- controversial plan from Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez failed in the Senate yesterday. One Senator going viral for the posters that he used to slam that deal. Plus, $750 million up for grabs tonight, that's the big Powerful drawing. MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And Futures are searching for direction this morning, we are looking at a lower opening for the broader averages, but fractionally. Dow Industrials down about 45 points right now, S&P 500 down two, and the NASDAQ down one.

Our top story this morning, lawmakers are focusing on aircraft safety this afternoon with a Senate Commerce subcommittee on aviation and space. That hearing is following the deadly crashes of the Boeing 737 Max 8 jet. This, as the same model aircraft made an emergency landing in Florida yesterday after a reported engine problem. Joining me right now is former FAA safety team representative and pilot, Kyle Bailey, is here. Kyle, great to have you on the program.

KYLE BAILEY, SAFETY TEAM REPRESENTATIVE, FAA: Good morning, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. Tell us what you think is most important in the hearing today in terms of looking at this 737 jet?

BAILEY: You know, I think as far as the FAA goes and with Boeing with the certification process, it really should be scrutinizing relationship they have, the two of them, if they're a little bit complacent, because Boeing really does a good job at the certification process. And it will be interesting to see when they investigate, you know, how the two are working together, and are they a little bit too complacent?

BARTIROMO: I see. Because Boeing unveiled a software update today to fix this problem, and I guess it's the automated system, it was thought to have caused the 737's nose to tilt down in last October's Lion Air crash. Can you explain a little about that and what the issue is?

BAILEY: So, the system -- the software update, what that -- what that will do is there's an angle of attack indicator on the airplane. One sensor was feeding into that, or one, you know, of the actual -- on the exterior of the airplane. Now, two of those are going to feed into that sensor. So, if one malfunctions, there will still be another one that is giving input. So, there will be two in place of one. Also, as far as that nose, the system pushing the nose down to make the airplane descend in a potential stall situation, the system will only do that a couple of times. So, it will not be like the pilot will be struggling over and over and over again like, you know, what might have been the case previously.

BARTIROMO: How significant is this for Boeing? I mean, obviously, you're going to talk about major lawsuits coming at the company. But do you think that this is a major problem for the business and for how it may have to redirect itself?

BAILEY: Well, you know, keep in mind, Boeing isn't just in airplanes, they're also in the defense business, but as far as the airplane business goes, I mean, I think --

BARTIROMO: It's an important product.

BAILEY: Yes. And the passengers, in general, are you know, typically fearful of flying for the most part. You know, they really have to build, you know, passenger confidence. And it'll be very interesting to see how they do that.

BARTIROMO: How can they do it?

BAILEY: You know, it's hard. I mean, they really just have to tell everybody what they're doing and prove everything. And, you know, test this airplane, test the new software to make sure everything is doing what it should be doing. So, now, you know, we've had two crashes already. I mean -- so, they're going to do the software fix. I mean, they really have to, you know, go out of their way to prove this to the general flying public that this stuff really does work.

BARTIROMO: To really communicate that they are on the -- on the issue. I'm worried about the FAA. I mean, does it surprise you that the U.S. was really the last of -- you know, in the globe in terms of grounding this jet?

BAILEY: Well, the FAA is very bureaucratic, but I have to say they do a fine job at what they do. And they typically work on the facts and statistics, so they really don't care about media pressure, they don't care about pressure from the public. I think this -- you know, incident might have changed things, but in general, they're pretty much facts and data-driven when they make decisions. So -- but this would be the exception, though.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will leave it there. Kyle, it's great to have you, thanks so much.

BAILEY: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thanks for your insights on that. Kyle Bailey there. Meanwhile, IPOs are in focus, big year, Lyft reportedly will price its stock above the range, ahead of its IPO. Dagen McDowell with more on that. Good morning, Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. Lyft-off, let's call it. So, Lyft is on its IPO road show at the moment, marketing the shares to potential investors, and it's been standing-room-only crowds, according to The Wall Street Journal. The targeted range previously talked about was between $62.00 and $68.00 a share, and now it is expected to price above that level. The Wall Street Journal says it's unlikely to be as high as $80, more likely to be in the low 70s. Nevertheless, Lyft will be valued at more than $23 billion on a fully-diluted basis when it goes public.

Here's one of the interesting things, so most of the big private companies have large shareholders, mutual fund companies that already owned shares privately. Lyft, not so much, with the exception of Fidelity Investments. So, there's a lot of demand there from mutual fund companies, potentially for this IPO because they don't have a stake in the company before it goes public. One concern is its profitability. You're looking at some of the major IPOs to watch.

This is a good sign for, say, Pinterest, Uber that will follow Lyft. And investors have told The Wall Street Journal, their concern is profitability, the path to profitability. Lyft last year lost $911 million. That was one of -- it was the biggest of any U.S. start-up in the 12 months preceding its IPO, the biggest lost there. But nevertheless, people are interested in this company, Maria.

And by the way, we talked about LEVI, LEVI is still trading. It went public, it was priced at $17.00 a share, it's trading at 22 bucks, that's a gain of 29 percent.

BARTIROMO: Yes, just in a couple of days, that was real successful. And how about Uber, what is its valuation? $120 billion or something on Uber.

MCDOWELL: A lot of upside here because Lyft is going to -- is promising that it's going to reduce its costs dramatically, reducing its insurance costs as it builds scale, so that's what they're telling investors about the path to profitability.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll keep talking about that. See you in a bit, Dagen, thank you. Meanwhile, prosecutors are facing backlash this morning after dropping all charges against actor Jussie Smollett. Lauren Simonetti with those details now and headlines. Lauren, what a story.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Maria, wow! Chicago's mayor and police chief both raising questions about why Smollett was not held accountable for allegedly faking a racist, anti-gay attack on himself to gain attention for his acting career. Prosecutors say they dropped the charges after Smollett agreed to let the city keep its $10,000 in bail and to perform community service. But Smollett may not be out of the woods just yet. An investigation into a death threat letter the actor supposedly received prior to the alleged attack has been handed over to the FBI.

Take a look at this, shares of FiatChrysler trading sharply higher, up 3-1/2 percent in the premarket. London's Financial Times is reporting that the company could be a takeover target once Renault restarts merger talks with Nissan, that in the coming months. The newspaper says the move is a new strategy following the arrest of former Renault CEO and former Nissan Chairman Carlos Ghosn on financial misconduct charges. Ghosn, of course, has denied any wrongdoing.

And it might be your lucky day, your chance to turn two bucks into 750 million. Tonight's Powerball jackpot, the fourth largest in history if someone picks the lucky numbers. They'll get a lump sum of $466 million before taxes. We always like to let you know your odds, your odds of winning, 1 in 292 million. There is a chance, Maria.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Lauren. All right, quick break. And then, coming up, Green No Deal, Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's controversial Green New Deal fails test vote in the Senate yesterday as one Senator's poster against it goes viral. We'll tell you about that one. And then, battle of the drones, UPS is rolling out the first revenue-generating drone deliveries, beating out competition from Amazon and FedEx, much more on that when we come right back. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Big program this morning, coming up. Georgia Senator, member of the Senate Budget Banking, and Armed Services, and Agricultural Committees, David Perdue is with us this morning. Tennessee Senator and a member of the subcommittee on Aviation and Space, Marsha Blackburn is here, she's going to be at that transportation hearing today. Former adviser to President George W. Bush, Fox News Contributor Karl Rove joining us. Along with the author of "The Coming Collapse of China," author Gordon Chang is with us, as U.S. officials head to Beijing -- oh, they are in Beijing already for another round of trade talks. And Fox News Senior Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. Family Medicine doctor, Mikhail Varshavski, "Dr. Mike" is here. Breakout of measles to talk about with Mike. You don't miss a moment of it.

Meanwhile, the Green New Deal was denied yesterday. The Senate voted 57-0 against a procedural motion to take up the resolution. Most Democrats voted present to protest the GOP's action. A fiery response by freshman Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez to push back from Congressman Sean Duffy. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. SEAN DUFFY (R), WISCONSIN: The Green New Deal is one that if you're a rich liberal from maybe New York or California, it sounds great because you can afford to retrofit your home or build a new home that has zero emissions, that's energy efficient, affordable and safe.

REP. ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ (D), NEW YORK: You want to tell people that their concern and their desire for clean air and clean water is elitists? Tell that to the kids in the South Bronx which are suffering from the highest rates of childhood asthma in the country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining the conversation this morning, the founder and CEO of Cheddar, Jon Steinberg is here, along with New Leaders Senior Fellow, Fox News Contributor, Richard Fowler. Dagen McDowell, that was some hearing yesterday on the Green New Deal, it looked like theatrics more than anything else. How did you see them?

MCDOWELL: I will not throw shade at a lady who can rock a red lip and uses her hands like that.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: I kid. This is interesting. And my takeaway from just that comment from Congresswoman Ocasio-Cortez when she was talking about -- she was talking about the dirty -- the water problems in Flint, Michigan and the South Bronx. She is not pointing to something that the Green New Deal would necessarily fix. She's pointing to problems that occur, say, in the South Bronx, this is one of the most socialist cities in the nation, where you have great government control and extremely high taxes, and you still have appalling conditions that people are living in. With the Flint water crisis, again, this is something that the government did not prevent and did not stop. So if she thinks that government is the solution, she just gave two examples of the government being the problem.

BARTIROMO: Yes. What do you think, Richard?

RICHARD FOWLER, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Listen, I think the Green New Deal was a -- is a framework, right? Like I said, I don't think it's the perfect solution but here lies the problem. So we saw -- and I'm pretty sure we'll show the clip later of Utah Senator Mike Lee showing all these pictures of -- I think Ronald Reagan sitting on top of --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Let's take a look at this because that was Senator Mike Lee yesterday and it went viral. His posters which slammed the Green New Deal. Here is one example.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. MIKE LEE (R), UTAH: I rise today to consider the Green New Deal with the seriousness it deserves. This is a picture of Aquaman, a superhero from the undersea kingdom of Atlantis. I draw your attention, Mr. President, to the 20-foot impressive seahorse he's riding. Under the Green New Deal, this is probably Hawaii's best bet.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: It is pretty funny.

FOWLER: It is funny and I'm pretty sure the Kinkos stocks should be going through the roof right now because he made a lot of -- he spent a lot in printing. But here is the truth is that both the United Nations, the Congressional report, the fact is that climate change is a real thing, right? And I think what we have on one side is the Green New Deal, I'm not saying it's the best solution but on the other side you have folks likes Senator Mike Lee saying that climate change, nothing to see here, nothing is happening and I think that is part of the problem.

MCDOWELL: Mitch McConnell didn't know. Mitch McConnell actually is now on the record as saying I'm talking about climate change.

(CROSSTALK)

FOWLER: They haven't given any solutions and I think the solution exist sometimes in the middle when Democrats, Republican, businesses come together and say, OK, we have a problem here and that's actually trying to figure out some real solutions because the real problems like Super Storm Sandy flooding.

BARTIROMO: It's a nice thing to say that this is just a framework but it actually -- it is legislation that she would like to bring to the -- that she would like to see materialize, so it's not just a framework.

JON STEINBERG, CEO & FOUNDER, CHEDDAR: But to your point, Maria, it's basically nonexistent on facts right now.

BARTIROMO: Right.

STEINBERG: No one actually knows what's in the Green New Deal, the world is ending in 10 years, apparently it's causing asthma in New York City. But what we've seen here is the politicians level of marketing skill has completely evolve. I think largely as a result of President Trump, we have people now that know how to message, know how to use gimmicks, you've got presentations skills from somebody like AOC that are spectacular.

The way she presents, the way she speaks and we're entering sort of an area where this is what's going to define, you know, the movements that happened in this country. This socialism thing is unbelievably dangerous whether it's the Green New Deal or the pied-a-terre tax or the -- under the real estate kill tax basically in New York City. This kind of stuff is going to make things happen.

MCDOWELL: The Green New Deal proposes explicitly retrofitting every house in America. This is the Wall Street Journal's editorial today. And eliminating fossil fuels within a decade. That is higher energy cost, it will hurt lower-income Americans more than anyone else and our standard of living as a nation will suffer and they have to answer to that. Instead all of these yesterday, Democratic presidential candidates voted present. The Journal is calling it profiles and present which is hilarious.

BARTIROMO: So, it's -- that's the thing, I mean, you could say, yes, climate change is an issue, she could have just said that but to come up with this whole plan that is specific in terms of getting rid of fossil fuels in the next 10 years doesn't make any sense and that's why they're --

(CROSSTALK)

FOWLER: Yes. I mean, I think the -- but the truth of the matter here is that her plan sits on one side and on the opposite side of the aisle there is nothing, there is no plan, there is zero, there is an empty box, right? And I think if you look at -- if you look at recent polls you will see millennials in the Republican side are saying climate change is real and their party doesn't have an answer to that.

MCDOWELL: Well, the answer will be is that a carbon-free future is one -- is it creates a nation that you don't want to live in.

FOWLER: But that's not coming from the President or the party.

MCDOWELL: But you -- and also well, they -- we talk about it endlessly on this program and it is private industry that has not only lowered our emissions --

STEINBERG: Absolutely, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: -- with the use of natural gas, it is private industry and getting out of the way of using and developing and discovering in a new way those very fossil fuels that are plentiful in this country that keep people's energy costs down.

BARTIROMO: So there is a plan and Corporate America has been executing that plant --

(CROSSTALK)

STEINBERG: Look at the electric car move, you know, we can -- you know, we all, you know, punch at Elon Musk for his craziness all day long. He's done more to affect, you know, hybrid and electric vehicles in this country than any amount of legislation, any amount of tax credits. He just --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: I forgot throw punches at Elon Musk although I think he's been a jerk in the past, I think that this is -- he ultimately by creating a cool car, he will get more people behind the wheel of the electric vehicle without AOC and her cronies telling us what kind of car to buy.

(CROSSTALK)

STEINBERG: I tried to do solar, you can't get it done on your house.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: And you can't get it done on your car because the sun is now always shining. We'll take a quick break. When we come back. The Federal Reserve is in focus. President Trump's expected nominee Stephen Moore reportedly in favor of the Central Bank cutting rates at this point. We're going to get into that. And then time for a change. Colorado's governor unveiling a new state logo. But it's his look that's gone viral. We'll be right back with that.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Headlines across America this morning. The Las Vegas review Journal says that giving Nevada a raise, minimum wage of $12 is possible by 2024. Proposed legislation raising minimum that wage to $12 an hour for workers not offered health insurance, $11 for those who are. The increase would be gradual, 75 cents a year beginning in 2020. Did you know Empire reporting an Alaska moose hunter can rev up his hovercraft according to the U.S. Supreme Court.

Justices reeling at the National Park Service was wrong to ban John Sturgeon from using his hovercraft on a river running through a national preserve. The panel decided the agency does not have the jurisdiction over that stretch of land. The Denver post this morning writing, Governor Jarid Polis unveils new Colorado logo with a tree and a sea from the state flag. He says the new look better reflects Colorado and will not cause taxpayers any more money.

The Governor wearing a winter hat featuring the colorful logo during his presentation and that hack up plenty of comments on social media. Colorado's new logo.

FOWLER: I like it.

STEINBERG: He was my classmate at Princeton. He was my classmate.

BARTIROMO: Is that right?

STEINBERG: Yes. He was always doing like start-ups and all sort of stuff.

MCDOWELL: That's awesome.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: I think Colorado is the coolest -- one of the coolest states in the country. I lived there for a couple of years and it's -- I think it -- the people in Colorado are also the thinnest in the nation because they're so --

(CROSSTALK)

STEINBERG: I want to ask you about the moose thing, OK?

(CROSSTALK)

STEINBERG: -- because you know -- because you've mentioned some of the outdoor stuff to me before in the green room. Like isn't hunting a moose in a hovercraft won't actually the moose off?

MCDOWELL: Is he hunting it?

STEINBERG: He was hunting moose in the hovercraft, right?

BARTIROMO: I don't know that he was hunting, no.

STEINBERG: Oh, he was just chasing those.

MCDOWELL: No. I think it was stretch of water.

BARTIROMO: It's a stretch of water.

MCDOWELL: It went through -- I don't know, I have to go read the story but I don't -- yes. But it depends on how loud his hovercraft is. I like how you turn to me from moose.

urn:contentItem:5X3B-R4C1-JDH1-C0XF-00000-00Senate tech critic tells Facebook CEO: Sell message services2019-09-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:47ZLexisNexisBUSINESSSenate tech critic tells Facebook CEO: Sell message services

WASHINGTON - The Senate's most vocal critic of the tech industry offered a challenge Thursday to Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg: Sell your WhatsApp and Instagram properties to prove you're serious about protecting data privacy.

It may have been more than Zuckerberg expected from his private meeting with Sen. Josh Hawley, a conservative Republican from Missouri, in his Capitol Hill office. Zuckerberg left the hourlong meeting - one of several with lawmakers on Capitol Hill - without answering questions from a throng of reporters and photographers pursuing him down a hallway.

Hawley, though, had plenty to say. "The company talks a lot. I'd like to see some action," he told reporters. "I will believe Facebook when I see some real action out of Facebook."

Rather than moving users' personal data from properties such as WhatsApp and Instagram to the core Facebook platform, the company should put a wall around the messaging services or, better yet, sell them off, Hawley said he told Zuckerberg.

Zuckerberg, who requested the meeting, "did not think that was a great idea," he said.

A Facebook spokesman declined to comment.

The popular messaging services are among some 70 companies that Facebook has acquired over the past 15 years or so, giving the company what critics say is massive market power that has allowed it to snuff out competition.

Zuckerberg's discussion with Hawley touched on industry competition, data privacy legislation, election security and accusations by conservatives that Facebook and other social media giants are biased against right-leaning content.

During his visit, Zuckerberg also met with other senators including Mark Warner, D-Va., vice chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, and Mike Lee, R-Utah, a senior member of the Senate Judiciary Committee. He also declined to answer reporters' questions when he left Lee's office earlier in the afternoon.

Lee's office said the two discussed bias against conservatives on Facebook's platform, regulation of online services, enforcement of antitrust laws in the tech industry and data privacy issues.

Congress has been debating a privacy law that could sharply rein in the ability of companies like Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple to collect and make money off users' personal data. A national law, which would be the first of its kind in the U.S., could allow people to see or prohibit use of their data.

Acting preemptively, Zuckerberg last spring called for tighter regulations to protect consumers' data, control harmful online content, and ensure election integrity and data portability. The internet "needs new rules," he said.

It was Zuckerberg's first public visit to Washington since he testified before Congress last spring about privacy, election interference and other issues.

Facebook, a social media giant based in Menlo Park, California, with nearly 2.5 billion users, is under heavy scrutiny from lawmakers and regulators following a series of privacy scandals and amid accusations of abuse of its market power to squash competition.

The Justice Department, the Federal Trade Commission and the House Judiciary antitrust subcommittee are all conducting antitrust investigations of the big tech companies, and a bipartisan group of state attorneys general has opened a competition probe specifically of Facebook.

At Facebook's request, Warner helped organize a dinner meeting in Washington on Wednesday night for Zuckerberg and a group of senators.

Warner told The Associated Press that he wanted Zuckerberg to hear his Senate colleagues' "enormous concerns about privacy and about protecting the integrity of our political system."

Their message for the Facebook chief was "self-regulation is not going to be the answer," Warner said. "I think Zuckerberg understood that."

Warner and Hawley have proposed legislation that would force the tech giants to tell users what data they're collecting from them and how much it's worth. The proposal goes to the heart of Big Tech's hugely profitable business model of commerce in users' personal data. The companies gather vast data on what users read and like, and leverage it to help advertisers target their messages to individuals they want to reach.

The tech companies view with particular alarm a separate legislative proposal from Hawley that would require them to prove to regulators that they're not using political bias to filter content. Failing to secure a bias-free audit from the government would mean a social media platform loses its long-held immunity from legal action.
